subsection.text: In this Division I of this article the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Community assistance” means activities designed to enhance the physical, social, or economic environment of a community to improve the health, safety, or socio–economic welfare of its citizens.

“Community assistance” includes the promotion of activities specified in paragraph (1) of this subsection through the concentration and coordination in communities in the State of federal, State, regional, and local public and private resources.

subsection.text: “County” means a county of the State or Baltimore City.
“Department” means the Department of Housing and Community Development.

paragraph.text: “Financial assistance” means any form of assurance, guarantee, grant, payment, or other assistance.
“Financial assistance” includes a loan, loan guarantee, or reduction in the principal obligations of or rate of interest payable on a loan or portion of a loan.

subsection.text: “Governmental unit” means an agency, authority, board, commission, council, office, or other unit or instrumentality of the government of the State or of a political subdivision of the State.

“Nonprofit organization” means a corporation, foundation, or other legal entity, no part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of a private shareholder or individual holding an interest in the entity.
“Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, representative of any kind, partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.
“Political subdivision” means a county or municipal corporation of the State.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Housing and Community Development.

section.text: There is a Department of Housing and Community Development, established as a principal department of State government.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: encourage and assist political subdivisions and public and private community organizations to develop mutual and cooperative solutions to their common problems;

serve as a clearinghouse for information and materials that may be pertinent to sound community assistance, including information on available federal, State, and private financial assistance and technical assistance;
implement model or demonstration programs and projects or otherwise provide a program of practical research in community assistance;
provide grants and loans for energy conservation and the use of solar energy in commercial and residential buildings;

provide advisory, consultative, training, and educational services, and technical assistance to any political subdivision, local public agency, or nonprofit organization for community assistance purposes;

contract for and accept a gift, grant, contribution, or loan of money, property, or other aid for community assistance from a governmental unit, the federal government, or another source and comply with the terms and conditions of that aid;
attach terms and conditions to financial assistance as the Secretary determines;

participate with political subdivisions, regional governments, organizations, and the federal government in developing, financing, and implementing a program to build the management capabilities of municipal corporations by supplying needed managerial expertise through circuit riding managers;
administer federal programs to community assistance; and

develop and implement a weatherization program in accordance with Title 4 of this article and administer the low–income weatherization component of the electric universal service program in accordance with § 7–512.1 of the Public Utilities Article.

subsection.text: The Department may:

paragraph.text: sell any mortgage or other obligation that the Department holds at public or private sale, with or without public bidding;
retain the servicing rights and charge servicing fees for any mortgage or other obligation that the Department sells; and
apply the proceeds from any sale and servicing fees earned to any of the funds established under Title 4, Subtitle 5 of this article.
With the advice and consent of the Senate, the Governor shall appoint the Secretary.
The Secretary is the head of the Department.

subsection.text: Before taking office, the Secretary shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The Secretary serves at the pleasure of the Governor and is directly responsible to the Governor.
The Secretary shall counsel and advise the Governor on all matters assigned to the Department and is responsible for carrying out the Governor’s policies on those matters.

subsection.text: The Secretary is entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.
The Secretary is responsible for the operation of the Department and shall establish guidelines and procedures to promote the orderly and efficient administration of the Department.
The Secretary may establish, reorganize, or abolish areas of responsibility in the Office of the Secretary as necessary to fulfill the duties assigned to the Secretary.

section.text: The Secretary shall have a seal.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint a deputy secretary.
The deputy secretary:

paragraph.text: serves at the pleasure of the Secretary; and
is entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The deputy secretary shall have the duties provided by law or delegated by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: In the Office of the Secretary, the Secretary shall have assistants, professional consultants, and employees as provided in the State budget.
The Secretary may designate a staff assistant to be in charge of a particular area of responsibility within the Office of the Secretary.

subsection.text: In the Office of the Secretary:

paragraph.text: each staff assistant in charge of a particular area of responsibility and each professional consultant serves at the pleasure of the Secretary; and
except as otherwise provided by law, the Secretary shall appoint and may remove all other employees in accordance with the State Personnel and Pensions Article.

subsection.text: The appointment or removal of personnel by a governmental unit in the Department is subject to the approval of the Secretary.
The Secretary may delegate this power of approval to the head or governing body of the governmental unit.

section.text: Each governmental unit in the Department shall report to the Secretary or the Secretary’s designee as provided in regulations or written directives that the Secretary issues.

Whenever law provides that an appointment is to be made by the Secretary with the approval of the Governor and the appointee is to serve at the pleasure of the Secretary, the Secretary may not remove the appointee without the prior approval of the Governor.

subsection.text: The Secretary is responsible for adopting regulations for the Office of the Secretary.
The Secretary shall review and may approve, disapprove, or revise the regulations of each governmental unit in the Department.

section.text: The Secretary is responsible for the budget of each governmental unit in the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary is responsible for the coordination and direction of all planning initiatives of the Secretary.
The Secretary shall keep apprised of and may approve, disapprove, or modify plans, proposals, and projects of the Department and its governmental units.

section.text: The Secretary may call a special meeting of a governmental unit in the Department whenever the Secretary considers it necessary.
The Secretary may exercise or perform any power, duty, responsibility, or function assigned to a governmental unit in the Department.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a governmental unit in the Department to the extent that the governmental unit is authorized by law to employ its own legal adviser or counsel.
The Attorney General is the legal adviser to the Department.
The Attorney General shall assign to the Department the number of assistant Attorneys General authorized by law for the Department and its governmental units.
An assistant Attorney General shall be a lawyer of the State in good standing.
An assistant Attorney General is entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General shall designate one of the assistant Attorneys General as counsel to the Department and may not reassign the counsel without consulting the Secretary.
The counsel to the Department has no duty other than to:

subparagraph.text: give the legal aid, advice, and counsel that the Secretary and the other officials of the Department require; and
supervise the other assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Department.

paragraph.text: The counsel shall perform the duties specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection subject to the control and discretion of the Attorney General.
The counsel and the other assistant Attorneys General in the Department shall perform those duties that the Attorney General assigns.

The Attorney General may require an assistant Attorney General to perform, subject to the Attorney General’s control and discretion, any duty for the Department required of the Attorney General by law.

section.text: The Department consists of:

paragraph.text: the Division of Credit Assurance;
the Division of Development Finance;
the Division of Neighborhood Revitalization;
the Community Development Administration;
the Community Legacy Program;
the Housing Finance Review Committee;
the Lead Hazard Advisory Committee;
the Maryland Housing Fund;
the Neighborhood Business Development Program; and
any other governmental unit that under law is a part of the Department.
The Department shall establish advisory councils, boards, and committees as the Governor and the Secretary determine.
The Governor and the Secretary shall determine:

subparagraph.text: the size of the advisory bodies;
the qualifications, method of appointment, terms, and compensation of members;
the manner of removal of members; and
the method of filling vacancies.

subsection.text: The advisory units shall advise and assist the Secretary on policies, programs, and activities of the Department.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Division” means the Division of Credit Assurance.
There is a Division of Credit Assurance.
The Division includes:

paragraph.text: the Maryland Housing Fund, a governmental unit of the Department;
loan asset management for the Department; and
the administration of statewide building and material codes established under Title 12, Subtitles 2, 3, 4, 5, and 10 of the Public Safety Article.

section.text: The Division shall administer each program assigned to the Division by law or by the Secretary.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Credit enhancement” means a guarantee, including a guarantee of an obligation backed by a pool of mortgages, or other assurance or security device issued to:

paragraph.text: improve the credit of a qualified borrowing entity; or
upgrade the security or rating of a financial obligation, including:

subparagraph.text: a mortgage backed security;
a certificate of participation; and
a bond or note issued to finance a development activity described in this subtitle.

subsection.text: “Energy conservation project” has the meaning stated in § 4-201 of this article.
“Financing” includes acquisition financing, permanent financing, short-term bridge financing, construction financing, and refinancing of a loan or project authorized under this subtitle.
“Fund” means the Maryland Housing Fund.
“Housing” includes:

paragraph.text: a single dwelling unit;
a multiple dwelling unit;
an accessory unit residential facility;
a shared-living unit facility, accommodating at least two individuals or families, in which some or all of the living, dining, kitchen, or sanitary facilities are shared; and
an ancillary commercial or other facility that is related to, incidental to, and supportive of the housing.

subsection.text: “Infrastructure project” has the meaning stated in § 4-201 of this article.
“Mortgage” includes:

paragraph.text: a deed of trust, a security agreement, and a pledge; and
any other security arrangement securing a loan, including a mortgage, to finance:

subparagraph.text: the purchase of stock or membership in a cooperative ownership housing corporation; or
the construction or rehabilitation of dwelling units in a cooperative ownership housing corporation.

subsection.text: “Public purpose project” has the meaning stated in § 4-201 of this article.
“Solar energy project” has the meaning stated in § 4-201 of this article.

paragraph.text: The General Assembly finds that:

subparagraph.text: the flow of private investment capital into adequate housing can be stimulated by a system insuring qualified lending institutions against losses resulting from nonpayment of money owed under the terms of a note, bond, or other evidence of indebtedness; and
the insurance can help State and local activity to finance housing and rehabilitation.

paragraph.text: The General Assembly also finds that adequate housing can and should be provided by private capital under our free enterprise system and in accordance with sound investment practices.
The General Assembly finds as a subject of concern that:

subparagraph.text: many residents of the State are living in substandard housing; and
there is a shortage of housing at reasonable costs for various income levels.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that it is in the public interest to promote energy conservation projects and solar energy projects by providing insurance for:

paragraph.text: loans made by qualified lending institutions; and
bonds or notes issued to finance the projects.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that the sale of pooled mortgages or securities backed by mortgages to private or public investors, including public and private pension funds, is in the public interest and could increase the investment capital available to make mortgage loans to acquire, construct, and rehabilitate housing.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “distressed area” has the meaning stated in § 4-201 of this article.

The General Assembly finds that it is in the public interest to encourage the financing of, and otherwise to support, the planning, acquisition, development, construction, reconstruction, rehabilitation, repair, renovation, and other improvement of:

subparagraph.text: public purpose projects in distressed areas in the State; and
infrastructure projects.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that the flow of public and private capital to support the activities specified in this section will be encouraged and expanded by:

paragraph.text: insuring:

subparagraph.text: loans made by qualified lending institutions;
bonds or notes issued by qualified issuers; and
obligations backed by mortgages; and

paragraph.text: providing other credit enhancements.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Housing Fund.
The Fund shall further the State interests expressed in § 3-202 of this subtitle.
The Department shall manage and supervise the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing special fund that is not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Department shall deposit money for the Fund with the State Treasurer.

The money shall be held in the financial institutions that the State Treasurer considers proper and shall be accounted for by the Comptroller in a special account known as the “Maryland Housing Fund”.
All premium and fee income shall be credited to the Fund to operate the Fund and to provide additional insurance, guarantees, and credit enhancement.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated by the State to the Fund;
proceeds of any State loan to the extent provided by the General Assembly or any governmental unit authorized to issue bonds for the Fund;
fees and premiums that the Department receives in connection with insurance or other credit enhancement provided by the Fund; and
all other money made available to the Department from any source for the purposes set forth in this subtitle.

subsection.text: Money in the Fund shall be invested in the same manner as other State money.

paragraph.text: Money in the Fund shall be used to:

subparagraph.text: insure loans that the Department accepts under this subtitle;
insure bonds or notes issued to finance a project that is eligible for insurance under this subtitle; and
provide other forms of credit enhancement under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Money in the Fund that by agreement, contract, secretarial determination, or regulation has been created as an identifiable insurance or credit reserve may be used only in conformance with the terms and conditions creating the reserve.

subsection.text: The Secretary may transfer to any reserve:

paragraph.text: operational money;
earnings not yet allocated to a particular reserve;
State appropriated money;
proceeds of State general obligation bonds; or
other money received and not allocated to a particular reserve.

Beginning in fiscal year 2010, if the balance of the unallocated reserve of the Fund at the end of any fiscal year exceeds $10,000,000, the excess over $10,000,000 shall be transferred by the Governor to the:

subparagraph.text: Homeownership Programs Fund established under § 4–502 of this article;
Rental Housing Programs Fund established under § 4–504 of this article; and
Special Loan Programs Fund established under § 4–505 of this article.

paragraph.text: The distribution of any money transferred from the Fund to the Homeownership Programs Fund, the Rental Housing Programs Fund, and the Special Loan Programs Fund shall be at the discretion of the Secretary.

section.text: Insurance, a guarantee, or other credit enhancement provided under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: does not pledge the faith, credit, or taxing power of the State or the Department; and
is payable only to the extent of the reserve or other identified money backing the insurance, guarantee, or credit enhancement.

subsection.text: In this section, “development costs” has the meaning stated in § 4-201 of this article.
The Department, in its own name or in the name of the Fund:

paragraph.text: may insure or guarantee on terms that it specifies a mortgage or pool of mortgages offered or bonds or notes issued that are eligible for insurance under § 3-202 of this subtitle;
may insure a total of not more than $30,000,000 of bridge loans that are:

subparagraph.text: made for part of the development costs of rental housing projects that are awarded federal low income housing tax credits; and
secured by personal rather than real property;

paragraph.text: may provide other forms of credit enhancement on terms that it specifies for qualified lenders and borrowers who otherwise cannot get credit enhancement in the private market;
may issue obligations in any form backed by a pool of mortgages, including:

subparagraph.text: securities;
certificates of participation;
grantor trusts;
collateralized mortgage obligations; and
pass-through certificates;

paragraph.text: notwithstanding Titles 10 through 17 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, after a default under an obligation that is insured or otherwise backed by a credit enhancement under this subtitle, may acquire, hold, improve, operate pending sale or other disposition, sell, assign, exchange, transfer, convey, lease, mortgage, or otherwise dispose of or encumber:

subparagraph.text: real property or an interest in real property;
personal property or an interest in personal property; or
evidence of indebtedness, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: pass-through certificates;
residual interests; and
other securities backed by real estate or a mortgage; and

paragraph.text: in connection with a property, whether or not insured by the Fund, acquired by the Department or the Fund through foreclosure, through deed in lieu of foreclosure, or in settlement for a claim for loss:

subparagraph.text: may contract with a private party for services to secure, maintain, operate, or improve the property in anticipation of disposition of the property, without requiring that the contract comply with Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article; or
may make a mortgage loan to assist in the disposition of the property.

subsection.text: In offering insurance and other forms of credit enhancement, the Department shall adopt eligibility standards that are reasonable to aid in:

paragraph.text: financing the purchase, construction, or rehabilitation of:

subparagraph.text: housing projects;
special housing facility projects, consisting of the acquisition, rehabilitation, improvement, renovation, construction, financing, or refinancing of a building that:

sub-subparagraph.text: provides common, shared, or independent living, dining, kitchen, sanitary, and sleeping facilities;
may include supportive services or supervisory live-in personnel for individuals with specialized housing needs; and
may include nonresidential facilities to serve individuals with special needs who may or may not be residents of the special housing facility;

subparagraph.text: rehabilitation projects, as defined in § 4-901 of this article;
energy conservation projects;
solar energy projects;
public purpose projects; or
infrastructure projects; and

paragraph.text: the sale or other transfer of an obligation that is:

subparagraph.text: denoted as a bond, note, collateralized obligation, grantor trust, conduit, or other form of security or obligation; and
backed directly or indirectly by a mortgage or a payment derived from a mortgage.

subsection.text: The standards adopted under subsection (a) of this section shall ensure that a lender benefiting from insurance or other credit enhancement provided by the Department is responsible and able to service the loan.
A determination by the Secretary is conclusive if it relates to the eligibility of a project, facility, or undertaking for:

paragraph.text: insurance or other credit enhancement; or
other action taken by the Department, in its own name or in the name of the Fund, under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Department shall adopt regulations that are necessary to carry out the purpose of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Annually, on or before December 1, the Department shall make a written report to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the financial status of the Fund and its operations for the preceding fiscal year.
The report shall include the types and amount of:

subparagraph.text: insurance reserves;
insurance issued;
premiums charged; and
claims made.

section.text: This subtitle shall be liberally construed to carry out the findings set forth in § 3-202 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Community Development Administration.
“Division” means the Division of Development Finance.
“Elderly household” means one or more individuals who occupy a residential dwelling unit, at least one of whom meets the age limit specified by the Secretary that:

paragraph.text: is greater than or equal to age 55; and
may vary for different programs or types of projects.

subsection.text: “Elderly rental housing project” means a project that meets the qualifications in § 4-407 of this title.
“Nonprofit sponsor” means a sponsor that is:

paragraph.text: a nonprofit organization; or
a limited partnership, if:

sub-subparagraph.text: each general partner is a nonprofit organization; or
each general partner is a wholly owned subsidiary of a nonprofit organization;

subparagraph.text: the limited partnership is formed to undertake a project that is eligible as a whole or in part for a federal program or incentive, including low-income housing tax credits; and
a nonprofit organization manages the project or will receive the net cash flow or residual sale proceeds on the sale of the project.

section.text: There is a Division of Development Finance.
The Division includes:

paragraph.text: the Community Development Administration;
the Disaster Relief Housing Program;
the Down Payment and Settlement Expense Loan Program;
the Elderly Rental Housing Program;
federal and State weatherization programs;
the Group Home Financing Program;
the Lead Hazard Reduction Grant Program;
the Lead Hazard Reduction Loan Program;
the local government infrastructure program;
the Maryland Home Financing Program;
the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program;
the Neighborhood Housing Services Fund;
the Operating Assistance Grants Demonstration Projects;
the Partnership Rental Housing Program;
the Radium Pilot Grant Program;
the Rental Allowance Program and other rental assistance programs;
the Rental Housing Production Program; and
the Self–Help Homeownership Technical Assistance Program.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commercial building” means any building that:

paragraph.text: is used primarily to carry on a business whether or not for profit;
is not a residential building; and
is not used primarily to manufacture or produce raw materials, products, or agricultural commodities.

subsection.text: “Commercial energy audit” means:

paragraph.text: an energy audit performed for purposes of Title VII of the National Energy Conservation Policy Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 6201 through 6422; or
an onsite inspection of a commercial building that includes a determination of, and provides information on:

subparagraph.text: the type, quantity, and rate of energy consumption of the building;
the maintenance and operation procedures to reduce the energy consumption of the building; and
the cost of implementing an appropriate energy conservation project, a solar energy project, or both, and the savings in energy costs likely to result from the project.

subsection.text: “Community development project” means a project that qualifies under § 4-217 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: “Development costs” means the costs that the Department considers reasonable and necessary to carry out:

subparagraph.text: a community development project;
an energy conservation project;
a home improvement project;
an infrastructure project;
a public purpose project;
a solar energy project; or
a special housing facility.

paragraph.text: “Development costs” includes:

subparagraph.text: the costs of:

sub-subparagraph.text: studies, surveys, plans and specifications, and architectural, engineering, or other special services;
acquisition of land and any buildings on the land;
site preparation and development, construction, reconstruction, rehabilitation, and improvement; and
acquisition of machinery, equipment, and furnishings;

subparagraph.text: expenses incurred in connection with initial occupancy or operation of the project;
an allocable portion of the administrative and operating expenses of the Department;

the cost of financing the project, including interest on bonds and notes issued to finance the project from the date issued to the date the Department determines that the project is substantially occupied or substantially in operation; and

the cost of other items, including indemnity and surety bonds, premiums on insurance, fees, relocation costs, and charges and expenses of trustees, depositories, and paying agents for bonds and notes issued.

subsection.text: “Director” means the Director of the Administration.
“Energy conservation project” means a project that qualifies under § 4-218 of this subtitle.
“Family of limited income” means a family or individual whose income does not exceed the upper income limits established by the Secretary under § 4-212 of this subtitle.
“Home improvement project” means a project that qualifies under § 4-219 of this subtitle.
“Infrastructure project” means a project that qualifies under § 4-220 of this subtitle.
“Limited dividend corporation” means a corporation that:

paragraph.text: qualifies as a limited dividend corporation under the Moderate-Income Rental Program of the National Housing Act, Title 12, Chapter 13 of the United States Code; and
is operated only to further a community development project.

subsection.text: “Local development agency” means the governmental unit of a political subdivision that the chief executive officer of the political subdivision designates to carry out community development under this subtitle.

“Local development entity” means a corporation or foundation, no part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of a private shareholder or individual, that is organized and operated primarily to foster, encourage, and assist community development in the State.
“Local obligation” means a bond, note, or other obligation of a political subdivision or a governmental unit of a political subdivision.
“Public purpose project” means a project that qualifies under § 4-221 of this subtitle.
“Residential building” means a single family or multifamily structure that is used primarily for human dwelling and that has a system for heating, cooling, or both.
“Residential energy audit” means:

paragraph.text: an inspection or energy audit of a residential building or a dwelling unit in a residential building performed for purposes of Title II or Title VII of the National Energy Conservation Policy Act, Title 42, Chapter 91 of the United States Code; or
an onsite inspection of a residential building or a dwelling unit in a residential building that includes a determination of and provides information on:

subparagraph.text: the type, quantity, and rate of energy consumption of the building or dwelling unit;
maintenance and operating procedures to reduce the energy consumption of the residential building or dwelling unit; and
the cost of implementing an appropriate energy conservation project, solar energy project, or both, and the savings in energy costs that are likely to result from the project.

subsection.text: “Residential mortgage loan” means a loan, including a temporary loan or advance, that is secured by a mortgage of real property in the State that is:

paragraph.text: improved by a residential building; or
unimproved, if the loan proceeds are to be used to construct a residential building.

subsection.text: “Solar energy project” means a project that qualifies under § 4-222 of this subtitle.
“Special housing facility” means a project or undertaking for the refinancing, acquisition, rehabilitation, improvement, renovation, or construction of a building that:

paragraph.text: will be occupied in substantial part by families of limited income;
will provide common, shared, or independent living, dining, kitchen, sanitary, and sleeping facilities;
may include supportive services or supervisory live-in personnel for individuals with specialized housing needs;
may include nonresidential facilities to serve individuals with special needs who need not be residents of the project or undertaking; and
is not subject to § 4-213(b) of this subtitle.

section.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: in this era of rapid population growth and expansion and of increasing urbanization, there is a need in many areas of the State to promote sound community development;

the political subdivisions do not have adequate resources to deal effectively with all of the problems of sound community development, and the ordinary operations of private enterprise cannot deal with them without State assistance;
there is a need to coordinate and concentrate federal, State, regional, and local public and private community development efforts and resources;

there is a shortage of adequate, safe, and sanitary housing for families of limited income, and increasing the housing supply for families of limited income will ease the shortage and promote sound community development;
increasing opportunities for homeownership is desirable and promotes sound community development;

reducing energy consumption and increasing the use of solar energy by providing financial assistance to encourage energy conservation and solar energy improvements to residential buildings and commercial buildings promote sound community development and the public interest;
the public infrastructure maintained by political subdivisions, including streets, sidewalks, curbs, sewer and water systems, bridges, and public buildings, needs rehabilitation and construction;
the resources necessary for financing infrastructure projects have become scarcer in recent years;

providing an additional, accessible, and uncomplicated mechanism to finance infrastructure projects promotes sound community development, is vital to a strong economy, improves the quality of the environment, and otherwise promotes the health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the State;
promoting sound community development is a proper public purpose and State use, for which public money may be spent and property may be acquired; and
the functions and responsibilities of the Administration set forth in this subtitle are necessary to achieve the ends listed in this section.

subsection.text: To attract and retain teachers in the State by increasing homeownership opportunities, the General Assembly finds that there is a need to authorize the Department to develop a program to dedicate up to $25,000,000 over 5 years to provide mortgage loans to teachers at interest rates below the prevailing interest rate for similar programs.

paragraph.text: A mortgage loan under this section shall be available to a teacher who is a first-time home buyer.
The loan shall be conditioned on an agreement by the teacher to teach in the State for at least 3 years if work is available for the teacher.
The loan shall be used to purchase property in a priority funding area as defined in §§ 5-7B-02 and 5-7B-03 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: The Administration shall develop the program in consultation with:

paragraph.text: the State Department of Education, to ensure that the program is consistent with the State’s strategy to attract and retain teachers; and
local boards of education, to ensure that the program is properly marketed.

section.text: There is a Community Development Administration.
The Administration is created to:

paragraph.text: coordinate activities and programs that contribute to sound community development;
encourage and facilitate the development of new and existing communities by reducing the costs of development through grants, loans, and other forms of financial assistance;
encourage and facilitate energy conservation and the use of solar energy in residential buildings and commercial buildings through grants, loans, and other forms of financial assistance;
make land available for sound community development; and
assist the efforts of private enterprise, political subdivisions, local public agencies, local development entities, and nonprofit organizations.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a grant of land or money may be made only to a political subdivision, a local development entity, a local development agency, or a nonprofit organization.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to grants that may be awarded to the Administration under federal law.
The Administration may award grants to home buyers for settlement expenses as provided by the Department under this title.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint the Director.
The Director serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.
The position of Director is in the executive service or management service of the State Personnel Management System.
The Director shall operate and exercise the powers of the Administration under the direction of the Secretary and in accordance with this subtitle.
The Director is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation as provided in the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Director shall have a staff and professional consultants as provided in the State budget.
There is a Housing Finance Review Committee.
The Housing Finance Review Committee consists of seven members appointed by the Governor on recommendation of the Secretary as follows:

paragraph.text: three employees of the Department, one of whom may be the Secretary;
one employee of the Executive Branch of State government who is not employed by the Department; and
three members of the public.
The term of a public member is 4 years and begins on July 1.
At the end of a term, a public member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A public member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Housing Finance Review Committee shall review and make recommendations to the Secretary about:

subparagraph.text: specific loan requests or categories of loan requests; and
the investment and project financing policies of the Administration.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may approve a specific loan request without a recommendation of the Housing Finance Review Committee if the request requires urgent action.

subsection.text: The Administration shall:

paragraph.text: assist the Governor in coordinating the activities of governmental units of the State that affect the solution of community development problems and the implementation of community plans;
encourage and assist political subdivisions to develop mutual and cooperative solutions to their common problems;

serve as a clearinghouse for information and other materials that may be pertinent to sound community development, including information on available federal, State, and private financial and technical assistance;
carry out continuing studies and analyses of sound community development in cooperation with the Department of Planning;
make recommendations, in cooperation with the Department of Planning, for administrative or legislative action, paying particular attention to the problems of metropolitan, suburban, and other areas;

implement model or demonstration programs and projects, contract to administer functions or services in a political subdivision, or otherwise provide a program of practical research in community development;
promote community development by giving to political subdivisions, local development agencies, local development entities, or nonprofit organizations:

subparagraph.text: technical assistance and advisory, consultative, training, and educational services; and
grants and loans to pay for:

sub-subparagraph.text: the services and technical assistance; and
any development costs;

subparagraph.text: contract for and accept from the federal government a grant, contribution, or loan of money, property, or other aid in any form for community development; and

do all things necessary to qualify for the grant, contribution, or loan, including those things necessary to qualify for assistance as a local public agency or public housing agency under a federal housing or renewal program;

paragraph.text: contract for and accept from any governmental unit of the State or other source a gift, grant, contribution, or loan of money, property, or other aid in any form for community development and comply with the terms and conditions of the gift, grant, contribution, or loan;
attach to a sale or lease of property or to a loan or grant the terms and conditions that the Director determines and the Secretary approves;
enter into agreements to make annual payments instead of assessments, charges, or property taxes to a political subdivision in respect to real property that the Administration owns; and
provide money to programs eligible to receive funding from the Neighborhood Business Development Fund under § 6-309 of this article.

subsection.text: To implement community development projects and public purpose projects in accordance with Part V of this subtitle, and subject to §§ 4-213(b) and 4-214 of this subtitle, the Administration may:

subparagraph.text: acquire, own, and hold land that is open, mainly open, or undeveloped, or any interest in the land;
install access and interior streets and roads and sewer and water lines in or to the land and otherwise improve the land; or
transfer, lease, mortgage, or otherwise dispose of or encumber the land;
acquire, own, and hold land that is not open, mainly open, or undeveloped, as well as personal or mixed property;
manage and operate the property;
clear, improve, construct, or rehabilitate the property;
transfer, lease, mortgage, or otherwise dispose of or encumber the property; or
take assignments of rentals or leases for the property;

paragraph.text: arrange or contract with a political subdivision or private party in connection with a community development project or public purpose project for:

subparagraph.text: planning, replanning, zoning, or rezoning;
opening, grading, or closing streets, roads, alleys, or other places;
furnishing facilities;
acquiring property or property rights by the political subdivision; or
furnishing property or services; and

paragraph.text: spend Administration money for an undertaking that the Secretary approves.

subsection.text: The Administration shall develop and implement a weatherization program to provide money for insulation materials and insulation costs to households that qualify based on income and the program eligibility guidelines that the Secretary establishes.
In establishing the upper income limits for a family of limited income, the Secretary shall consider factors including:

paragraph.text: the income of the family available for housing;
the size of the family;
the cost and condition of available housing;
the ability of the family to compete in the private housing market; and
standards and definitions established for federal housing programs.

subsection.text: The limits established under subsection (a) of this section may vary for different:

paragraph.text: types of housing;
programs of the Administration; and
areas of the State.

subsection.text: A limit established under subsection (a) of this section may be supplemented for a particular project.

In accordance with regulations that the Secretary adopts, an agreement that the Administration makes to carry out its functions and responsibilities under §§ 4-211, 4-214, and 4-225 through 4-235 of this subtitle shall be approved by:

paragraph.text: the Secretary; and
the Board of Public Works, if its approval is required by law.

subsection.text: The Administration shall get approval of the land use for a community development project by resolution of the appropriate governing body of the locality in which the development is located before:

subparagraph.text: acquiring, owning, or holding land that is not open, mainly open, or undeveloped, personal property, or mixed property;
clearing, improving, constructing, or rehabilitating the property; or
transferring, leasing, mortgaging, or otherwise disposing of the property; or

paragraph.text: building housing on any land.

subsection.text: A project that the Administration finances is subject to applicable zoning and building codes.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle or other State law.

In exercising its functions and responsibilities, the Administration may sell or lease for a term not exceeding 99 years all or part of the real, mixed, or personal property constituting a community development project.
A sale or lease under this section may be made:

subparagraph.text: without public bidding or public sale; and
on terms and conditions that make housing in that development economically feasible for families of limited income.

paragraph.text: A sale or lease under this section shall conform with a plan for community development that the Secretary approves at a public hearing held after notice is published in at least one newspaper of general circulation in the political subdivision in which the development is located.
The plan for community development presented at the hearing shall be in accordance with regulations that the Secretary adopts, requiring:

subparagraph.text: a description of the property;
a statement of the identity of the proposed purchaser or lessee and the proposed use or reuse of the property;
the price or rental to be paid by the purchaser or lessee; and
the conditions of the sale or lease that ensure that the community development purposes of this subtitle will be carried out.

subsection.text: In carrying out this subtitle, the Administration shall comply with local laws applicable to the community development project.

paragraph.text: In carrying out this subtitle, the Administration shall:

subparagraph.text: work closely, consult, and cooperate with local elected officials;
give primary consideration to local needs and desires;
foster local initiative and participation in community development activities; and
consider local and regional goals and policies as expressed in urban renewal, community renewal, and local comprehensive land use plans and regional plans.

paragraph.text: Wherever possible, the Administration shall carry out community development projects together with and through the use of:

subparagraph.text: private enterprise;
limited dividend corporations;
local development agencies; and
local development entities.

section.text: The Administration has the power of eminent domain, but may not exercise it in a political subdivision without the consent of the political subdivision given by ordinance of its governing body for a specific community development project.

subsection.text: The Administration shall administer a home buyer assistance program that:

paragraph.text: assists home buyers to receive low-interest mortgage loans, with down payment and closing cost assistance options, for the purchase of homes near their place of employment; and

coordinates with, and matches where appropriate, similar programs offered by private employers and county and municipal governments so as to maximize the total amount that home buyers can receive under the program.

subsection.text: With reference to loans under this program, the Administration shall:

paragraph.text: allow home buyers to utilize the loans for the purchase of newly constructed or existing homes; and
require a home purchased under this program to be occupied by the home buyer as a principal residence.

subsection.text: The Administration shall facilitate the marketing of the program with private employers and county and municipal governments, and, where appropriate, other units of State government and nonprofit organizations.
The Administration shall adopt regulations to implement the program established under this section.

A project, undertaking, or a part of a project or undertaking, including the real, personal, and mixed property involved, qualifies as a community development project if it is planned, acquired, owned, developed, constructed, reconstructed, rehabilitated, repaired, renovated, or improved to promote sound community development.
A community development project shall provide for:

paragraph.text: new or existing housing:

subparagraph.text: that is or will be occupied in substantial part by families of limited income; or

at least 20% of which is or will be occupied by families of limited income, if the project is financed with bonds, notes, or other evidences of indebtedness issued by the Administration, the income from which being includable in the holder’s gross income under the Internal Revenue Code as determined by the Administration at the time of issue;

paragraph.text: any improvements, such as streets, roads, sewer lines, and water lines that are needed to support the housing; and
the public or private commercial, educational, cultural, recreational, community, or civic facilities that are needed to support the housing.

subsection.text: A community development project may include public or private commercial, educational, cultural, recreational, community, or civic facilities that are not needed to support the housing, if:

paragraph.text: they are less than a substantial part of the project; or
the Secretary finds that they will promote sound community development.
The Administration shall administer community development projects that:

subparagraph.text: are in sustainable communities approved under § 6–305 of this article; and
provide employees with financial assistance in the form of grants to buy homes near their workplaces.

paragraph.text: A community development project administered under this subsection is not subject to the provisions of subsection (b)(1) of this section that require part of the housing to be occupied by families of limited income.
The community development projects administered under this subsection shall be known as the “Live Near Your Work” program.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to implement the “Live Near Your Work” program established under this subsection.

subparagraph.text: In fiscal year 2007 and fiscal year 2008, the Governor may include in the State budget $250,000 for the “Live Near Your Work” program established under this subsection.

In fiscal year 2009 and every fiscal year thereafter, the Governor may include in the State budget no less than $250,000 and no more than $500,000 for the “Live Near Your Work” program established under this subsection.

subsection.text: A project for a residential building qualifies as an energy conservation project if it consists of:

paragraph.text: the purchase or installation of:

subparagraph.text: caulking or weather stripping;
a clock thermostat;
ceiling, attic, wall, floor, or duct insulation;
water heater insulation;
a storm window or door, multiglazed window or door, or heat-absorbing or heat-reflecting window or floor material;
a device associated with load management techniques;
an automatic energy control system;
machinery, equipment, or a facility that uses groundwater as a heat source for a heating system or as a heat sink for an air conditioning system;
a furnace efficiency modification, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: a replacement burner, furnace, or boiler or any combination of them that increases the energy efficiency of the heating system;
a device for modifying a flue opening that increases the energy efficiency of the heating system; and
an electrical or mechanical furnace ignition system that replaces a standing gas pilot light; and

subparagraph.text: any other energy conservation improvement that the Administration determines by regulation to be appropriate and consistent with this subtitle; or

paragraph.text: a planning or technical service, a residential energy audit, or a conversion from a master utility meter to individual utility meters if the service, audit, or conversion is related to or undertaken with the installation of an item specified in item (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A project for a commercial building qualifies as an energy conservation project if it consists of:

paragraph.text: the purchase, installation, or modification of an installation that is designed primarily to reduce the consumption of energy, including:

subparagraph.text: caulking or weather stripping;
insulating the building structure or a system in the building;
a storm window or door, a multiglazed window or door, a heat-absorbing or heat-reflecting window or door system, glazing, a reduction in glass area, or another window or door system modification;
an automatic energy control system;
equipment that is associated with an automatic energy control system and that is required to operate a variable steam, hydraulic, or ventilation system;

the replacement or modification of a lighting system to increase energy efficiency without increasing the overall illumination, unless the increase in illumination is necessary to conform to State or local law;
an energy recovery system;
a cogeneration system;
machinery, equipment, or a facility that uses groundwater as a heat source for a heating system or as a heat sink for an air conditioning system;
a modification of a furnace or utility plant and distribution system including:

sub-subparagraph.text: a replacement burner, furnace, or boiler or any combination of them that increases the energy efficiency of the heating system;
a device for modifying a flue opening that increases the energy efficiency of the heating system; and
an electrical or mechanical furnace ignition system that replaces a standing gas pilot light; or

subparagraph.text: any other energy conservation improvement that the Administration determines by regulation to be appropriate and consistent with this subtitle; or

paragraph.text: a planning or technical service or a commercial energy audit, if the service or audit is related to or undertaken with the installation, or the modification of an installation of an item specified in item (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A project or undertaking qualifies as a home improvement project if, by improvement, alteration, addition, or repair, it substantially protects or improves the basic liveability of a residential building that will be occupied in substantial part by families of limited income.
A home improvement project for a residential building that contains more than four dwelling units is subject to the provisions of this subtitle that apply to a community development project.

This section does not apply to a facility if a local obligation that finances the facility is a private activity bond under § 141 of the Internal Revenue Code, for which an allocation under § 146 of the Internal Revenue Code is required.

paragraph.text: A project, undertaking, or facility qualifies as an infrastructure project if it is planned, acquired, owned, developed, constructed, reconstructed, rehabilitated, or improved by or on behalf of a political subdivision to provide the essential physical elements that are the basis of the public service system.

Infrastructure projects include streets, sidewalks, curbs, sewer and water systems, bridges, and public buildings that are owned by a political subdivision or a governmental unit of a political subdivision.

subsection.text: A project or undertaking, including the real, personal, and mixed property involved, qualifies as a public purpose project if it is planned, acquired, owned, developed, constructed, reconstructed, rehabilitated, repaired, renovated, or improved with the financial assistance of the Administration or the assistance of federal low-income housing credits authorized by the Internal Revenue Code, and it is:

paragraph.text: eligible wholly or partly for federal low-income housing credits; or
located in a distressed area designated under subsection (e) of this section.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a public purpose project:

paragraph.text: shall provide in substantial part for existing or new housing; and
may include:

subparagraph.text: any improvements, such as streets, roads, sewer lines, and water lines; and
public or private commercial, educational, cultural, recreational, community, or civic facilities.

subsection.text: A public purpose project may include a greater proportion of public or private facilities if the Secretary determines that to do so would promote sound community development.
All or part of the housing portion of a public purpose project shall be occupied by families of limited income.
At the request of a political subdivision, the Secretary may designate a distressed area of the political subdivision after considering factors including:

paragraph.text: the availability, cost, and condition of housing and neighborhood facilities, including the age and number of abandoned and substandard structures;
the incomes of residents relative to State or area-wide regional median incomes, including the number of individuals who are welfare recipients, unemployed, or living in poverty;
the need to finance housing or public or private facilities to upgrade the social and economic conditions of the distressed area;
the plans and financial commitment of the political subdivision to undertake improvements in the distressed area; and
other standards and criteria that the Secretary considers relevant, including standards established for other State or federal programs.

subsection.text: A project qualifies as a solar energy project if it:

paragraph.text: is an addition, alteration, or improvement to a residential building or a commercial building; and
is designed to reduce the energy requirements of the building by using:

subparagraph.text: wind energy;
energy from a wood-burning appliance; or
solar energy of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the active type based on mechanically forced energy transfer;
the passive type based on convective, conductive, or radiant energy transfer; or
a combination of these types.

subsection.text: A solar energy project may include:

paragraph.text: a solar process heat device;
a solar electric device; and
an earth sheltered building in which the sheltering substantially reduces the consumption of energy by the building.

subsection.text: A solar energy project may not include a fireplace, unless the fireplace is an integral part of a system designed to use passive solar energy.
The Administration shall administer a program of financial assistance for:

paragraph.text: community development projects;
energy conservation projects;
home improvement projects;
public purpose projects;
solar energy projects; and
special housing facilities.

subsection.text: The Administration shall provide financial assistance for projects and facilities under this section with money that the Administration can get for them from any source, including:

paragraph.text: payments under federal law;
bonds or notes issued by the Administration;
bonds or notes issued by the State; and
mortgage-backed securities and proceeds of investments in them.

subsection.text: A loan for a home improvement project having a principal balance exceeding $5,000 shall be secured by a mortgage.
Subject to an agreement with noteholders or bondholders, the Administration may consent that a loan, loan commitment, or agreement to which the Administration is a party be modified as to:

paragraph.text: the interest rate;
the time of payments of an installment of principal or interest;
security; or
any other term.
In connection with property on which it holds a mortgage, the Administration may:

subparagraph.text: foreclose on the property;
begin an action to protect or enforce a right conferred on the Administration by law, or any agreement;
bid for and purchase the property at a foreclosure or other sale; and
acquire and take possession of the property.

paragraph.text: In an action under this subsection, the Administration may:

subparagraph.text: complete, administer, and pay the principal of and interest on an obligation incurred in connection with the property; and
dispose of and otherwise deal with the property, so as to protect the interests of the Administration.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to a lien held in connection with a public purpose project.
The Administration may not lend money on the security of property unless the lien on the property is superior to all other liens, except for:

subparagraph.text: a lien for taxes owed to the State or a political subdivision; or
an earlier mortgage lien.

paragraph.text: At public or private sale and with or without public bidding, the Administration may sell a mortgage or other obligation that the Administration holds.
The Administration may retain the servicing rights and charge servicing fees for any mortgage or other obligation the Administration sells.

subsection.text: The Administration shall coordinate the promotion of its programs of financial assistance for energy conservation projects with the energy conservation promotion programs of the Maryland Energy Office.

paragraph.text: The Administration shall adopt regulations to establish and implement programs of financial assistance for energy conservation projects and solar energy projects.

These regulations shall be consistent with the provisions of this subtitle that generally concern the powers of the Administration to award financial assistance for energy conservation projects and solar energy projects.

subsection.text: The regulations shall include provisions about:

paragraph.text: eligibility and application requirements;
interest rates, maximum loan amounts, and the terms of loans;
allocations of money among classes of eligible buildings;
credit and underwriting requirements; and

warranties, representations, forms of security, certifications, inspections, audits, and any other means of ensuring compliance with and enforcing the terms of financial assistance awarded under this subtitle.

subsection.text: To finance infrastructure projects, the Administration may:

paragraph.text: make, purchase, and participate in making loans;
purchase local obligations issued to finance such projects; and
provide any other form of financial assistance other than grants.

subsection.text: All transactions under subsection (a) of this section shall be evidenced by instruments containing the terms and conditions necessary to secure payment of all obligations and charges due to the Administration.

Subject to an agreement with holders of its bonds, notes, or other obligations, the Administration may consent that a loan, local obligation, commitment, instrument, or agreement that the Administration holds or to which it is a party may be modified as to:

paragraph.text: interest rate;
time of payment of any installment of principal or interest;
security; or
any other term.
In connection with any security that it receives or owns, including a local obligation, the Administration may:

subparagraph.text: sue to protect or enforce its rights under any law or agreement; or
acquire or take possession of the security.

paragraph.text: If the Administration begins such an action, it may:

subparagraph.text: administer the security;
pay the principal and interest on any obligation incurred in connection with the security;
dispose of the security; and
otherwise deal with the security so as to protect the Administration’s interests.

subsection.text: The Administration may sell a loan, agreement, local obligation, or other obligation that it holds at public or private sale with or without public bidding.

paragraph.text: If the Administration purchases a local obligation, the procedures and requirements for the issuance or sale of the local obligation shall be as provided in §§ 4-230 through 4-233 of this subtitle.

Notwithstanding any other public general law or public local law, charter, or ordinance, an issuer of a local obligation may sell a local obligation to the Administration to finance an infrastructure project:

subparagraph.text: at private or public sale, with or without public bidding;
without limitation on the denomination of the local obligation; and
at any interest rate, cost, or price that the issuer considers necessary or desirable.

paragraph.text: The issuer of a local obligation may pay any fee or charge necessary for the Administration to:

subparagraph.text: sell bonds, notes, or other obligations of the Administration;
provide the financial assistance authorized by § 4-228 of this subtitle;
provide any other guarantee, credit enhancement, or additional security for a note, bond, or obligation of the Administration; or
insure obligations of the issuer or of the Administration.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any other public general law, public local law, charter, or ordinance, to enhance the security or the marketability of the bonds, notes, or obligations of the Administration that are sold to finance an infrastructure project, a political subdivision may agree with the Administration to pledge any money, including a share of income tax, that the political subdivision is entitled to receive from the State.

In accordance with a pledge under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Comptroller and the State Treasurer shall cause the money pledged to be paid to the Administration or a trustee that the Administration designates.

Notwithstanding any other public general law, or public local law, charter, or ordinance, a political subdivision or a governmental unit of a political subdivision may issue a local obligation to be purchased by the Administration for infrastructure projects.
A local obligation shall be issued in accordance with this section.
Each local obligation must be authorized by resolution or ordinance of the governing body of the issuer.
Before a local obligation is issued under this section:

subparagraph.text: the issuer shall publish a notice of the proposed issuance in a newspaper of general circulation in the jurisdiction of the issuer; and
the governing body of the issuer shall hold a public hearing on the proposed issuance.

paragraph.text: The notice shall include the proposed amount of the issue, the nature of the infrastructure project to be financed, the time and place of the public hearing, and the name and address of the governing body where written comments may be sent.

subsection.text: A resolution or ordinance that authorizes a local obligation shall contain:

paragraph.text: a statement of the public purpose for which the proceeds of the local obligation are to be spent;
the form of the local obligation, including:

subparagraph.text: each place and time of payment;
each interest rate or maximum interest rate;
the titles of the officials whose signatures shall be on it;
a reference to this part as the authority for issuing it; and
the taxes or special revenues from which the principal and interest will be payable;

paragraph.text: a provision for the disposition of the proceeds of sale of the local obligation;
a provision that the principal and interest shall be payable to the Administration or its designee;
a provision for payment of the principal and interest that specifies each source of payment;
a provision that the local obligation is a valid and binding obligation of the issuer in accordance with its terms even if an official whose signature appears on the local obligation:

subparagraph.text: ceases to be an official before the local obligation is delivered; or
becomes an official after the date of the issue; and

paragraph.text: any other provision that is not inconsistent with this subsection and that the governing body of the issuer considers appropriate, including a provision that:

subparagraph.text: the chief elected official of the issuer may modify the forms adopted by the resolution or ordinance without altering the substance of the forms;
the official signatures and seals to be affixed to a local obligation may be imprinted in facsimile, except for the signature of the clerk or secretary of the issuer, which shall be affixed manually;

subject to terms that the Administration specifies, if the local obligation contains a statement of redemption provisions that is acceptable to the Administration all or a portion of a local obligation is redeemable at the option of the issuer at any time before maturity at the price, at or above the par value of the local obligation, that is acceptable to the Administration and set in the enabling resolution or ordinance; and
a local obligation may be in any denomination that is acceptable to the Administration and shall be in fully registered form.

subsection.text: A provision under subsection (a)(5) of this section is a covenant binding the issuer to provide the money from the specified source or sources when principal and interest become due and payable.

paragraph.text: A local obligation that an issuer issues under this part shall have all the attributes of a negotiable instrument under Article 31, § 8 of the Code.
The principal of and interest on a local obligation in the hands of its owner are exempt from taxation by the State or a political subdivision.
Each ordinance or resolution enacted under this section:

subparagraph.text: shall be adopted by the governing body of the issuer;
shall be approved by the chief executive officer, if any, of the issuer; and
shall have the force of law.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, an ordinance, a resolution, or the question of the issuance of local obligations authorized by an ordinance or resolution need not be submitted to a referendum of the qualified voters of the issuer.

subsection.text: The qualified voters of a political subdivision may petition to referendum an ordinance or resolution that authorizes the issuance of local obligations, if:

paragraph.text: the charter of the political subdivision authorizes the voters to do so; and
the petition is filed not later than 20 days after the ordinance or resolution is adopted by the governing body of the political subdivision.

subsection.text: An ordinance or resolution authorizing the issuance of local obligations:

paragraph.text: may be adopted at the public hearing required under § 4-230(b) of this subtitle or at another regular or special session of the governing body; and
shall be effective on the date adopted and approved.

subsection.text: Each issuance of a local obligation under § 4-230 of this subtitle shall be secured by, at the discretion of the Administration, a pledge of the faith and credit of the issuer or a pledge of specific revenue of the issuer or the facility being financed as designated and described in the authorizing ordinance or resolution.
If a local obligation is secured by a pledge of the faith and credit of the issuer to make prompt payment from the tax and other revenues described in the enabling resolution or ordinance:

paragraph.text: the pledge is a covenant to levy taxes sufficient to pay the principal of and interest on the local obligation when due:

subparagraph.text: on all real and tangible personal property that is within the issuer’s corporate limits and subject to assessment for unlimited ad valorem taxation; and
in each year in which the local obligation is outstanding;

paragraph.text: if at the time of issuance of a local obligation there is a charter or statutory limit on the power of the issuer to levy property taxes, the pledge is a covenant to levy ad valorem taxes, within that limit, sufficient to pay the principal of and interest on the local obligation:

subparagraph.text: on all real and tangible personal property that is within the issuer’s corporate limits and subject to assessment for ad valorem taxation; and
in each year in which the local obligation is outstanding;

paragraph.text: a local obligation may not be issued if the issuance would cause the issuer to exceed any limit set by the charter of the issuer or by statute on the power of the issuer to incur indebtedness; and
notwithstanding item (3) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: a limit on the power to incur indebtedness imposed after the issuance of a local obligation does not affect that obligation; and

outstanding local obligations of an issuer are not affected by the issuance of a new local obligation if the new obligation is consistent with an increase in or the elimination of a limit on the power to incur indebtedness.

paragraph.text: An issuer of a local obligation under § 4-230 of this subtitle may secure payment by the pledge of specific revenues of the issuer.
If a local obligation issued under § 4-230 of this subtitle is secured by the pledge of specific revenue, the specific revenue may include:

subparagraph.text: payments to the issuer from the State or federal government;
special benefit assessments, taxes, fees, or service charges that the issuer has authority to impose, levy, or charge; or
revenue expected to be generated by the facility to be financed.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Capital reserve fund” means a reserve fund created under this section.

“Minimum capital reserve requirement” means the minimum capital reserve amount established by the Administration for a capital reserve fund in connection with the issuance of bonds, notes, or other obligations of the Administration in connection with the financing of one or more infrastructure projects.

subsection.text: The Administration may establish one or more capital reserve funds in connection with the financing of one or more infrastructure projects.
Money in a capital reserve fund shall be used solely to pay the principal of, and premium and interest on, the bonds, notes, or other obligations of the Administration:

paragraph.text: secured by the capital reserve fund; and
issued in connection with financing infrastructure projects.

subsection.text: A capital reserve fund may consist of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget for the purposes of the capital reserve fund;
proceeds of a sale of bonds, notes, or other obligations of the Administration or the State;
investment earnings of the capital reserve fund; and
any other money from any other source accepted for the benefit of a capital reserve fund.
If the balance of a capital reserve fund is less than the minimum capital reserve requirement established by the Administration for that fund, the Administration:

subparagraph.text: may not use money from the fund for the optional purchase or redemption of a bond, note, or other obligation of the Administration; and
shall replenish the fund from available operating revenue generated by infrastructure projects or funds provided by the State.

paragraph.text: If available operating revenue generated by infrastructure projects and funds provided by the State are insufficient to replenish a capital reserve fund as required under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Administration shall request that the Comptroller advance the contingent funding to replenish the capital reserve fund as provided in the Local Government Infrastructure Financing Program Capital Reserve Fund Loan of 2009 (Chapter 719 (S.B. 932/H.B. 1330) of the Acts of the General Assembly of 2009) or any other bond bill enabling act for this purpose.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Administration may not issue bonds, notes, or other obligations secured in whole or in part by a capital reserve fund if on issuance the amount in the capital reserve fund will be less than the minimum capital reserve requirement.

The limitation under paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply if at the time of issuance an amount is deposited in the capital reserve fund so that on issuance the total amount in the capital reserve fund will be at least equal to the minimum capital reserve requirement.

subsection.text: In this section, “government–sponsored enterprise” means the Federal National Mortgage Association, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the Federal Home Loan Bank, or other agency or instrumentality of or chartered by the federal government that has similar powers.

To finance community development projects, public purpose projects, or residential mortgage loans, the Administration may purchase or issue securities that are backed by mortgage loans and guaranteed by the Government National Mortgage Association or a government–sponsored enterprise.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding inconsistent provisions of this subtitle relating to bonds or notes that the Administration purchases or issues, the issuance, terms, and conditions of a security that the Administration issues under this section may be as the Administration finds necessary or desirable for guaranty by the Government National Mortgage Association or a government–sponsored enterprise.

Except as provided by paragraph (1) of this subsection, the provisions of this subtitle that relate to bonds or notes issued by the Administration apply to securities purchased or issued under this section.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Mortgage loan” includes a loan to:

subparagraph.text: finance or refinance the purchase of stock or membership in a cooperative ownership housing corporation; or
rehabilitate units in a cooperative ownership housing corporation.

paragraph.text: “Reverse equity mortgage loan” includes a loan that uses the equity in a home as collateral.

subsection.text: The Administration may make, participate in making, and undertake a commitment for a residential mortgage loan to a family of limited income:

paragraph.text: for a family that has a disabled family member who will reside in the dwelling;
for an emergency housing need as determined by the Secretary;
for settlement and down payment costs; or
that is made in conjunction with a loan funded with State appropriated funds if the State appropriated funded loan comprises at least 20% of the total amount loaned.
In accordance with § 4–213 of this subtitle, the Administration may make, participate in making, purchase, and undertake a commitment for:

subparagraph.text: a mortgage loan or other financial assistance secured by a mortgage lien for a community development project or public purpose project; and
a reverse equity mortgage loan secured by a mortgage lien that is for housing related expenses of an elderly household that qualifies as a family of limited income.

paragraph.text: Financial assistance to purchase a dwelling unit in a community development project or public purpose project under paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection may include a temporary loan or advance and a permanent direct mortgage loan to a family of limited income, if otherwise required by law.
Housing related expenses under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection include personal expenses that enable the owner to continue to occupy the owner’s home.
A commitment, mortgage, bond, or secured note shall contain terms and conditions necessary to secure repayment of its loan, the interest on it, and other charges in connection with the loan.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a mortgage loan for a community development project or a public purpose project and a reverse equity mortgage loan may bear interest at a rate or rates that the Administration finds will make the project economically feasible.

The Administration may not increase the interest rate originally charged on a permanent direct mortgage loan to a family for the purchase of a dwelling unit in a community development project or a public purpose project.

paragraph.text: Subject to any agreement with noteholders or bondholders, the Administration may consent to the modification of the interest rate, time of payment of any installment of principal or interest, security, or any other term, of a mortgage, mortgage loan, reverse equity mortgage loan, mortgage loan commitment, or reverse equity mortgage loan commitment, contract, or agreement to which the Administration is a party.

subsection.text: In connection with property on which it holds a mortgage loan or reverse equity mortgage loan:

paragraph.text: the Administration may:

subparagraph.text: foreclose on the property or begin an action to protect or enforce a right that is conferred on the Administration by law, a mortgage contract, or other agreement;
bid for and purchase the property at a foreclosure or other sale; or
acquire or take possession of the property; and
