paragraph.text: in a manner to protect the interests of the Administration, the Administration may:

subparagraph.text: complete, administer, and pay the principal of and interest on an obligation incurred in connection with the property;
dispose of the property; and
otherwise deal with the property.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to a lien held in connection with a public purpose project.
The Administration may not lend money on the security of property unless the lien on the property is superior to all other liens, except for:

subparagraph.text: liens for taxes owed to the State or a political subdivision; or
earlier mortgage liens.

subsection.text: The Administration may:

paragraph.text: sell any mortgage or other obligation that it holds, at public or private sale, with or without public bidding; and
retain the servicing rights and charge servicing fees for any mortgage or other obligation the Administration sells.

subsection.text: The Administration may purchase securities backed by mortgages to provide financial assistance to community development projects and public purpose projects and to finance residential mortgage loans with the proceeds of the securities or with investment earnings on the securities.

section.text: In carrying out this section and §§ 4-237 through 4-241 of this subtitle, the Administration may not make a loan to a mortgage lender or purchase a mortgage loan from a mortgage lender unless the mortgage lender is:

paragraph.text: a bank, trust company, savings institution, savings and loan association, national bank association, mortgage banker, or other financial institution that:

subparagraph.text: has an office in the State; and
makes or originates residential mortgage loans;

paragraph.text: an insurance company authorized to do business in the State; or
the Maryland Home Financing Program.

subsection.text: The Administration may:

paragraph.text: purchase or commit to purchase, from a mortgage lender that is eligible under § 4-236 of this subtitle, a note, mortgage, or partial interest in a note or mortgage that evidences:

subparagraph.text: a residential mortgage loan to a family of limited income; or
a mortgage loan to a sponsor of a community development project or a public purpose project;

paragraph.text: make a loan to an eligible mortgage lender in accordance with this subtitle;
finance, with proceeds of its revenue bonds or notes, all or part of a mortgage purchase program or a loan to a mortgage lenders program; and
take any action necessary or convenient to carry out this subsection, including:

subparagraph.text: settling or compromising an obligation or debt to the Administration, subject to any agreement with bondholders;
acquiring an interest in real or personal property by gift, purchase, foreclosure, or otherwise, and selling or otherwise disposing of the property;
obtaining insurance against loss in connection with its property and other assets, including mortgage loans, in the amount and from the insurer that the Administration considers desirable;
contracting for servicing of a mortgage loan or an interest in a mortgage loan that the Administration holds or takes as collateral; and
making a contract or commitment that relates to the exercise of any of the powers listed in this subsection.

subsection.text: The Administration may adopt regulations or program directives, as appropriate, to carry out this section, including:

paragraph.text: procedures to submit requests for the purchase or sale of mortgage loans or for loans to the eligible mortgage lenders;
restrictions as to the number of family units, locations, or other qualifications or characteristics of dwellings to be financed by residential mortgage loans;
restrictions as to:

subparagraph.text: the interest rates on loans made from the proceeds of purchases of mortgage loans or from the proceeds of loans to eligible mortgage lenders; or
returns realized by eligible mortgage lenders;

paragraph.text: restrictions on maturities and other terms of loans made from the proceeds of purchases of mortgage loans or from the proceeds of loans to eligible mortgage lenders;
requirements as to the application by eligible mortgage lenders of the proceeds of the purchases or loans;
schedules of fees and charges necessary to provide for expenses and reserves of the Administration;
standards for allocating money among areas of the State and among eligible mortgage lenders; and

provisions on warranties, representations, certifications, rights of inspection and audit, program sanctions, and other methods of ensuring compliance with the terms of purchase commitments and loans.
New mortgage loans that the Administration purchases shall be loans to families of limited income or to sponsors of community development projects.
A commitment that the Administration makes to purchase new mortgage loans shall specify:

subparagraph.text: the interest rate on loans eligible for purchase, which may not exceed the prevailing interest rate on comparable mortgage loans available in the State, independent of public assistance or purchase; and
the numbers or volumes of loans under the commitment to be made in specific geographic areas.

paragraph.text: For any residential mortgage loans to be used to acquire homes for families of limited income, the commitment shall be limited to loans of a specified amount per dwelling unit, based on the current average sale price of new homes in the area, as determined by the Administration.

subsection.text: A commitment that the Administration makes to purchase existing mortgages shall require that the proceeds of the purchase be:

paragraph.text: reinvested, within specified time limits, in new mortgage loans to:

subparagraph.text: families of limited income; or
sponsors of community development projects; or

paragraph.text: invested in short-term obligations pending the purchase or making of the mortgages.

A loan from the Administration to an eligible mortgage lender shall require the eligible mortgage lender to make mortgage loans in principal amounts that add up to at least the amount of the loan from the Administration to:

subparagraph.text: families of limited income; or
sponsors of community development projects.

paragraph.text: After receiving the loan from the Administration, the eligible mortgage lender shall commit the amount of the mortgage loans required by paragraph (1) of this subsection within the time the Administration sets.
A loan from the Administration to a mortgage lender is a general obligation of the mortgage lender as to repayment of principal and interest.
Repayment of principal and interest shall be secured by a pledge of and lien on collateral security in an amount that the Administration by regulation determines to be necessary to secure the loan.
The collateral security shall consist of:

subparagraph.text: obligations of or guaranteed by the United States, the State, or a political subdivision;
obligations issued by a unit of the federal government that are satisfactory to the Administration;
certificates of deposit, time deposits, or similar banking arrangements secured by obligations of or guaranteed by the United States or the State;
mortgages insured or guaranteed entirely or partly by the Maryland Housing Fund, a unit of the federal government, or a private insurer that the Administration approves; or
other mortgages that the Administration finds to be of reasonably comparable security.

paragraph.text: The Administration shall require that:

subparagraph.text: the collateral be held by a bank or trust company as independent custodian; or
the mortgage lender enter into a security agreement containing provisions that the Administration considers necessary to identify, maintain, and service the collateral.

paragraph.text: The security agreement shall:

subparagraph.text: provide that the mortgage lender:

sub-subparagraph.text: holds the collateral as an agent for the Administration; and
is accountable as the trustee of an express trust for the application and disposition of the collateral; and

subparagraph.text: require that the income from the collateral be applied only in accordance with the agreement.

paragraph.text: A copy of each security agreement shall be filed with the Secretary of State.

Further filing or other action under the Commercial Law Article or any other law of the State is not required to perfect the security interest of the Administration in the collateral or its proceeds or in any addition to or substitution for the collateral or its proceeds.
Once filed, liens and trusts created for the benefit of the Administration under this subsection are binding against each person with a claim against the mortgage lender.

The Administration may establish additional requirements for pledging, assigning, setting aside, or holding the collateral, and making substitutions for or additions to it, and disposing of interest and income from it.

Notwithstanding any other law, a loan to a mortgage lender and the collateral for it are not subject to Article 95, § 22 of the Code or to § 6-202, § 6-205, § 6-206, § 6-209, or § 6-210 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: A mortgage lender shall make a certificate under this section for every residential mortgage loan that the lender makes under a purchase commitment by the Administration with:

paragraph.text: the proceeds of purchase of a mortgage loan by the Administration; or
the proceeds of a loan from the Administration.

subsection.text: The certificate shall state that in the mortgage lender’s opinion, based on information given by the mortgagor and on the lender’s knowledge of the prevailing terms and standards of mortgage lending in the area, the mortgagor could not get a mortgage loan on the property in the unassisted private lending market.

section.text: Except as required to qualify for insurance or guaranty by the federal government, a residential mortgage loan may not be assigned to or assumed by a person not qualified under the appropriate Administration program if the residential mortgage loan is:

paragraph.text: a new loan that the Administration purchases or in which the Administration purchases an interest;
a loan made with the proceeds of purchase by the Administration of a residential mortgage; or
a loan made with the proceeds of a loan from the Administration to a mortgage lender.

subsection.text: The Administration may provide financial assistance, meet any development cost, or carry out any other of its purposes by spending:

paragraph.text: money appropriated by the General Assembly;
the proceeds of a State loan to the extent provided by the General Assembly or a governmental unit authorized to issue bonds;
the proceeds of the bonds, notes, or other evidences of indebtedness that the Administration issues, payable solely from revenues of the Administration as provided in this part; or
any other money available to the Administration for community development under this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: from its own operations;
from investment of the proceeds of its bonds, notes, or other indebtedness; or
from any other public or private source.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in a determination made under this section, the Administration shall deposit with the State Treasurer any money that it does not need to meet current expenses and obligations.
The State Treasurer shall:

subparagraph.text: credit the money to the Administration;
invest the money as provided by statute; and
credit earnings from the money to the Administration.

paragraph.text: The Administration may:

subparagraph.text: borrow money and issue bonds or notes; and
use the proceeds or the earnings from the investment of the proceeds to provide money to:

sub-subparagraph.text: make, purchase, or participate in making mortgage loans or other loans;
purchase securities backed by mortgage loans or other loans;
purchase local obligations;
meet any development cost; or
achieve any other purpose of the Administration.

paragraph.text: Bonds or notes may be issued only if:

subparagraph.text: the Director, or a person that the Secretary designates, determines that the issuance is necessary to achieve one or more purposes of the Administration; and
the Secretary approves the determination.

paragraph.text: Without any other proceeding, action, or approval, the determination is effective when approved by the Secretary and is conclusive.

subsection.text: For bonds or notes of any issue, the Administration has absolute discretion to determine:

paragraph.text: the date, amount, and manner of issue, including private sale;
the date of maturity, which:

subparagraph.text: for a bond, may not be more than 50 years after the bond is issued; and
for a note, including renewals, may not be more than 5 years after the note is originally issued;

paragraph.text: the price to be paid, whether above, at, or below par, the interest rate to be paid, and the dates of payment;
the form, denomination, and manner of execution, which may be by facsimile;
the place of payment, which may be any bank or trust company in or out of the State;
whether they are redeemable before maturity and, if so, the terms, conditions, and prices of the redemption; and
any other matter relating to the form, terms, conditions, security, issuance, sale, delivery, replacement, and indemnification in connection with replacement or payment.

subsection.text: A bond or note issued under this section is a negotiable instrument under State law notwithstanding any other provision of the Code or any recital in the bond or note.

The manual or facsimile signature of an officer or employee of the Administration that appears on a bond, note, or coupon is valid even if the individual leaves office or employment before delivery of the bond, note, or coupon.
The Administration may:

paragraph.text: issue its bonds or notes in coupon or registered form or both; and
provide for:

subparagraph.text: registration of coupon bonds or notes as to principal only or as to both principal and interest;
reconversion into coupon form of bonds or notes registered as to both principal and interest; and
interchange of coupon and registered bonds or notes.

subsection.text: A bond or note issued under this section is exempt from §§ 8-206, 8-208, and 8-213 through 8-221 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Administration may issue a bond or note without:

paragraph.text: the consent of another governmental unit of the State; or
a proceeding, or the occurrence of a condition, other than those that this section expressly requires.

subsection.text: The Secretary and any other person executing a bond or note under this section are not personally liable or accountable because the bond or note is issued.

By written determination, the Administration may provide for the issuance of notes to renew its notes, and bonds to pay its notes or to fund or refund its bonds, whether or not the bonds to be refunded have matured, including the payment of any redemption premium and any interest accrued or to accrue on the notes or bonds to be renewed, paid, or refunded.
The issuance and incidents of renewal notes and refunding bonds are governed by applicable provisions of this part.

paragraph.text: Bonds or notes that the Administration issues may be secured by a trust agreement between the Administration and a trustee that is in or out of the State.
A trustee shall be a trust company or a bank with trust powers.

subsection.text: A trust agreement or a determination authorizing the issuance of bonds or notes may contain:

paragraph.text: subject to then-existing agreements with bondholders or noteholders, provisions to secure payment of bonds or notes by pledging or assigning:

subparagraph.text: any of the revenues of the Administration;
a mortgage that the Administration holds, a loan that the Administration has made, or security for the mortgage or loan;
the proceeds of a bond or note of the Administration; or
any combination of these and other assets of the Administration;

paragraph.text: provisions to protect and enforce rights and remedies of bondholders or noteholders, and covenants stating the duties of or restrictions on the Administration;
provisions restricting the rights of bondholders or noteholders;

provisions that appoint one or more trust companies or banks with trust powers to act as depositaries of the proceeds of bonds or notes or of any revenues or money of the Administration, with any indemnifying bonds or securities required by the Administration allowed to be given or pledged by any depositary bank or trust company incorporated in the State;
provisions on the custody, safeguarding, and application of money of the Administration;

provisions on investments of money of the Administration as the Administration provides, notwithstanding Article 95, § 22 of the Code and §§ 6-202, 6-205, 6-206, 6-209, and 6-210 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
provisions that establish and control all aspects of reserves, including debt service reserves;
provisions for funding or refunding bonds or notes, including redemption premiums and interest; and
any other provisions that are reasonable and proper for the security of bondholders or noteholders.

The interest rate or rates on and the terms of any loans and the revenues from the terms of any other assets that are financed from the proceeds of bonds or notes of the Administration, any fees that the Administration charges, and any other available revenues shall be at least sufficient to ensure repayment in full of the principal of and interest on the bonds or notes as and when due.
Any pledge that the Administration makes is valid and binding from the time the pledge is made.

subsection.text: The lien of the pledge:

paragraph.text: immediately attaches, without any physical delivery or further act, to revenues or property so pledged and later received by the Administration; and
is valid and binding against each person having a claim against the Administration whether or not:

subparagraph.text: the person has notice of the lien of the pledge; or
the determination or any other instrument has been recorded or filed.

subsection.text: Subject to agreements with noteholders or bondholders, the Administration may purchase its notes or bonds with any money available for the purchase.
The purchase price may not exceed:

paragraph.text: the redemption price at the time of the purchase, plus accrued interest to the next interest payment date, if the note or bond is redeemable, at the time of the purchase; or

the redemption price on the first date after the purchase on which the note or bond becomes redeemable, plus accrued interest to that date, if the note or bond is not redeemable at the time of the purchase.

subsection.text: When the Administration purchases its note or bond, the note or bond shall be canceled.
A bond or note issued by the Administration under this part is a legal and proper investment for:

paragraph.text: a public officer, a political subdivision, or a governmental unit;
a bank, trust company, savings and loan association, investment company, or other person doing a banking business;
an insurance company, insurance association, or other person doing an insurance business;
a personal representative, guardian, trustee, or other fiduciary; or
any other person.

subsection.text: For any purpose for which the deposit of a bond or other obligation of the State is authorized by law, a bond issued by the Administration under this part is a security that may legally and properly be deposited with and received by a public officer, a political subdivision, or a governmental unit.
A bond or note issued under this part:

paragraph.text: is not a debt of and does not pledge the faith, credit, or taxing power of the State, the Administration, or a political subdivision; but
is payable only from the revenues and property provided for in this subtitle.

subsection.text: Each bond or note shall state on its face the provisions of subsection (a) of this section.

section.text: The following are exempt at all times from taxation of every kind and nature whatsoever by the State, a political subdivision, or a governmental unit of any kind:

paragraph.text: a bond or note that the Administration issues under this part;
the transfer of, interest payable on, or income derived from the bond or note; and
profit realized by the sale or exchange of the bond or note.

section.text: To improve the management of debt issued under the provisions of this part or to reduce the cost of servicing the debt, the Administration may enter into interest rate exchange agreements or contracts providing for payments based on levels of or changes in interest rates.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in a document required to be submitted to the Administration by an agreement relating to a loan.

A person applying for a loan may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report to influence the action of the Administration on a loan application or to influence an action of the Administration affecting a loan already made.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Eligible homebuyer” means an individual who meets the qualifications under § 4-305 of this subtitle.
“Fund” means the Homeownership Programs Fund.

paragraph.text: “Homebuyer education” means instruction in preparing for homeownership, shopping for a home, getting a mortgage loan, loan closing, and life as a homeowner.
“Homebuyer education” includes housing counseling.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Down Payment and Settlement Expense Loan Program.
“Program loan” means a loan that the Department makes under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: “Settlement expenses” means money that must be paid at the time of the purchase of real estate.
“Settlement expenses” includes:

subparagraph.text: fees and premiums for title examination, title insurance, and similar expenses;
fees for preparing deeds, settlement statements, and other documents;
payments owed at settlement for property taxes and hazard insurance coverage;
escrows for future payments of taxes and hazard insurance;
fees for notarizing deeds and other documents;
appraisal fees;
fees for credit reports;
transfer and recordation taxes and fees;
fees and premiums for mortgage insurance; and
loan discount points and origination fees.

section.text: There is a Down Payment and Settlement Expense Loan Program.
The purpose of the Program is to provide financing for down payment and settlement expenses to enable eligible homebuyers to purchase homes.

subsection.text: The Department may:

paragraph.text: charge an application fee or other fee to a Program loan applicant or lender;
purchase or make commitments to purchase Program loans made by mortgage lenders;
make contracts with third parties to make or service mortgage Program loans made for the Department;
acquire any property that secures a Program loan under this subtitle by gift, purchase, foreclosure, or otherwise, and sell or otherwise dispose of the property or an interest in the property;
delegate to a political subdivision any administrative or operational element of the Program not assigned to the Department under subsection (b) of this section;
take any other action necessary or convenient to operate the Program; and
require a political subdivision that administers its own down payment and settlement expense loan program to inform the Department of the political subdivision’s homebuyer education requirements.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Program;
attach to a Program loan the terms needed to carry out the Program;
establish eligibility standards for Program loans, considering State, regional, and county housing costs, median incomes, and household sizes;
establish guidelines to determine what parts of the down payment and settlement expenses may be covered by the Program loan; and
adopt regulations to carry out the Program.

subsection.text: The sale or purchase of property that the Department acquires or disposes of under this section need not be approved or executed by the Board of Public Works or the Department of General Services.

section.text: An individual qualifies as an eligible homebuyer if the individual:

paragraph.text: will purchase and occupy a single-unit principal residence and has household income not exceeding upper limits that the Secretary establishes; or

will purchase and occupy a residential building with no more than four units and agrees to rent all units other than the owner’s unit to households with income not exceeding upper limits that the Secretary establishes.

section.text: The Program shall be operated with money in the Fund.

subsection.text: Proceeds of a Program loan shall be used only to make a down payment or pay settlement expenses for an eligible homebuyer to purchase a personal residence.
A Program loan shall be secured by a mortgage lien that:

paragraph.text: may be subordinate to other mortgage liens; and
may include terms, including deferred payment of principal and interest, that the Department considers necessary to make housing purchases affordable to eligible homebuyers.

subsection.text: In reviewing an application for a Program loan, the Department shall:

paragraph.text: consider the eligible homebuyer’s financial resources, including savings available to make a down payment or pay settlement expenses, in relation to:

subparagraph.text: the purchase price of the home; and
the down payment requirements of the lender; and

paragraph.text: give high priority to eligible homebuyers of low income within the income limits established under § 4-304(b)(3) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other law, the Department may require that Program loans become due and payable on the later sale or transfer of the property, but the Department may allow an eligible homebuyer who purchases the property to assume the Program loan.

If a borrower defaults, the Department may modify the interest rate, the time or amount of payment, or any other term of a Program loan to facilitate repayment of the Program loan and to achieve the purpose of the Program.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a recipient of a Program loan shall complete homebuyer education that meets the requirements of the Department.

If the political subdivision in which a Program loan recipient will use a Program loan administers a down payment or settlement expense loan program that requires homebuyer education, the homebuyer education to be completed by the Program loan recipient must meet the more stringent of the requirements of the Department and the requirements of the political subdivision.

paragraph.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in a document required to be submitted to the Department under an agreement relating to a Program loan.
A loan applicant may not knowingly make or cause to be made any false statement or report to influence an action of the Department on a Program loan application or a Program loan already made.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Fund” means the Rental Housing Program Fund.
“Program” means the Elderly Rental Housing Program.

section.text: There is an Elderly Rental Housing Program.
The purposes of the Program are to:

paragraph.text: stimulate the production of rental housing, including conversion of existing rental housing, for occupancy by elderly households;
increase the supply of decent, safe, and sanitary rental housing at costs that are affordable to low-income elderly households;
use available resources to serve the elderly households that are most in need; and

relieve unemployment by stimulating the construction or substantial rehabilitation of elderly rental housing projects or the conversion of existing rental housing projects for occupancy by elderly households.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Program;
adopt policies to ensure that rental property is made available to low-income elderly households; and
use federal and State programs to help carry out the Program.

subsection.text: The Department shall set income guidelines by considering:

paragraph.text: the median income for the area;
the minimum income needed to afford available standard rental units in the area; and
any other factor the Department considers relevant.

section.text: To achieve the purposes of the Fund, the Department shall, from time to time, ask the State to increase or replace amounts deposited with the State Treasurer in the Fund.

subsection.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out the Program.
The regulations shall provide for:

paragraph.text: applications for money from the Fund;
standards of eligibility, terms, and fees;
charges that shall be imposed on deferred-payment, subordinated loans; and
the recapture of money of the Fund from a borrower that does not use the money in a timely manner.

subsection.text: A project qualifies as an elderly rental housing project, if:

paragraph.text: its purpose is to acquire, construct, or rehabilitate all or part of a building or improvement that will be occupied by low-income elderly households as provided in this subsection;
some dwelling units in the project are set aside for low-income elderly households for at least the greater of 15 years or the number of years required by federal law; and
the number of dwelling units so set aside is at least the greatest of:

subparagraph.text: the number that bears the same ratio to the whole number of dwelling units in the project as the amount of the program loan bears to the whole financing of the undertaking;
the number of dwelling units chosen by the sponsor to satisfy federal occupancy requirements, if the project receives federal low-income housing tax credits; and

the number of dwelling units required for community development projects under § 4-217(b)(1)(ii) of this title or the number of dwelling units that the issuer of the bonds chooses, whichever is greater, if part of the costs of the project is financed with government-issued federally tax-exempt revenue bonds.

subsection.text: Dwelling units that may be counted toward the minimum number required under subsection (a) of this section include:

paragraph.text: a dwelling unit set aside for occupancy to meet another federal or State occupancy requirement; and
a dwelling unit that is for single room occupancy or is for shared living.

subsection.text: The Department shall review applications for loans submitted by private or nonprofit sponsors, political subdivisions, or local housing authorities established under Division II of this article on behalf of sponsors of proposed elderly rental housing projects.
In reviewing an application for a deferred payment loan under § 4-409 of this subtitle, the Department shall consider:

paragraph.text: the degree of local government incentive and support provided to the proposed residential rental facility supported by money from the Fund, including contribution of land, abatement of taxes or fees, direct or indirect rental subsidies, and grants;
the extent to which low-income elderly households will be assisted by granting the application;
the number and percentage of low-income elderly households in the political subdivision; and
the quantity and condition of residential property in the political subdivision.

subsection.text: Money in the Fund may be used to make a deferred payment loan to an approved applicant to:

paragraph.text: acquire, construct, or rehabilitate an elderly rental housing project; or
convert existing rental housing to an elderly rental housing project.

subsection.text: A deferred payment loan under this section may be subordinate to other financing.

paragraph.text: Each fund established under this subtitle is a continuing, nonlapsing special fund that is not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The State Treasurer shall hold and the Comptroller shall account for each fund established under this subtitle.

subsection.text: Money in a fund established under this subtitle shall be invested in the same way as other State money.

paragraph.text: In the State budget, the State may appropriate to the Rental Housing Programs Fund and the Special Loan Programs Fund all or part of the money received as repayment of principal or payment of interest on a loan made by the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program.
The appropriation may be increased by budget amendment.
The amount of repayments appropriated to make loans under the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program may not exceed $12,000,000 annually.

The State may not appropriate repayment of principal and payment of interest to the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program to the extent that loans expected to be made with the money appropriated would cause the principal amount of loans outstanding to exceed $100,000,000.

subsection.text: The Department shall attempt to use to the greatest extent feasible minority business enterprises to provide brokerage and investment management services to the Department for the funds established under this subtitle consistent with minority business purchasing standards applicable to units of State government under the State Finance and Procurement Article and consistent with the fiduciary duties of the Department.
For purposes of this section, brokerage and investment management services shall include services relating to all allocated asset classes.

paragraph.text: To assist the Department in achieving the goal described under subsection (a) of this section, the Department shall undertake measures to remove any barriers that limit full participation by minority business enterprises in brokerage and investment management services opportunities afforded by the Department for the funds established under this subtitle.

The measures undertaken by the Department shall include the use of a wide variety of media, including the Department’s Web site, to provide notice to a broad and varied range of potential providers about the brokerage and investment management services opportunities afforded by the Department for the funds established under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In conjunction with the Governor’s Office of Minority Affairs, the Department shall develop guidelines to assist it in identifying and evaluating qualified minority business enterprises in order to help the Department achieve the objective for greater use of minority business enterprises for brokerage and investment management services for the funds established under this subtitle.

On or before September 1 each year, the Department shall submit a report to the Governor’s Office of Minority Affairs and, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly on:

paragraph.text: the identity of the minority business enterprise brokerage and investment management services firms used by the Department in the immediately preceding fiscal year;

the percentage and dollar value of the assets in the funds established under this subtitle that are under the investment control of minority business enterprise brokerage and investment management services firms in each allocated asset class; and
the measures the Department undertook in the immediately preceding fiscal year in accordance with subsection (c)(2) of this section.

subsection.text: In this section, “Fund” means the Homeownership Programs Fund.
There is a Homeownership Programs Fund.
As provided in the State budget, the Department shall use the Fund to:

paragraph.text: pay expenses of the Maryland Home Financing Program, including reserves for anticipated future losses directly related to the Maryland Home Financing Program;
make loans under the Maryland Home Financing Program; and
make loans and pay expenses of the Down Payment and Settlement Expense Loan Program.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated by the State for homeownership programs, including the Maryland Home Financing Program under Subtitle 8 of this title and the Down Payment and Settlement Expense Loan Program under Subtitle 3 of this title;
money from the sale of the State’s general obligation bonds;

repayments or prepayments of principal and payments of interest on loans made under the Maryland Home Financing Program, the Homeowners’ Emergency Mortgage Assistance Program, the Reverse Equity Program, or the Down Payment and Settlement Expense Loan Program, formerly the Settlement Expense Loan Program;
money transferred to the Fund in accordance with §§ 4–503(d), 4–504(f), and 4–505(h) of this subtitle and §§ 3–203(i) and 6–310(g) of this article; and
investment earnings of the Fund.

subsection.text: Subject to § 7-209 of the State Finance and Procurement Article and except as otherwise provided in the State budget, after the first 8 months of a fiscal year, the Department may transfer unencumbered money in the Fund to any other fund established under this title.

Money received as repayment of principal or payment of interest on a loan made under the Maryland Home Financing Program that is not appropriated in the State budget may be credited to the Annuity Bond Fund and used to pay the principal of or interest on money borrowed by the State and appropriated to the Maryland Home Financing Program.
In this section, “Fund” means the Partnership Rental Housing Fund.
There is a Partnership Rental Housing Fund.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated by the State to the Partnership Rental Housing Program;

money made available to the Partnership Rental Housing Program from the sale of general obligation or other bonds including the proceeds of the sale of bonds authorized by Chapter 625 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1988 and Chapter 97 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1989;
investment earnings of the Fund; and
repayment of loans from the Fund except to the extent any State or federal law governing the proceeds of bonds prohibits the recycling of money.

subsection.text: Subject to the approval of the Legislative Policy Committee and § 7-209 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, after the first 8 months of a fiscal year, the Department may transfer unencumbered money in the Fund among the Partnership Rental Housing Fund, the Rental Housing Programs Fund, the Homeownership Programs Fund, and the Special Loan Programs Fund, if the Secretary determines that demand is:

paragraph.text: less than anticipated for the fund from which money is being transferred; and
greater than anticipated for the fund to which money is being transferred.

subsection.text: In this section, “Fund” means the Rental Housing Programs Fund.
There is a Rental Housing Programs Fund.

paragraph.text: The Department shall use the Fund to:

subparagraph.text: operate, make loans, and pay expenses of the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program, including reserves for anticipated future losses directly related to the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program, as provided in the State budget; and
operate, make loans, and pay expenses of the Rental Housing Production Program.

paragraph.text: The Administration shall use the Fund to operate, make loans, and pay expenses of the Elderly Rental Housing Program.

subparagraph.text: The Administration may use the Fund to make deferred payment loans to approved applicants to enable the applicants to acquire, construct, or rehabilitate elderly rental housing projects or to convert existing rental housing to elderly rental housing projects.
Deferred payment loans may be subordinate to other financing.

subsection.text: The Administration shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund consists of:

subparagraph.text: money appropriated by the State for rental housing programs, including the Elderly Rental Housing Program under § 4–402 of this title, the Multifamily Rehabilitation Program under § 4–906(b) of this title, the Nonprofit Rehabilitation Program under § 4–929 of this title, and the Rental Housing Production Program under § 4–1502 of this title;
repayments and prepayments of loans made under the programs set forth in item (i) of this paragraph;
money appropriated under § 4–501(c) of this subtitle;
money transferred to the Fund in accordance with §§ 4–502(e), 4–503(d), and 4–505(h) of this subtitle and §§ 3–203(i) and 6–310(g) of this article; and
investment earnings of the Fund.

paragraph.text: The State, under § 4–501(c) of this subtitle, may appropriate to the Fund money received as repayment of principal or payment of interest on a loan made by the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program.
When the Department issues a binding commitment to make a loan, the Department shall withdraw from the Fund an amount equal to the commitment.

Subject to § 7-209 of the State Finance and Procurement Article and except as otherwise provided in the State budget, after the first 8 months of a fiscal year the Department may transfer unencumbered money in the Fund to any other fund established under this title.

subsection.text: In this section, “Fund” means the Special Loan Programs Fund.
There is a Special Loan Programs Fund.
As provided in the State budget and subject to subsection (d) of this section, the Department shall use the Fund to:

paragraph.text: operate, pay expenses of, and make loans under the Group Home Financing Program;
operate, pay expenses of, and make grants and loans under the Lead Hazard Reduction Grant Program and the Lead Hazard Reduction Loan Program;

operate, pay expenses of, and make loans under the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program, including reserves for anticipated future losses directly related to the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program;
make loans under the Regular Rehabilitation Program; and
make loans under the special loan programs.

subsection.text: During the first 6 months of each fiscal year the Department shall reserve at least 25% of the appropriation for the Fund to make loans to rehabilitate buildings with four or fewer dwelling units.

paragraph.text: The Department annually shall allocate money in the Fund to the Lead Hazard Reduction Grant Program and the Lead Hazard Reduction Loan Program.

If the number of eligible applications under the Lead Hazard Reduction Grant Program or the Lead Hazard Reduction Loan Program is insufficient to commit all money allocated to that Program within 6 months after the allocation, the Department may reallocate the uncommitted money to other programs of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund shall be administered in accordance with this section.

paragraph.text: The Fund consists of:

subparagraph.text: money appropriated by the State for special loan programs, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Special Rehabilitation Program under § 4–906(b) of this title;
the Regular Rehabilitation Program under § 4–906(b) of this title;
the Group Home Financing Program under § 4–602 of this title; and
the Lead Hazard Reduction Grant Program under § 4–708 of this title and the Lead Hazard Reduction Loan Program under § 4–709 of this title;

subparagraph.text: repayments of principal and payments of interest on loans made under these programs;
repayments of grants from the Fund;
repayments of principal and payments of interest on loans from the Fund;
money transferred to the Fund in accordance with §§ 4–502(e), 4–503(d), and 4–504(f) of this subtitle and §§ 3–203(i) and 6–310(g) of this article; and
investment earnings of the Fund.

paragraph.text: The State, under § 4–501(c) of this subtitle, may appropriate to the Fund money received as repayment of principal or payment of interest on a loan made by the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program.

subsection.text: Subject to § 7-209 of the State Finance and Procurement Article and except as otherwise provided in the State budget, after the first 8 months of a fiscal year, the Department may transfer unencumbered money in the Fund to any other fund established under this title.
In this section, “Fund” means the Workforce Housing Fund.
There is a Workforce Housing Fund.
As provided in the State budget, the Department shall use the Fund to operate and provide funds under the Workforce Housing Grant Program.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated by the State;
repayments of principal and payments of interest on loans made under the Workforce Housing Grant Program;
amounts paid in connection with transfers of homeownership workforce housing units;
money transferred to the Fund in accordance with this subtitle; and
investment earnings of the Fund.

subsection.text: In this section, “Fund” means the Housing Counseling and Foreclosure Mediation Fund.
There is a Housing Counseling and Foreclosure Mediation Fund.
The purposes of the Fund are to:

paragraph.text: support nonprofit and government housing counselors and other nonprofit entities with providing:

subparagraph.text: legal assistance to homeowners or occupants who are trying to avoid foreclosure or manage foreclosure proceedings; and
homebuyer education, housing advice, or financial counseling for homeowners and prospective homeowners;

paragraph.text: support the establishment and operation of nonprofit housing counseling entities;
support efforts by the Department and the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation to:

subparagraph.text: contact and provide advice and assistance to homeowners or occupants facing financial difficulty or foreclosure; and
provide advice and assistance to prospective homeowners; and

paragraph.text: assist in funding the costs of foreclosure mediations provided by the Office of Administrative Hearings under § 7–105.1 of the Real Property Article.

subsection.text: The Department shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The State Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: revenue distributed to the Fund under § 7–105.1 of the Real Property Article;
investment earnings of the Fund;
money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund; and
any other money from any other source accepted for the benefit of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund may be used only for the purposes described in subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: The State Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.

subsection.text: Expenditures from the Fund may be made only in accordance with the State budget.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Group home” means a housing facility that offers:

subparagraph.text: supportive services or supervisory personnel to individuals with special housing needs who are not related to the group home sponsor; and
common, shared, or independent living, dining, kitchen, sanitary, and sleeping facilities.

paragraph.text: “Group home” need not include all of the facilities listed in paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection if it provides emergency and temporary housing for homeless individuals.

subsection.text: “Group home sponsor” means a person who qualifies for a Program loan under § 4-607 of this subtitle.
“Person of lower income” means an individual or family whose income does not exceed the upper income limit that the Secretary sets.
“Program” means the Group Home Financing Program.
“Program loan” means a loan that the Department makes under this subtitle.

section.text: There is a Group Home Financing Program.

The purpose of the Program is to provide loans to group home sponsors to finance or refinance the costs of acquiring, constructing, or modifying buildings as group homes for persons of lower income, elderly households, individuals with disabilities, and other residents of the State with special housing needs.
The Department may establish:

paragraph.text: eligibility standards for group home sponsors;
Program loan fees and charges;
maximum Program loans for group homes based on their size, use, and location; and
a process for selecting group homes to be financed under the Program that promotes statewide distribution of money.

section.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Program;
adopt policies that encourage the establishment of group homes for persons of lower income throughout the State;
attach to a purchase, sale, or lease of a group home or land for a group home the terms needed to carry out the Program;

establish guidelines for monitoring the group homes to ensure that, aside from dwelling room for supervisory individuals and their families, group homes receiving financing under the Program are occupied in substantial part by persons of lower income; and
establish guidelines to determine the ability of a group home sponsor to manage a group home, provide necessary services, and repay the Program loan.

section.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out the Program.
To qualify for a Program loan, a group home sponsor shall own and operate a group home and be:

paragraph.text: a nonprofit organization;
an individual; or
a limited partnership if:

sub-subparagraph.text: each general partner qualifies as a nonprofit organization; or
each general partner is a wholly owned subsidiary of a nonprofit organization;

subparagraph.text: the limited partnership is formed to undertake a group home project that is totally or partly eligible for a federal low income housing tax credit program or any other federal program or incentive; and
a nonprofit organization manages the project or receives the net cash flow from or the residual sale proceeds on sale of the group home.

section.text: The Program shall be operated with money in the Special Loan Programs Fund under § 4-505 of this title.
In reviewing an application for a Program loan, the Department shall consider:

paragraph.text: the economic feasibility of the group home; and
the ability of the group home sponsor to manage the group home, provide necessary services, and repay the Program loan.
A Program loan shall be secured by a mortgage lien and may include the terms that the Department considers necessary to make the group home affordable to persons of lower income.
In exceptional circumstances, the terms may include:

subparagraph.text: deferred payment of principal and interest; and
interest rates as low as 0%.

subsection.text: Each loan shall require that all unpaid principal and accrued interest, including principal or interest that was deferred, be paid at the earliest of:

paragraph.text: a stated date, which may be the maturity date of the Program loan;
the date of the sale or other transfer of the group home or a controlling interest in the group home; and
the date when the project ceases to be used as a group home.
Each Program loan shall provide for:

subparagraph.text: a limit on the return on equity allowed to a group home sponsor;
equity participation between the Department and the group home sponsor; or
an amount of accrued and deferred interest that the Department finds can reasonably be expected to be paid from profit resulting from the sale of the group home.

paragraph.text: The Department may forgive any accrued and deferred interest described in paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection that exceeds the profit from the sale of the group home.
The Department may allow the group home sponsor to earn a reasonable return before the group home sponsor pays accrued and deferred interest.

subsection.text: If a Program loan is in default or is at risk of being in default, the Department may modify the interest rate, the time or amount of payment, or any other term to facilitate repayment and achieve the purposes of the Program.
A Program loan may finance:

paragraph.text: the site acquisition, construction costs, and permanent mortgage for a group home;
the purchase of an existing building to provide a group home;
a modification to a building purchased with a Program loan, if the modification improves, repairs, renovates, or rehabilitates the building to:

subparagraph.text: make it suitable as a group home; or
eliminate housing, building, fire, safety, health, or other code violations;

paragraph.text: the refinancing of an existing mortgage loan on a group home;
closing costs associated with the construction, purchase, or refinance of a group home;
engineering, legal, title, survey, or architectural fees associated with financing real property development; and
other development costs that the Department considers reasonable.

section.text: Subject to the approval and permitting procedures of the local zoning authority, a group home that houses four or more individuals may provide for nonresidential uses that:

paragraph.text: are in a minor part of the building;
conform with local zoning requirements; and
although not directly related to the housing facility, offer goods or services for persons of lower income or other disadvantaged individuals.
A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in a document required to be submitted to the Department under an agreement relating to a Program loan.
A loan applicant may not knowingly make or cause to be made any false statement or report to influence the Department’s action on a Program loan application or a Program loan already made.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Child care center” has the meaning stated in § 5-570(c) of the Family Law Article.
“Family of limited income” means a family that meets the qualifications under § 4-707 of this subtitle.
“Fund” means the Special Loan Programs Fund under Subtitle 5 of this title.
“Grant Program” means the Lead Hazard Reduction Grant Program.

paragraph.text: “Lead hazard reduction activity” means measures to reduce or eliminate lead-based paint hazards in accordance with State or federal standards.
“Lead hazard reduction activity” includes:

subparagraph.text: removing lead-based paint and lead-contaminated dust, containing or encapsulating lead-based paint, and replacing or removing surfaces or fixtures painted with lead-based paint;
meeting the risk reduction standards under § 6-815 of the Environment Article or the modified risk reduction standards under § 6-817 of the Environment Article;

temporarily reducing human exposure or probable exposure to lead-based paint hazards, including specialized cleaning, repairing, maintaining, painting, temporarily containing, and ongoing monitoring of lead-based paint hazards or potential hazards;
associated testing, preparing, cleaning, protecting workers, disposing, and post-lead hazard reduction clearance testing; and
testing an innovative or unproven method of lead hazard reduction.

subsection.text: “Loan Program” means the Lead Hazard Reduction Loan Program.

section.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: lead paint is present in a large percentage of residential properties in the State, particularly residential rental properties constructed before 1950;
lead paint on the friction surfaces of windows is a leading cause of lead poisoning;
lead poisoning harms the health and well-being of children and pregnant women and causes substantial long-term public costs for medical expenses and additional education; and
reduction or elimination of lead in the environment will reduce:

subparagraph.text: the risk of lead poisoning of children and pregnant women;
the incidence of learning disabilities and behavioral problems in children who live in older housing; and
the cost of publicly financed medical care.

section.text: The purpose of the Grant Program and the Loan Program is to make grants and loans to owners of residential property or child care centers for financing lead hazard reduction activities, especially replacing windows containing lead-based paint on friction surfaces.

subsection.text: The Department may establish:

paragraph.text: loan fees and charges;
maximum loan or grant amounts for lead hazard reduction activities; and
guidelines that give financing priority to lead hazard reduction activities that include replacing windows containing lead-based paint on friction surfaces.

On application of a political subdivision, the Department may provide money from the Fund allocated to the Grant Program or the Loan Program to the political subdivision to make a grant or loan, on behalf of the Department, to an eligible owner of residential property or a child care center in the political subdivision.
The Department may limit the amount of money that a political subdivision may request under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

section.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Grant Program and the Loan Program; and
establish eligibility guidelines for grants and loans.

section.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out the Grant Program and the Loan Program.

subsection.text: An individual or family, including an elderly household, qualifies as a family of limited income if the income of the individual or family does not exceed the limits that the Secretary sets.
The factors that the Secretary shall consider in setting limits under subsection (a) of this section shall include:

paragraph.text: the family income deemed available for housing;
the size of the family;
the ability of the family to compete successfully in the private housing market;
the cost and condition of available housing; and
relevant standards and definitions under federal and State housing programs.

subsection.text: There is a Lead Hazard Reduction Grant Program.
The Department may make a grant solely to finance a lead hazard reduction activity that:

paragraph.text: is a program that tests innovative or unproven methods of lead hazard reduction; or
is in a residential property in an area designated by the Department to have a concentration of:

subparagraph.text: families of limited income; and

sub-subparagraph.text: residential property constructed before 1950; or
children diagnosed with elevated blood lead, which is a quantity of lead in their blood, expressed in micrograms per deciliter (g/dl), that exceeds a specified threshold level.

paragraph.text: The Department may establish standards to determine the eligibility of a lead hazard reduction activity for a grant under the Grant Program.
The standards may call for consideration of:

subparagraph.text: the extent to which the lead hazard reduction activity benefits families of limited income;
the need and circumstances of the owner–occupants or tenants of the residential property in which the proposed lead hazard reduction activity will be undertaken; and
whether the grant finances research into innovative or unproven methods for lead hazard reduction.

subsection.text: In determining whether to make a grant under the Grant Program, the Department shall require that the owner of the residential property or child care center submit evidence that the owner cannot undertake lead hazard reduction activity without a grant.
The Department may require that all or part of a grant under the Grant Program be repaid when conditions specified by the Department occur.
There is a Lead Hazard Reduction Loan Program.
The Department may make a loan to finance lead hazard reduction activity.
A loan under the Loan Program:

paragraph.text: may be secured by a mortgage lien or other security interest acceptable to the Department; and
may include terms that the Department considers appropriate.

subsection.text: For a loan made under the Loan Program, the Department may:

paragraph.text: defer payment of principal and interest; and
establish interest rates as low as 0%.

subsection.text: Each loan shall require repayment of all unpaid principal and payment of accrued interest, including deferred interest, but the loan terms may allow the Department to forgive all or part of the principal and interest.
If a loan is in default, the Department may modify the interest rate, the time or amount of payment, or any other term to facilitate repayment and achieve the purposes of the Loan Program.

section.text: In reviewing an application for a loan or grant, the Department shall consider:

paragraph.text: the needs of the beneficiaries of the proposed lead hazard reduction activity;
the capacity of the applicant to repay a loan;
the overall public benefit;
the impact on the surrounding neighborhood or community; and
any other factor that the Department finds relevant.

subsection.text: In this section, “Committee” means the Lead Hazard Advisory Committee.
There is a Lead Hazard Advisory Committee.
The Committee consists of the following seven members:

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Housing and Community Development, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of the Environment, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene, or the Secretary’s designee; and
four members appointed by the Governor:

subparagraph.text: a member of the Lead Poisoning Prevention Commission;
a representative of owners of residential rental property built before 1950;
a representative of a child, youth, or health advocacy group; and
a member of the public who has an interest in lead in the environment.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member of the Committee is 4 years.
The terms of the appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Committee on October 1, 2005.
At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
An appointed member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Secretary or the Secretary’s designee is the chair of the Committee.
Each member of the Committee is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
In consultation with the Committee, the Department shall develop regulations, policies, and guidelines to carry out the Grant Program and the Loan Program.

paragraph.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in a document required to be submitted to the Department relating to a grant or loan.

A grant or loan applicant may not knowingly make or cause to be made any false statement or report to influence the action of the Department on a grant or loan application or a grant or loan already made.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Adjusted annual income” means gross income from all sources with adjustments, as determined by the Department, made for unusual or temporary income items and long-term unusual expenses such as medical, rehabilitation, or special education expenses.
“Adjusted annual income” includes:

subparagraph.text: wages;
investment income;
Social Security payments;
retirement payments;
disability payments; and
unemployment insurance payments.

subsection.text: “Fund” means the Homeownership Programs Fund under Subtitle 5 of this title.
“Household of limited income” means one or more individuals whose aggregate adjusted annual income does not exceed the upper income limits that the Secretary sets under § 4-807 of this subtitle.
“Lot consolidation” means the acquisition of real property adjacent to and in connection with a residence financed by the Program to include the real property as part of the residence.

“Median annual family income” means the median annual family income for the State, county, or area, whichever is greatest, as shown in the latest Census Bureau Report of the United States Department of Commerce.
“Preferred interest rate” means an interest rate that the Department sets under § 4-806(c) of this subtitle.
“Program” means the Maryland Home Financing Program.
“Region” means an area of the State that the Department establishes comprising one or more counties.
“Short-term loan” means a loan that, under the loan documents, is expected to be taken out by other financing within 7 years.

section.text: This subtitle applies only to loans that the Department makes under this subtitle or that were made before July 1, 1989, under the Maryland Home Financing Program, the Reverse Equity Loan Program, or the Homeowners’ Emergency Mortgage Assistance Program.
There is a Maryland Home Financing Program.
The purposes of the Program are to make, participate in making, and purchase:

paragraph.text: preferred interest rate loans to acquire, acquire and rehabilitate with or without demolition or lot consolidation, or refinance a primary residence by:

subparagraph.text: households of limited income that will occupy single–unit primary residences; or
owner–occupants of residential buildings with not more than four units, if each unit other than the owner’s will be occupied by a household of limited income;

paragraph.text: short–term construction loans to developers or nonprofit sponsors to construct or rehabilitate dwelling units that households of limited income can afford;

short–term loans to nonprofit sponsors, as defined in Departmental regulations, to acquire and construct or acquire and rehabilitate, with or without demolition or lot consolidation, dwelling units that households of limited income can afford to buy under a purchase or lease–purchase contract;

emergency assistance loans to households of limited income who, because of unemployment or other extraordinary hardship, cannot make current mortgage payments on their homes and risk forfeiting the title to their homes;
reverse equity loans to elderly households of limited income for housing related expenses or personal expenses that enable the owner to continue to occupy the home; and

preferred interest rate loans to households that meet income standards set by the Department for the redemption of ground leases on their principal residence, including the transactional costs associated with the redemption.

section.text: The Department may:

paragraph.text: contract for services related to the Program;
contract with private mortgage servicers to perform on behalf of the Department functions the servicers ordinarily perform, including foreclosure and employment of counsel;
require payment of a nonrefundable application fee;
purchase or commit to purchase from mortgage lenders notes or mortgages that meet the requirements of this subtitle, any regulations adopted under it, and appropriate Program directives; and
without approval or execution by the Board of Public Works:

subparagraph.text: assign a mortgage for value;
release a mortgage;
foreclose a mortgage;
acquire property that secures a loan in default;
encumber, sell, or otherwise dispose of property acquired in connection with a loan in default;
sell a loan at a discount or on other terms acceptable to the Department;
transfer to the Fund money received on the sale of a loan under item (vi) of this item; and
repurchase or pay the cost of servicing a loan that has been sold under item (vi) of this item with money in the Fund and on terms acceptable to the Department.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: manage the Program in a manner that:

subparagraph.text: serves all areas of the State; and
does not create or aggravate low-income concentrations that adversely affect communities;

paragraph.text: periodically set upper limits on adjusted annual income;
use federal or State programs that complement or facilitate carrying out the Program; and
adopt regulations to carry out the Program.

subsection.text: The Department shall adopt policies to ensure that each loan made under the Program is made only to:

paragraph.text: a household that:

subparagraph.text: when the loan is made, has an adjusted annual income at or below the applicable upper limit that the Secretary sets under § 4-807 of this subtitle; and

cannot qualify for conventional or other available departmental financing to enable the owner to continue to occupy the home, or to acquire, acquire and rehabilitate with or without demolition or lot consolidation, or refinance a home;

paragraph.text: a developer that the Department reasonably believes can build or rehabilitate housing that a household of limited income can afford; and
an owner-occupant of a residential building with not more than four units if each unit other than the owner’s will be occupied by a household of limited income.
For each type of loan described in § 4–804 of this subtitle, the Department periodically shall set:

subparagraph.text: appropriate terms, including deferred payments on principal and interest; and
a preferred interest rate that may be as low as 0.0% or as high as is reasonable in light of the incomes of the proposed occupants.

paragraph.text: In setting these terms and interest rates, the Department shall take into account rates available in the conventional private housing market and the adjusted annual income and assets of prospective borrowers.

subsection.text: In setting upper limits on adjusted annual income, the Department shall consider factors including:

paragraph.text: the total income of each individual expected to live in the home;
the size of the household;
the cost of available housing facilities;
the ability of the household to compete successfully in the conventional private housing market; and
pertinent standards and definitions established for federal housing programs.

subsection.text: Upper limits on adjusted annual income may vary for different:

paragraph.text: types of housing;
types of financing offered by the Program; and
regions.

subsection.text: Within the upper limits on adjusted annual income, lower income limit ranges and lower interest rates may be established for loans to households with adjusted annual incomes in the lower ranges.

Except for loans made under § 4–804(4) and (6) of this subtitle, the upper limits on adjusted annual income established under subsection (a) of this section may not exceed the median annual family income.

section.text: The Program shall be operated with the money in the Fund.
To apply for a loan under this subtitle, an applicant shall submit:

paragraph.text: a completed application in a form that the Department requires;
a copy of the applicant’s latest State income tax return or other available verification of income, unless the application is for a loan under § 4-804(1)(i) or (2) of this subtitle; and
any other information or documentation that the Department considers necessary to make a determination on the loan.

subsection.text: To qualify for a loan under § 4-804(1)(i), (4), or (5) of this subtitle, an applicant:

paragraph.text: shall be a member of a household of limited income;
on closing of the loan, shall intend to reside in the home to be financed;
may not own other property used as the applicant’s personal residence; and
in the estimation of the Department, shall lack the financial resources to obtain a private conventional mortgage or to qualify for other departmental loan programs.

subsection.text: To qualify for a loan under § 4-804(1)(ii) of this subtitle, an applicant:

paragraph.text: shall agree in writing to live as an owner-occupant in one of the units of a residential building with no more than four units;
shall agree in writing to rent each unit other than the applicant’s unit to a household of limited income; and
in the estimation of the Department, shall lack the financial resources to obtain a private conventional mortgage or qualify for other departmental loan programs.

subsection.text: To qualify for a loan under § 4-804(2) of this subtitle, an applicant shall agree to sell or rent each dwelling unit constructed or rehabilitated with the proceeds of the loan to a household of limited income.
To qualify for a loan under § 4–804(6) of this subtitle, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: own and occupy the home as the applicant’s principal residence; and
meet the income requirements set by the Department.

subsection.text: To qualify for an emergency assistance loan made under § 4-804(4) of this subtitle, an applicant:

paragraph.text: shall be unable to keep payments current on the applicant’s home mortgage because of unforeseeable adverse personal or economic circumstances;
shall be at risk of forfeiting title to the applicant’s home; and
reasonably may be expected to resume regular mortgage payments within 24 months after the first mortgage assistance payment is provided.

subsection.text: For an emergency assistance loan under § 4-804(4) of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: the Department shall consider the amount of equity in the property; and
the loan may not exceed an amount equal to 36 payments of principal and interest on all superior liens, plus:

subparagraph.text: late fees;
taxes;
insurance payments; and
other payments needed for the loan to be current.

section.text: To qualify for a reverse equity loan under § 4-804(5) of this subtitle, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: be at least 62 years old when the loan closes; and
need financial assistance with housing-related expenses or personal expenses that enable the owner to continue to occupy the home.

subsection.text: To qualify for a short-term construction loan under § 4-804(2) of this subtitle, a developer or nonprofit sponsor shall:

paragraph.text: provide construction costs, marketing data, and other information the Department requires; and
have a commitment from the Department under § 4-815(j) of this subtitle for permanent financing for the sale of each residence to be built or rehabilitated with the short-term construction loan.

subsection.text: To qualify for a short-term loan under § 4-804(3) of this subtitle, a nonprofit sponsor:

paragraph.text: shall provide:

subparagraph.text: information on the costs of the proposed undertaking;
marketing data; and
other information the Department requires; and

paragraph.text: shall have:

subparagraph.text: a commitment from the Department for permanent financing for the sale of each residence built or rehabilitated with the short-term loan; or
approval from the Department to rent the residence subject to a lease purchase agreement acceptable to the Department.

section.text: To qualify for a preferred interest rate loan to refinance an existing home under § 4-804(1) of this subtitle, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: be unable to keep payments current on the applicant’s home mortgage because of exceptional adverse personal or economic circumstances; and
risk forfeiting title to the applicant’s home.

subsection.text: As to each loan, the Department may set:

paragraph.text: the principal amount, subject to subsection (f) of this section;
the term of the loan, not to exceed 40 years except in the case of a reverse equity loan made under subsection (b)(3) of this section;
the interest rate, which may be adjustable under subsection (g) of this section;
the principal repayment terms, subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section; and
other terms that the Department considers necessary to achieve the purposes of the Program.
A loan may provide for immediate acceleration if the borrower violates § 4-816 of this subtitle or if the loan is in default.
In the case of a preferred interest rate loan under § 4-804(1) of this subtitle, a loan may provide for full acceleration of principal after 5 years if the borrower:

subparagraph.text: no longer qualifies as a household of limited income; and
can qualify for conventional mortgage financing.

paragraph.text: In the case of a reverse equity loan made under § 4-804(5) of this subtitle, a loan may provide for:

subparagraph.text: full or partial deferral on payment of interest and principal until sale, conveyance in accordance with a will or trust instrument, or other transfer of the mortgaged property or a beneficial interest in the property; and
forgiveness of accrued interest in excess of the available equity in the mortgaged property when the conveyance occurs.

paragraph.text: In the case of an emergency assistance loan under § 4-804(4) of this subtitle, a loan may provide for full or partial deferral of payment of interest and principal until a stated date when the Department reasonably anticipates that the borrower will be able to make full or partial payments.

subsection.text: A mortgage shall include the right of the Department to:

paragraph.text: foreclose the mortgage and take title to the foreclosed property or convey title to a buyer; and
obtain a deficiency judgment.
Repayment of a loan shall be secured by a recorded lien on the real property.
The lien may be a subordinate lien.
A lien securing an emergency assistance loan may be released if the release is in the interest of the Department.

subsection.text: The Department may require a mortgage to be insured at the borrower’s expense by a federal, State, or private instrumentality.

paragraph.text: For a preferred interest loan under § 4–804(1) of this subtitle, the amount of the loan and any prior recorded liens outstanding may not exceed the value of the secured property, as determined by the Department when the loan is closed, plus settlement expenses.

For a reverse equity loan under § 4–804(5) of this subtitle, the principal amount of the loan and any prior liens outstanding may not exceed the value of the secured property as determined by the Department from time to time.

For a short–term loan under § 4–804(2) of this subtitle, the amount of the loan may not exceed the total commitments for permanent financing for buyers, including any commitments of federal, State, or local money to subsidize the cost of the dwelling units.

For a preferred interest rate loan under § 4–804(6) of this subtitle, the Department may set the maximum amount of the loan, including the maximum amount that may be used for the transactional costs associated with the redemption.

subsection.text: After full disclosure to the borrower when the loan is made, the Department may take as security an adjustable interest rate mortgage under which any rate adjustment must:

paragraph.text: follow written notice to the borrower; and
be based on an increase or decrease in household income.

subsection.text: On default, the Department may modify the interest rate, the time or amount of payment, or any other term of the loan to facilitate repayment of the loan and achieve the purposes of the Program.
For a mortgage securing a loan under this subtitle, the Department may allow:

paragraph.text: the transfer of the mortgaged property or an interest in the property without monetary consideration:

subparagraph.text: to a spouse, child, or other immediate family member; or
