in connection with the death of a borrower, a divorce decree, or a legal separation agreement; and

paragraph.text: assumption of the mortgage by a transferee described in item (1)(i) of this subsection for monetary consideration and by any other transferee with or without consideration if the transferee qualifies as a household of limited income and satisfies all other Program requirements.

subsection.text: For the developer of housing that will be priced so as to be affordable to households of limited income, the Department may commit to reserve for a fixed period a fixed amount of Program money to be available to finance preferred interest rate mortgage loans for households of limited income who seek to purchase from the developer fully constructed or rehabilitated homes.
A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made any material misstatement of fact, including an understatement or overstatement of financial condition, in a statement or report that:

paragraph.text: is in or relates to a loan application under this subtitle; or
affects a loan already made under this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Cooperative housing corporation” has the meaning stated in § 5–6B–01 of the Corporations and Associations Article.
“Cooperative interest” has the meaning stated in § 5–6B–01 of the Corporations and Associations Article.

paragraph.text: “Family of limited income” means a family or individual whose income does not exceed the limits that the Secretary establishes under § 4–915 of this subtitle.

“Family of limited income” includes a trust described in 42 U.S.C. § 1396p(d)(4), or a trust established for the benefit of an individual with a disability by an individual other than the beneficiary and that is funded with assets that were never owned or controlled by the beneficiary, if:

subparagraph.text: the income of the trust does not exceed the upper income limits established by the Secretary under § 4–915 of this subtitle; and
the beneficiary of the trust is an individual who resides in the residential building owned by the trust.

subsection.text: “Local rehabilitation program” means a rehabilitation program that uses Program loans and is administered by a political subdivision.
“Member” has the meaning stated in § 5–6B–01 of the Corporations and Associations Article.

“Minimum livability code” means a regulation, statute, or ordinance that establishes minimum property maintenance standards that the State or a political subdivision adopts under § 12–203 of the Public Safety Article.
“Nonprofit sponsor” means:

paragraph.text: a nonprofit organization;
a political subdivision; or
a limited partnership formed to undertake a rehabilitation project that is eligible wholly or partly for federal programs or incentives, including low–income housing tax credits, if:

subparagraph.text: each general partner is a nonprofit organization or a political subdivision; or

sub-subparagraph.text: each general partner is a wholly owned subsidiary of a nonprofit organization or political subdivision; and
a nonprofit organization or political subdivision manages the rehabilitation project or will receive net cash flow or the residual sale proceeds on the sale of the rehabilitation project.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program.
“Program loan” means a loan under the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program or a special loan program.

paragraph.text: “Rehabilitation project” means a project to repair, reconstruct, renovate, redevelop, improve, modify, or add to a building for a purpose listed in § 4–923 of this subtitle.
“Rehabilitation project” includes providing utility submetering for dwellings in a residential rental building.

subsection.text: “Special loan program” means:

paragraph.text: the Accessory, Shared, and Sheltered Housing Program;
the Indoor Plumbing Program;
the Lead Paint Abatement Program;
the Migratory Worker Housing Program; or
the Radon and Asbestos Abatement Pilot Program.

subsection.text: “Sponsor” means an owner who receives a loan to rehabilitate a building for residential rental purposes or nonresidential purposes.
This subtitle applies to buildings that, after rehabilitation, provide:

paragraph.text: traditional dwellings;
single room occupancy;
shared living dwellings in which two or more households can live and share some or all of the living, dining, kitchen, or sanitary facilities; or
congregate or group housing and related services or temporary shelters and related services that serve:

subparagraph.text: individuals with disabilities or low-income, elderly households, homeless, or other disadvantaged individuals; or
the nonresidential commercial, business, or social needs of the community where the building is located, so as to enhance the economic feasibility of housing rehabilitation in that community.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to a building that provides group housing unless the group housing is provided by an owner-occupant or a nonprofit sponsor.

section.text: The General Assembly finds that:

subparagraph.text: many residents of the State live in dwellings that do not conform to building, health, safety, fire, occupancy, or other codes and standards applicable to housing;
many communities or political subdivisions in the State do not have a minimum livability code; and
these conditions impede the development and maintenance of healthy, safe, and viable communities;

paragraph.text: private sector financing is often unavailable for rehabilitation because:

subparagraph.text: owner-occupants of housing in need of rehabilitation often have low incomes; and
nonoccupant owners often incur high risks in owning and managing the housing;

paragraph.text: rehabilitating suitable housing:

subparagraph.text: increases the economic life of the housing;
is often more economical and less disruptive than replacing the housing and relocating its occupants;
can better promote community development when it is done through organized housing rehabilitation programs;
is essential for sound community development; and
can be helped by rehabilitating commercial buildings serving communities where housing rehabilitation is desirable;

paragraph.text: it is a proper public purpose for which public money may be spent and property acquired to:

subparagraph.text: rehabilitate housing;
develop healthful, safe, and viable communities;
rehabilitate commercial buildings to help rehabilitate and develop housing; and
provide healthful and safe housing for migratory workers to maintain and expand the agricultural activities that are dependent on the labor of these workers; and

paragraph.text: it is a proper public purpose for which public money may be spent to:

subparagraph.text: improve, modify, and add to housing to increase the supply of special housing for special populations, such as elderly households, individuals with disabilities, and other disadvantaged residents of the State;
prevent lead poisoning by modifying older housing to provide a lead-safe environment, as lead paint in older housing is a major source of lead poisoning in children;
provide adequate indoor plumbing, water supply, and sewage disposal systems for dwellings;
rehabilitate or acquire and rehabilitate large rental housing facilities for low- and moderate-income individuals and keep those facilities in a decent, safe, and sanitary condition; and
reduce or eliminate radon and asbestos, which are major detriments to the health and safety of residents, on a pilot program basis.

section.text: There is a Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program.
The Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program includes:

paragraph.text: the Accessory, Shared, and Sheltered Housing Program;
the Indoor Plumbing Program;
the Migratory Worker Housing Program;
the Nonprofit Rehabilitation Program; and
the Radon and Asbestos Abatement Pilot Program.
The Department shall operate the Program and make Program loans.
As much as possible, the Program shall be administered:

subparagraph.text: in conjunction with federal programs assisting rehabilitation of housing, to ensure maximum use of available federal money; and
consistently with locally approved plans or programs of concentrated neighborhood revitalization.

paragraph.text: The Multifamily Rehabilitation Program consists of:

subparagraph.text: Program loans made to rehabilitate or acquire and rehabilitate buildings providing more than four dwellings or serving nonresidential needs; and
Program loans to nonprofit sponsors under § 4-929 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Except for Program loans made under a special loan program, the Regular Rehabilitation Program consists of Program loans to rehabilitate residential buildings providing four or fewer dwellings.
The Special Rehabilitation Program consists of Program loans made under a special loan program.

subsection.text: The Regular Rehabilitation Program and the Special Rehabilitation Program shall operate with money in the Special Loan Programs Fund and other money available to the Department for these programs.

paragraph.text: If the applications that qualify for a Program loan under the Regular Rehabilitation Program or a special loan program do not commit all money appropriated to that loan program within 6 months after the appropriation, the Department may reallocate the remaining appropriated money to any other program financed by the Special Loan Programs Fund.

In like circumstances, the Department may reallocate money appropriated to the Nonprofit Rehabilitation Program or the Multifamily Rehabilitation Program to any other program financed by the Rental Housing Programs Fund.

section.text: The Department may:

paragraph.text: limit the return on equity allowed to, or enter into equity participation agreements with, sponsors and nonprofit sponsors;
require and obtain appraisals, credit and title information, and other information related to making Program loans;
contract for services relating to any aspect of the operation of the Program under the procedures required by law for State contracts;
charge and collect:

subparagraph.text: reasonable application and processing fees; and
other charges, fees, or reimbursements incidental to Program loans; and

paragraph.text: if necessary, limit the cumulative outstanding debt for Program loans made to a trust described in 42 U.S.C. § 1396p(d)(4) to preserve the ongoing financial viability of the Program.

subsection.text: If Program loans are secured by first or junior mortgages, the Department may:

paragraph.text: enforce the mortgages;
foreclose on the mortgages and take title to the mortgaged properties, or take deeds in lieu of foreclosure;
convey title to purchasers;
obtain and enforce deficiency judgments;
allow assumption of mortgages; and
contract with private mortgage servicers to perform on behalf of the Department any functions the servicers ordinarily perform.

subsection.text: Without approval or execution by the Board of Public Works, the Department may:

paragraph.text: assign mortgages for value;
release mortgages when paid;
foreclose on mortgages;
take deeds in lieu of foreclosure; or
convey property after acquisition.

subsection.text: If a Program loan to a member of a cooperative housing corporation is secured by a security interest in the member’s cooperative interest, the Department may:

paragraph.text: foreclose on the security interest or otherwise enforce the security interest as permitted under Title 9 of the Commercial Law Article;
take possession of the premises in lieu of foreclosure;
obtain and enforce deficiency judgments;
transfer the cooperative interest;
allow assumption of the security agreement; and
contract with private loan servicers to perform on behalf of the Department any functions the private loan servicers ordinarily perform.

subsection.text: Without approval or execution by the Board of Public Works, the Department may:

paragraph.text: assign a security interest for value;
release a security interest when paid;
foreclose on a security interest;
take possession of the premises in lieu of foreclosure; or
transfer a cooperative interest after acquisition.

section.text: The Department may adopt regulations to carry out the Program.

subsection.text: To ensure that all areas of the State are served, the Department shall allocate at least annually among the counties the money appropriated for making Program loans under the Regular Rehabilitation Program.
When allocating money to a county, the Department shall consider:

paragraph.text: the number of families of limited income in the county;
the need to rehabilitate buildings in the county;
the capability of the county to administer a local rehabilitation program; and
other standards that the Department considers relevant to ensure fair and equitable distribution of money among counties.

subsection.text: The Department may:

paragraph.text: allocate on a countywide basis first and then make suballocations among participating municipal corporations within counties;
allocate up to 25% of the total money available in the Special Loan Programs Fund to a reserve; and
from time to time, reallocate the money held in the reserve.

section.text: Money that is received as repayment of principal or payment of interest on loans under the Program and that is not appropriated in the State budget may be credited to the Annuity Bond Fund, to be used to pay the principal of or interest on money borrowed by the State and appropriated to the Program.
The Department shall include in its request for appropriations for the Program:

paragraph.text: an estimate of the interest rates at which Program loans may be made in the next fiscal year;
the total principal amount of Program loans expected to be made at those interest rates in the next fiscal year; and
any other information that the Secretary of Budget and Management requests about Program loans.

subsection.text: If the Department certifies a political subdivision as capable of administering a local rehabilitation program, the political subdivision may originate and administer Program loans under regulations of the Department.

paragraph.text: By regulation, the Department shall establish standards for determining the capability of a political subdivision to administer a local rehabilitation program.
The standards shall include provisions on:

subparagraph.text: the size, training, and experience of the professional staff that would administer the Program; and
the capability of the professional staff to:

sub-subparagraph.text: determine rehabilitation needs;
establish rehabilitation programs;
evaluate applications for Program loans; and
monitor Program loans and the rehabilitation work done with them.

subsection.text: If the Department determines that a political subdivision cannot or does not want to administer a local rehabilitation program, the Department may originate and administer Program loans from the allocation or suballocation to that political subdivision.
The Department may:

paragraph.text: help train employees of political subdivisions to administer local rehabilitation programs under the standards that the Department sets; and

provide political subdivisions advice and technical assistance on the administration of their local rehabilitation programs, including loan packaging, contractor and bid selection, zoning, marketing, engineering, and related services.
The Secretary shall set upper limits on the income that a family or individual may have to qualify as a family of limited income.
In setting the limits, the Secretary shall consider factors that include:

subparagraph.text: the portion of the total family income available for housing;
the size of the family;
the cost and condition of available housing;
the ability of the family to compete successfully in the private housing market; and
relevant standards and definitions established for federal and State housing programs.

subsection.text: The Secretary may waive income limits for a borrower or occupant seeking a Program loan to rehabilitate a building that the State historical preservation officer finds historically or architecturally significant.

paragraph.text: The Department may make Program loans for housing on terms that the Department considers necessary to make the housing affordable to families of limited income.
The terms may include:

subparagraph.text: deferred payment of principal and interest until the maturity date or the date of any sale or other transfer of the building or an interest in the building;

an interest rate as low as 0% or as high as is reasonable, given the incomes of the proposed occupants, if the interest rate does not violate any federal regulation governing the borrowing of money by the State;
increased interest rates or accelerated payments of principal and interest, if the borrower no longer qualifies for the Program loan; and
advance payments to a nonprofit sponsor for certain development costs, including architectural, engineering, and attorneys’ fees.

subsection.text: Within the maximum income limits for families of limited income, the Secretary may establish:

paragraph.text: lower income ranges;
interest rates to be available on Program loans serving occupants with incomes within those lower ranges; and
any preference or reservation of money for applications for Program loans to finance housing to serve occupants in those lower income ranges.

subsection.text: A Program loan:

paragraph.text: may not be made if the Department determines that comparable private financing is available to the prospective borrower; and
may not exceed an amount the Secretary establishes by regulation.

Except as provided under paragraphs (2), (3), and (4) of this subsection, a Program loan of more than $5,000 shall be secured wholly or partly by a recorded mortgage or deed of trust on real property.
A Program loan to a political subdivision may be secured by a recorded mortgage, deed of trust on real property, or other security device acceptable to the Department.
A Program loan to a trust described in 42 U.S.C. § 1396p(d)(4) may be secured by a recorded mortgage, deed of trust on real property, or other security device acceptable to the Department.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a Program loan to a member of a cooperative housing corporation may be secured by a perfected security interest in the member’s cooperative interest.

Before a Program loan is secured by a perfected security interest in the member’s cooperative interest, the Department shall enter into an agreement with the cooperative housing corporation that establishes the rights and obligations of the Department and the cooperative housing corporation with respect to the secured cooperative interest.

subsection.text: Program loans shall be made to:

paragraph.text: families of limited income owning and occupying the building to be rehabilitated; or
sponsors or nonprofit sponsors.

subsection.text: The Department may require that Program loans be insured.
A Program loan may cover:

paragraph.text: costs of a rehabilitation project, including implementation costs such as appraisal, architectural, and engineering fees; and
closing costs of the Program loan.

subsection.text: The Department may modify the interest rate, the time or amount of payment, or any other term of a Program loan that is in default to facilitate repayment of the Program loan and achieve the purposes of the Program.

paragraph.text: When the Department makes a Program loan to finance a residential rehabilitation project, the sponsor or nonprofit sponsor shall restrict some dwellings for occupancy by families of limited income for at least the greater of 15 years and the number of years required by federal law.
The number of dwellings restricted under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be at least the greater of:

subparagraph.text: the number that bears the same ratio to the total number of dwellings in the project as the amount the Program loan bears to the total financing of the undertaking;
the number of dwellings chosen by the sponsor to satisfy federal occupancy requirements if the residential rehabilitation project receives an allocation of federal low-income housing tax credits; and

the number of dwellings required for a community development project under § 4-217(b)(1)(ii) of this title or the number of dwellings that the issuer of the bonds chooses, whichever is greater, if a portion of the costs of the residential rehabilitation project is financed by government-issued, federally tax–exempt revenue bonds.

subsection.text: Dwellings restricted for occupancy to meet other federal or State occupancy requirements may be counted toward the number required under subsection (a) of this section.
As a condition to certain types of Program loans, the Department may require the political subdivision where a rehabilitation project is located to make a contribution to the project.
The Secretary shall establish standards to promote the maximum use of private financing.

If a portion of a rehabilitation project is to be financed by a private lending institution, the Department shall require that the sponsor use all the private financing that the rehabilitation project can support without impairing:

paragraph.text: the rehabilitation project; or
affordable housing for families of limited income, if the rehabilitation project is residential.

subsection.text: As long as the State complies with all applicable federal treasury regulations governing borrowing money by the State, a Program loan shall be at an interest rate that at least covers:

paragraph.text: the administrative and other expenses of the Program; and
reasonably expected losses from defaults on Program loans.

section.text: The Department shall establish a maximum percentage or amount of Program loans from the Rental Housing Programs Fund that may be used for nonresidential rehabilitation.

subsection.text: Rehabilitation loans under the Multifamily Rehabilitation Program and nonprofit rehabilitation loans shall be financed by the Rental Housing Programs Fund.
Rehabilitation loans under the Regular Rehabilitation Program and special loan programs shall be financed by the Special Loan Programs Fund.

In addition to making loans for rehabilitation projects to sponsors, nonprofit sponsors, or families of limited income from the Rental Housing Programs Fund and the Special Loan Programs Fund, the Department may use money from any other authorized source, including federal programs of assistance for rehabilitation, to make:

paragraph.text: grants for rehabilitation projects to families of limited income or nonprofit sponsors; and
loans for rehabilitation projects to sponsors, nonprofit sponsors, or families of limited income.
The Department:

subparagraph.text: shall use federal programs of assistance for rehabilitation to the maximum extent consistent with the purposes of this subtitle; and
may do all things necessary to qualify for participation in those programs.

paragraph.text: The terms and conditions of loans and grants made under this section shall be in accordance with the legislation or other authority by which the money is made available to the Department.

subsection.text: The purpose of a rehabilitation project is:

paragraph.text: to bring a building to a decent, safe, and sanitary condition in accordance with applicable codes and standards, including those for construction, health, safety, fire, and occupancy;
to maintain the building in that condition;
to make the building more useful and attractive;
to conform the building to the appropriate minimum livability code;
to acquire a building containing more than four dwelling units for the purposes set forth in items (1) through (4) of this subsection;
to provide, under applicable special loan programs:

subparagraph.text: lead paint abatement;
indoor plumbing; or
shared, accessory, or sheltered housing;

paragraph.text: in the case of a loan to an elderly household or a disabled homeowner, to modify or improve a dwelling to make it more accessible or functional for the occupants, if the building is, or after improvements will be, structurally sound and free of health and safety hazards; or
to provide, under applicable special loan pilot programs, radon abatement or asbestos abatement.
The applicable codes and standards under subsection (a)(1) of this section are:

subparagraph.text: those in force in the political subdivision where the building is located; or

those that the Department sets by regulation for that political subdivision solely for purposes of this subtitle, if the political subdivision lacks codes and standards that the Secretary considers sufficient to promote the objectives of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: With the approval of the local enforcement authority, the Secretary may allow exceptions to a code or standard to preserve the historic or architectural value of a building undergoing rehabilitation under this subtitle.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Accessory housing” means a dwelling with complete and independent sleeping, cooking, and living facilities that is:

subparagraph.text: within, attached to, or on the same parcel as a single-family, owner-occupied dwelling; and
subordinate to but under the same ownership as the single-family, owner-occupied dwelling.

paragraph.text: “Shared housing” means a single-family, owner-occupied dwelling adapted for common and shared living use by the owner-occupant and another family of limited income.
“Sheltered housing” means a single-family, owner-occupied dwelling that:

subparagraph.text: accommodates the owner-occupant; and
provides sleeping and living facilities, meals, and assistance with daily activities for a rental fee to not more than 15 elderly individuals or individuals with disabilities.

subsection.text: There is an Accessory, Shared, and Sheltered Housing Program.

The Department shall operate the Accessory, Shared, and Sheltered Housing Program and make loans for rehabilitation costs for accessory, shared, and sheltered housing from the Special Loan Programs Fund under this subtitle.
The terms for accessory, shared, and sheltered housing loans shall satisfy the requirements of § 4-916(b) of this subtitle.
To qualify for an accessory housing loan, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: own the property for which the loan is made and agree to live in the property after the rehabilitation is completed; and

subparagraph.text: agree to use the loan proceeds to implement a rehabilitation project to provide an accessory dwelling for a family of limited income for a fixed minimum term that the Department determines; or
be a family of limited income when the loan is made and agree to use the loan proceeds to provide an accessory dwelling for a fixed minimum term that the Department determines.

subsection.text: To qualify for a shared housing loan, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: be a family of limited income;
own the property for which the loan is made and agree to live in the property after the rehabilitation is completed; and
agree to use the loan proceeds to implement a rehabilitation project to provide shared housing or an accessory dwelling for a family of limited income.

subsection.text: To qualify for a sheltered housing loan, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: own the property for which the loan is made and agree to live in the property after the rehabilitation is completed;
agree to provide shelter, meals, and assistance with daily activities to not more than 15 elderly individuals or individuals with disabilities who qualify as families of limited income; and
demonstrate that the property will be certified by the appropriate governmental unit to provide sheltered care to elderly individuals or individuals with disabilities.

subsection.text: There is an Indoor Plumbing Program.
The Department shall:

paragraph.text: operate the Indoor Plumbing Program; and
make loans for rehabilitation projects that provide for adequate indoor plumbing from the Special Loan Programs Fund under this subtitle.
The terms for indoor plumbing loans shall meet the requirements of §§ 4-917 through 4-919 of this subtitle.
The Department may forgive all or part of a deferred payment loan, if:

subparagraph.text: the loan is made to a family of limited income that owns and occupies the dwelling and whose income is within a lower income range established under § 4-916(b) of this subtitle; and
the Secretary determines that the family of limited income does not have enough income to repay the principal amount of the loan.

subsection.text: To qualify for an indoor plumbing loan, an applicant shall:

paragraph.text: own a building that is otherwise structurally sound, or for which the applicant provides a commitment from a lender to finance improvements needed to make the building structurally sound, and that:

subparagraph.text: has no or incomplete indoor plumbing or a failing septic system; and
needs indoor plumbing pipes, equipment, wells, septic tanks or other on-site sewer system, or a connection to a community water or sewer system;

paragraph.text: live in the building and be a family of limited income, or rent at least two-thirds of the dwellings in the building to families of limited income; and

submit to the Department a proposal for installing an adequate indoor plumbing system for water supply and sewage disposal, including any needed septic system, well, or connection to a community sewer or water system that meets the requirements of the Department of the Environment and every other governmental unit that has jurisdiction over the system.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “Migratory labor camp” means one or more structures, buildings, tents, barracks, trailers, vehicles, mobile homes, converted buildings, or unconventional enclosures of living space that are established, operated, or used as living quarters for four or more migratory workers engaged in agricultural activities, including related food processing.
“Migratory labor camp” includes appurtenant land.

paragraph.text: “Migratory Housing Program” means the Migratory Worker Housing Program.
“Migratory worker” means an individual from within or outside the State who:

subparagraph.text: is not a year-round employee but moves seasonally from one place to another for work; and
during a period of work, occupies living quarters that are not the individual’s permanent home.

subsection.text: There is a Migratory Worker Housing Program.
The Department shall:

paragraph.text: operate the Migratory Housing Program;

make migratory worker housing loans from the Special Loan Programs Fund under this subtitle to a qualified owner of a migratory labor camp to make migratory worker housing safer and more healthful; and
to the extent determined by the Secretary, administer the Migratory Housing Program in conjunction with any appropriate federal program.

subsection.text: To the extent applicable, migratory worker housing loans shall satisfy the requirements of § 4-916(b) of this subtitle.
To qualify for a migratory housing loan, the owner of a migratory labor camp shall:

paragraph.text: live or have a principal place of business in the State;

have been denied a loan by a private lending institution or have received a commitment from a private lending institution for less than the amount of money required to finance the necessary health and safety improvements; and
submit to the Department a plan for the necessary health and safety improvements that has been approved by the Department of the Environment.

subsection.text: There is a Nonprofit Rehabilitation Program.
The Department shall:

paragraph.text: operate the Nonprofit Rehabilitation Program; and
make loans for rehabilitation projects to nonprofit sponsors under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The terms of a nonprofit rehabilitation loan shall meet the requirements of § 4-916(b) of this subtitle.
To qualify for a nonprofit rehabilitation loan, a nonprofit sponsor shall:

paragraph.text: own or have a contract to acquire the building to be rehabilitated or act on behalf of the owner;
demonstrate the capability to manage the rehabilitated project and pay back the loan; and
agree to use the loan proceeds for a rehabilitation project that provides housing for families of limited income in accordance with the requirements of § 4-918(a) and (b) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A nonprofit sponsor that qualifies for a nonprofit rehabilitation loan may provide for:

paragraph.text: nonresidential uses that are not directly related to the residential facilities but occupy a minor part of the building and offer goods or services for families of limited income or other disadvantaged individuals; or

periodic or temporary limited use of the residential or nonresidential space of the building for activities that make the project more financially viable and do not harm the use of the project as housing for families of limited income.

subsection.text: There is a Radon and Asbestos Abatement Pilot Program.
The Department shall:

paragraph.text: operate the Radon and Asbestos Abatement Pilot Program; and
make loans for rehabilitation projects for radon and asbestos abatement.

subsection.text: The terms of loans shall meet the requirements under §§ 4-917 through 4-919 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: To qualify for a loan, an applicant shall:

subparagraph.text: own a building in need of radon or asbestos abatement:

sub-subparagraph.text: that is otherwise structurally sound; or
for which the applicant provides a commitment from a lender to finance improvements to make the building structurally sound; and

subparagraph.text: make a proposal to the Department for treatment that complies with the requirements and procedures of the Department of the Environment for radon or asbestos abatement.

paragraph.text: In addition to the requirements in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the applicant shall:

subparagraph.text: live in the building and be a family of limited income;
agree to rent at least two-thirds of the dwellings in the building to families of limited income; or
agree to provide congregate or group housing or temporary shelters to families of limited income.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement of material fact, including an overstatement or understatement of financial condition, to influence the action of the Department on a grant or loan or an application for a grant or loan under this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.
If a borrower violates this section, the Department may immediately accelerate the loan, whether or not a criminal prosecution has begun and regardless of the status of the prosecution.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Fund” means the Neighborhood Housing Services Fund.
“Neighborhood corporation” means a neighborhood housing services corporation established in connection with the Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation.

paragraph.text: “Operating budget” means the money necessary to operate a neighborhood corporation, including money to pay:

subparagraph.text: administrative, technical, legal, or other expenses; and
expenses incurred by an umbrella corporation in operating programs.

paragraph.text: “Operating budget” does not include money allocated to revolving or other loan funds.

subsection.text: “Program” means a program that a neighborhood corporation establishes and supervises to achieve its goals and to provide services within a specific neighborhood.
“Umbrella corporation” means a neighborhood corporation that establishes and supervises at least two programs.
There is a Neighborhood Housing Services Fund.
The Department shall administer the Fund.

section.text: The Department may adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: To be eligible for a grant under this subtitle, a neighborhood corporation or umbrella corporation shall:

paragraph.text: submit a timely application in the form that the Secretary prescribes;
create a board of directors composed of:

subparagraph.text: a member of the General Assembly;
neighborhood residents;
representatives of local financial institutions; and
representatives of local political subdivisions, if not inconsistent with local law;

paragraph.text: be authorized to establish and administer a revolving loan fund by lending money at flexible rates and terms to neighborhood homeowners who cannot obtain mortgage financing on reasonable terms through normal lending channels to preserve or revitalize neighborhoods and encourage homeownership; and

be authorized to establish and administer, in cooperation with appropriate officials of the political subdivision, a housing program to bring neighborhood dwellings to acceptable levels of health and safety.

subsection.text: The Secretary or the Secretary’s designee shall be a voting member of each neighborhood corporation receiving grants from the Department.
An application for a grant under subsection (a)(1) of this section shall contain:

paragraph.text: a description of the boundaries of the area that the neighborhood corporation or Program serves;
certification that the applicant is registered with the Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation;
certification of incorporation under State law;
certification of receipt of a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service that the applicant is exempt from federal income taxation;

certification that the portion of the applicant’s annual operating budget that will not be covered by the grant sought has been provided exclusively from political subdivisions or private sources; and
any other information that the Secretary requires.
Each eligible neighborhood corporation may apply for a grant in an amount up to $50,000 that does not exceed one-third of its annual operating budget.
Each umbrella corporation may apply for a grant for each program under its supervision in an amount up to $50,000 that does not exceed one-third of the annual operating budget of the program.

subsection.text: If the amount requested by eligible applicants in a fiscal year exceeds the amount of the Fund, the Secretary shall reduce each grant pro rata so that the Fund amount appropriated for that fiscal year is not exceeded.

The Department shall award operating assistance grants to nonprofit organizations to increase their capacity to participate in housing projects and activities authorized by the programs that are financed through the Homeownership Programs Fund under § 4-502 of this title, the Rental Housing Programs Fund under § 4-504 of this title, the Special Loan Programs Fund under § 4-505 of this title, or otherwise financed totally or partly by the Department.

To be eligible for an operating assistance grant under this section, a nonprofit organization must have limited expertise or no recent experience participating in projects or activities financed wholly or partly by the Department.

A nonprofit organization may receive a grant or grants under this section for up to 3 years to increase its capacity to participate in each of the housing development areas of rental housing programs, homeownership programs, and special loan programs.
A grant under this section may be for a term of up to 3 years if the Department finds that:

paragraph.text: the performance of the nonprofit organization in the prior year was acceptable; and
money is appropriated and available to pay the grant.

subsection.text: The Department shall award operating assistance grants to nonprofit organizations to further the production or rehabilitation of limited income housing by those organizations or by individuals they help.
A nonprofit organization is eligible for a grant if it meets the performance and other standards that the Department sets and:

paragraph.text: makes an application that:

subparagraph.text: describes the housing project;
includes evidence of acceptable performance in the prior year, if the nonprofit organization received a grant in the prior year; and
is acceptable to the Department;

paragraph.text: has helped individuals to apply for loans from the Department; or
was responsible for originating applications, as certified by a political subdivision approved by the Department.

section.text: A nonprofit organization may use an operating assistance grant for predevelopment, operating, and overhead costs, including:

paragraph.text: staff costs;
organizational costs; and
for a grant under § 4-1102 of this subtitle, costs relating to applying for loans or helping individuals to apply for loans.

subsection.text: Operating assistance grants under this subtitle may not exceed the amounts that the Department sets.
During a fiscal year, all operating assistance grants under this subtitle shall be made from:

paragraph.text: up to 1% of the total amount of budgeted money in the Homeownership Programs Fund under § 4-502 of this title, the Rental Housing Programs Fund under § 4-504 of this title, and the Special Loan Programs Fund under § 4-505 of this title; and
money appropriated from any other source.

section.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Fund” means the Partnership Rental Housing Fund.
“Household of lower income” means a household that qualifies under § 4-1206 of this subtitle.
“Housing authority” means a housing authority authorized under Division II of this article.
“Partnership project” means an undertaking that the Program finances to acquire, construct, reconstruct, renovate, or rehabilitate a building or improvement, or a part of a building or improvement.

paragraph.text: “Partnership rental housing” means rental housing financed under this subtitle.
“Partnership rental housing” includes apartments, condominium units, cooperatives, town houses, town homes, single room occupancy and shared living unit facilities, and single-family homes.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Partnership Rental Housing Program.

section.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: there is a shortage of decent, safe, and sanitary rental housing for households of lower income;
the private sector often cannot develop, improve, operate, and maintain housing for households of lower income; and

to address this shortage, a partnership is needed among the State, political subdivisions, housing authorities, the private sector, and households of lower income to develop, operate, and maintain housing for households of lower income.

section.text: There is a Partnership Rental Housing Program.
The purposes of the Program are to:

paragraph.text: provide decent, safe, and sanitary rental housing for households of lower income;
provide financial assistance to political subdivisions or housing authorities to acquire, construct, reconstruct, renovate, or rehabilitate rental housing affordable to households of lower income;

stimulate the development and ownership of rental housing for households of lower income by political subdivisions, housing authorities, or partnerships that include political subdivisions or housing authorities;
provide financial assistance to private sector entities to acquire, construct, reconstruct, renovate, or rehabilitate housing units:

subparagraph.text: for sale to political subdivisions, housing authorities, or partnerships that include political subdivisions or housing authorities, as affordable rental housing for households of lower income; or
for occupancy by households of lower income that include one or more individuals with disabilities or special needs;

paragraph.text: promote affordable housing programs and increased contributions to the production of affordable rental housing by political subdivisions, housing authorities, and the private sector, including for profit and nonprofit entities;
encourage households of lower income that live in partnership rental housing to contribute actively to the operation or maintenance of the housing or the community;
finance rental housing that is:

subparagraph.text: to be occupied by households of lower income;
to be owned by political subdivisions or housing authorities or partnerships that include political subdivisions or housing authorities; and
expected to be financially self-sufficient, without further governmental financing for maintenance, renovation, or operating subsidies; and

paragraph.text: encourage the private sector to provide rental housing for households of lower income that include one or more individuals with disabilities or special needs.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Program;
adopt policies and procedures that encourage partnership rental housing throughout the State; and

adopt regulations to carry out the Program, including regulations that specify criteria for local contributions to the cost of partnership projects undertaken by a political subdivision or housing authority.

subsection.text: The Department may establish:

paragraph.text: maximum limits for financing that it will provide to:

subparagraph.text: individual partnership rental housing units;
any one partnership project; or
any political subdivision or housing authority;

paragraph.text: a process for approving financing for partnership projects that encourages a broad geographic distribution of money; and
the time that a household may occupy the partnership rental housing after the annual income of the household exceeds the continuing occupancy income limits for households of lower income.

section.text: A household qualifies as a household of lower income:

paragraph.text: for initial occupancy, if the gross annual income of the household does not exceed:

subparagraph.text: 50% of the statewide median income for a household of like size; or

a lower income level that the Secretary establishes for a particular partnership project or for a unit of partnership rental housing to be occupied by one or more individuals with disabilities or special needs; and

paragraph.text: for continuing occupancy, if the gross annual income for the household does not exceed the greater of:

subparagraph.text: an income level that the Secretary establishes; and
an applicable federal requirement.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the Department may approve an application for a proposed partnership project only if:

paragraph.text: the application is authorized by the chief elected official of the political subdivision or, if there is no chief elected official, by the governing body of the political subdivision in which the project is located;
the political subdivision or housing authority:

subparagraph.text: contributes from nonstate sources the land for the partnership rental housing;
funds the part of the acquisition cost of the property that is attributable to the value of the land; or
makes a contribution under § 4-1208(d)(2) of this subtitle that equals or exceeds the value of the land;

paragraph.text: the political subdivision or housing authority is to have an ownership interest in the partnership project or in the rental units financed by the Program and sold to the political subdivision or housing authority or to a partnership that includes the political subdivision or housing authority;
the political subdivision or housing authority directly or indirectly manages the partnership project;
the rental units financed by the Program are to be occupied on completion of the acquisition, construction, reconstruction, renovation, or rehabilitation by households of lower income;

the households of lower income occupying the partnership project or the part financed by the Program are required to contribute services to enhance or maintain the partnership project or the community in a way that the political subdivision or housing authority accepts; and
it is reasonable to anticipate that:

subparagraph.text: more State subsidies will not be needed for long-term occupancy by households of lower income; and

rental income, including any contribution to allow for more affordable rents under § 4-1208(d) of this subtitle, will be enough to pay the operating costs of the partnership project and to build an adequate reserve for the long-term maintenance and renovation of the partnership project.

subsection.text: The rental units financed by the Program may include, as among those that must be occupied by households of lower income, rental units restricted for occupancy to meet other federal or State occupancy requirements.

The Department may approve the use of partnership rental housing funds for a unit of partnership rental housing that is not owned in whole or in part by a political subdivision or housing authority if:

paragraph.text: the unit will be occupied by a household of lower income that includes one or more individuals with disabilities or special needs; and

the project in which the unit is located complies with the requirements of the other State housing programs financing the project, if any, including requirements for local support or local contribution.

subsection.text: A political subdivision or housing authority may participate in the Program and do all things necessary or convenient to its participation, including:

paragraph.text: developing, acquiring, improving, owning, operating, and managing rental housing;
borrowing money; and
mortgaging, pledging, and granting a security interest in real or personal property related to a particular partnership project.

subsection.text: The Department may not require a political subdivision or housing authority to repay money made available under the Program, unless the political subdivision or housing authority:

paragraph.text: sells the partnership project; or
fails to operate the partnership project for the benefit of households of lower income in accordance with agreements between the Department and the political subdivision or housing authority.

subsection.text: The Department shall secure the obligations of the political subdivision, housing authority, or private sector entity by using a mortgage, deed of trust, or other security device that the Department accepts on the property or on revenues derived from the property.

paragraph.text: To allow for more affordable rents, a political subdivision or housing authority may contribute local money, including locally administered federal money or federal rental assistance.
The contributions of political subdivisions or housing authorities under § 4-1207(a)(2)(iii) of this subtitle may include the costs of:

subparagraph.text: necessary studies, surveys, tests, plans, and specifications;
architectural, design, engineering, and other special services;
site preparation;
indemnity and surety bonds and premiums on title and hazard insurance; and
other costs of development.

subsection.text: To participate in the Program and to receive loans, a political subdivision or housing authority may not be required to pledge its full faith and credit.
For rental housing financed from the Fund and owned or managed by a housing authority, this subtitle supersedes:

paragraph.text: §§ 12-401, 12-402, and 12-405 of this article; and
all other restrictions on tenant income under Division II of this article.
A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in a document required to be given to the Department in connection with the Program.
A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report to influence the action of the Department in connection with the Program.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Program” means the Radium Grant Program.
There is a Radium Grant Program.
The purpose of the Program is to provide financial assistance to residential well owners who incur the cost of adding a water treatment system to remove radium or gross alpha from well water.
A county may participate in the Program.

subsection.text: A county that participates in the Program shall process grant applications and award grants to residential well owners in accordance with this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Department may award a grant under the Program only to a residential well owner who resides in a county that participates in the Program.
The Department shall award a grant equal to the grant awarded by the county.

section.text: A residential well owner is eligible for a grant under this subtitle if the residential well owner:

paragraph.text: tests a well and finds that it contains radium or gross alpha levels above the levels recommended by the federal Environmental Protection Agency;
installs a water treatment system to remove excess levels of radium or gross alpha from well water; and
does not earn more than 110% of the statewide or Washington, D.C. Metropolitan statistical area median income.

subsection.text: The Department shall establish for participating counties a sliding scale formula, based on income, under which residential well owners with lower incomes are eligible for larger grants and those with higher incomes are eligible for smaller grants.
The combined county and State grants shall equal at least 10% but not more than 25% of the cost of the water treatment system that the residential well owner installs.

section.text: The Department may adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.
In this subtitle, “programs” means rental assistance programs other than the Rental Allowance Program established under § 4–1403 of this subtitle.
There are the Rental Allowance Program and other programs in the Department.

subsection.text: The Department shall administer the Rental Allowance Program to assist low–income households that are homeless or at risk of being homeless by providing housing assistance payments to or on behalf of eligible households.
The Secretary shall establish:

paragraph.text: income limits for eligibility of low–income households not exceeding 30% of the State or area median income, whichever is higher; and
minimum standards for eligible dwelling units.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall establish the amount of payments made through the Rental Allowance Program, taking into account factors identified in § 4–1405(d) of this subtitle.
Eligible uses of payments may include rent, security deposits, utilities, and other housing–related expenses.

The Department may administer the Rental Allowance Program by providing monthly housing assistance payments to or on behalf of eligible households directly or through political subdivisions, their local housing agencies or departments, or nonprofit organizations.
Funds appropriated to serve low–income households through the Rental Allowance Program may not be used for other programs authorized under this subtitle.
The Department may adopt regulations to carry out the Rental Allowance Program, including time frames for assistance and other criteria the Secretary considers appropriate.

section.text: The Department may establish and administer programs, including programs to assist households that:

paragraph.text: are homeless or at risk of homelessness;
include an individual with a disability or special need;
have been displaced or otherwise impacted by disaster; or
have a critical or emergency housing need.

subsection.text: The Department may administer the programs by providing monthly housing assistance payments to or on behalf of eligible households directly or through political subdivisions, their local housing agencies or departments, or nonprofit organizations.
In establishing the programs, the Department shall consult with, as appropriate:

paragraph.text: the Department of Human Resources;
the Department of Disabilities; or
any other unit of State or local government.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall establish criteria for the programs, including:

paragraph.text: income limits for eligibility of households;
time frames for assistance;
monthly assistance amounts;
standards for eligible dwelling units, including types of units, inspection standards, and rent limits;
eligible uses of assistance payments which may include security deposits, utilities, and other housing related expenses; and
any other criteria the Secretary considers appropriate.

subsection.text: In establishing the program criteria, the Secretary may consider factors that include:

paragraph.text: household size and expected average income;
regional variations throughout the State;
typical housing costs and expenses;
relevant standards and definitions established for State and federal housing programs;
housing needs of eligible households and the expected duration of the housing needs; and
equitable distribution of funds statewide.

subsection.text: The Secretary may establish different criteria for different programs.

section.text: The Department may adopt regulations to carry out the programs.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Development costs” means costs incurred to construct or rehabilitate a project.
“Development costs” includes the costs of:

subparagraph.text: necessary studies, surveys, plans, or specifications;
architectural, engineering, or other specialized services;
the acquisition of land or improvements;
site preparation or development;
construction, reconstruction, rehabilitation, ancillary demolition, lot consolidation, or improvement;
acquisition of necessary machinery, equipment, or furnishings;
the initial occupancy expenses of the project;
indemnity bonds, surety bonds, or insurance premiums; and
other fees or relocation expenses.

subsection.text: “Family of lower income” means a family or individual whose income:

paragraph.text: does not exceed the upper income limits that the Secretary establishes under § 4-1505 of this subtitle; and
is lower than the income limits established for families of limited income as provided in § 4-212 of this title.

subsection.text: “Fund” means the Rental Housing Programs Fund under Subtitle 5 of this title.
“Office or other commercial space conversion” means the conversion to rental housing of a building that:

paragraph.text: is in a sustainable community as defined in § 6–301 of this article;
was built more than 30 years before an application is submitted to the Department to finance the conversion;
consists of at least two floors at or above ground level; and
was last used as office or other commercial space.
“Operating costs” means a cost that a sponsor of a completed project incurs that is necessary to maintain or operate a project.
“Operating costs” includes payments of principal and interest on a loan to cover development costs.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Rental Housing Production Program.
“Program loan” means a loan that the Department makes under this subtitle.
“Project” means a rental housing production project that meets the qualifications under § 4-1504 of this subtitle.
“Sponsor” means the Department, a political subdivision, or a person that applies for a Program loan.

section.text: There is a Rental Housing Production Program.

subsection.text: In this section, “lot consolidation” means acquisition of real property adjacent to, and to be included in, a project.
The purposes of the Program are to:

paragraph.text: increase the supply of decent, safe, and sanitary rental housing for occupancy by families of lower income;

provide financial assistance for acquisition, construction, or rehabilitation of rental housing, including demolition and lot consolidation so that families of lower income can afford the rental housing;
encourage political subdivisions to provide assistance in producing rental housing that families of lower income can afford; and
revitalize sustainable communities, as defined in § 6–301 of this article, through office or other commercial space conversion.

subsection.text: To qualify under this subtitle, a project must be:

paragraph.text: an office or other commercial space conversion; or

an undertaking to acquire, construct, or rehabilitate buildings and improvements or parts of them with at least a minimum number of dwelling units restricted for occupancy by families of lower income for at least the greater of 15 years and the number of years required by applicable federal law.

subsection.text: A project may include:

paragraph.text: a single room occupancy facility;
a shared living unit facility;
an emergency or temporary shelter; and

limited equity cooperative housing as defined in § 143(k)(9)(C) of the Internal Revenue Code and regulations that the Internal Revenue Service adopts under § 143(k)(9)(C) of the Internal Revenue Code if, when shares are sold or transferred, the occupancy requirements under this section are satisfied.

subsection.text: The number of dwelling units restricted under subsection (a)(2) of this section shall be at least the greatest of:

paragraph.text: the number that bears the same ratio to the whole number of dwelling units in the undertaking as the amount of the Program loan for the project bears to the whole financing of the undertaking;
the number of dwelling units chosen by the sponsor to satisfy federal occupancy requirements if the project receives federal low income housing tax credits; and

the number of dwelling units required for community development projects under § 4-217(b)(1)(ii) of this title or the number of dwelling units that the issuer of the bonds chooses, whichever is greater, if a part of the cost of the project is financed with government issued federally tax-exempt revenue bonds.

subsection.text: Dwelling units restricted for occupancy to meet other federal or State occupancy requirements may be counted toward the minimum number required under this section.
The Secretary shall establish income limits for a family of lower income by considering factors that include:

paragraph.text: the total amount of family income available for housing;
the size of the family;
the cost and condition of available housing;
the ability of the family to compete successfully in the conventional private housing market; and
relevant standards and definitions of federal housing programs.
The income limits may vary for different areas or regions of the State.
A limit of general applicability may be supplemented by a lower limit for a particular project.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle or any other law, the Department may:

paragraph.text: make and participate in making Program loans to sponsors for:

subparagraph.text: development costs related to the construction or rehabilitation of a project; and
the acquisition of completed projects;

paragraph.text: own or lease a project or the land for a project during the construction or rehabilitation of the project and sell, assign, or transfer a completed project without public bidding or public sale to a sponsor on terms and conditions that make economically feasible rental housing available for families of lower income or from office or other commercial space conversions;
own, lease, construct, or rehabilitate a project or the land for a project and may at anytime after the completion of the project transfer the project or the land to an eligible sponsor;
limit the return on equity allowed to sponsors or enter into equity participation agreements with sponsors; or

establish income ranges and percentages of each income range to be served by a project, except as provided in subsection (c) of this section and within the limits established for families of lower income.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Program;
adopt policies to ensure that rental housing is made available to families of lower income with the assistance of political subdivisions, except as provided in subsection (c) of this section;
attach such specific terms to any purchase, sale, or lease of a project or land for a project as may be necessary to carry out the purposes of the Program;

develop procedures for monitoring the occupancy of the rental units produced under the Program by families of lower income to ensure that the rental units receiving financial assistance under the Program are occupied by families of lower income, except as provided in subsection (c) of this section; and
comply with the requirements of local laws applicable to any particular project.

subsection.text: Subsections (a)(5) and (b)(2) and (4) do not apply to office or other commercial space conversions.
The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out the Program.
By regulation, the Department may establish:

paragraph.text: standards of eligibility for sponsors;
limitations on the return on investment allowed to sponsors;
requirements for the number of bedrooms in a project for each income range;
terms, fees, and charges of Program loans;
a process to select projects that ensures a broad geographic distribution of money; and
incentives for nonprofit sponsors to participate in the Program, including:

subparagraph.text: reserving part of the Fund for a period of time for Program loans to nonprofit sponsors; and
allowing advance payment to nonprofit sponsors for development costs, including architects’, engineers’, and attorneys’ fees.

subsection.text: The Department may approve an application for a project only if the political subdivision in which the project is to be situated has:

paragraph.text: approved the project; and

subparagraph.text: contributed to reducing the development costs or operating costs; or
otherwise supported the project.

subsection.text: In reviewing an application for a Program loan, the Department shall consider:

paragraph.text: the economic feasibility of the project;
the contribution of the political subdivision for the project in relation to the ability of the political subdivision to contribute; and
other relevant factors.
A Program loan may be secured by a mortgage lien.
A lien under this subsection may:

subparagraph.text: be subordinate to other mortgage liens; and
include terms the Department considers necessary to make the rental housing affordable to families of lower income, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: deferred payment of principal and interest; and
interest rates as low as 0%.

subsection.text: A Program loan may be used for:

paragraph.text: capital assistance to finance all or part of the development costs of a project if all or part of the Program loan is secured by a mortgage lien; or

operating assistance to reduce the operating costs of a project by depositing the proceeds of the Program loan in an interest bearing account that is under the control of the Department and is used to pay the operating costs, including the principal and interest when due on any prior mortgage loan securing the project.

subsection.text: To facilitate repayment of the Program loan and achieve the purposes of the Program, the Department may modify:

paragraph.text: the interest rate;
the time or amount of payment; or
any other term of the Program loan.

section.text: If a rental housing facility is converted to limited equity cooperative housing with the help of a Program loan, a tenant may not be required to vacate the premises because the tenant does not elect to become a stockholder in the corporation owning the limited equity cooperative housing.

paragraph.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in a document required to be submitted to the Department under an agreement relating to a Program loan.

A loan applicant may not knowingly make or cause a false statement or report to be made to influence the action of the Department on a Program loan application or to influence action of the Department affecting a Program loan already made.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Covered county” means:

paragraph.text: a county that has adopted home rule powers under Article XI-F of the Maryland Constitution; or
Anne Arundel County, Calvert County, Frederick County, Howard County, or Washington County.

subsection.text: “Family of low or moderate income” means a family or individual that a covered county determines cannot afford a price or rent sufficient to induce private enterprise in the covered county to build enough adequate, safe, and sanitary housing without the assistance of a program.
“Program” means a residential mortgage program under this subtitle.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: in many areas of covered counties, including areas that contain presently stable neighborhoods and middle class residential housing, families of low or moderate income cannot purchase, rehabilitate, or maintain decent, safe, and sanitary housing, and so do not have an opportunity for home ownership directly or through a condominium or cooperative;
the inability of families of low or moderate income under item (1) of this subsection is the result of continuing increases in:

subparagraph.text: the cost of construction or rehabilitation;
county taxes;
heating and electricity expenses;
maintenance and repair expenses;
inflation;
the cost of land;
the cost of energy conservation; and
borrowing costs, including interest;

paragraph.text: the inability of families of low or moderate income to purchase and hold housing in covered counties results in the decline of new housing, the decay of existing housing and neighborhoods, and increased costs for welfare, police, and fire protection;

the decline in new housing construction and the decay of existing housing have produced a critical shortage of adequate housing, harming the economy of covered counties and the well-being of residents;
private enterprise cannot construct or rehabilitate adequate housing for families of low or moderate income without the assistance of a program; and

forcing families of low or moderate income to live in substandard housing is undesirable because it decreases the interest of the families in their communities and the maintenance of their property and their neighborhoods.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: it will be hard for many residents in covered counties to find decent, safe, and sanitary housing unless housing is constructed or rehabilitated;

unless the supply of housing and the ability of families of low or moderate income to get mortgage financing are increased significantly and expeditiously, many residents of covered counties may have to live in unsanitary, overcrowded, or unsafe conditions to the detriment of the health, welfare, and well-being of these individuals and of the whole community of which they are a part; and
increasing the housing supply in covered counties and the ability of families of low or moderate income to get mortgage financing will:

subparagraph.text: help in the clearance, replanning, development of, and redevelopment of blighted areas;
reduce the critical shortage of adequate housing; and
greatly enhance the maintenance and use of existing housing and neighborhoods.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: a major cause of the housing crisis is a lack of:

subparagraph.text: money that can be borrowed at a cost low enough to enable families of low or moderate income to afford to own and maintain decent, safe, and sanitary housing; and
money with which private mortgage lenders can finance housing; and

paragraph.text: the lack of money has frustrated the maintenance, sale, and purchase of existing housing in covered counties.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that covered counties have a basic public interest in:

paragraph.text: providing a supplemental source of single-family residential mortgage money for families of low or moderate income at a cost lower than otherwise prevailing for residential mortgages; and
stimulating a steady flow of money for residential housing for families of low or moderate income and for low and middle class residential housing to help maintain:

subparagraph.text: a well-balanced society;
existing housing;
established neighborhoods; and
a sound tax base.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that the power given by this subtitle and the spending of public money as needed to carry out a program serve a public purpose, and this subtitle is in the public interest.

section.text: The purposes of this subtitle are to:

paragraph.text: help remedy the conditions described in § 4-1602 of this subtitle;
make residential mortgage loans available to families of low or moderate income at borrowing costs lower than those otherwise prevailing for residential mortgages;
help reduce the shortage of adequate housing; and
help maintain housing and neighborhoods.

subsection.text: To accomplish the purpose of this subtitle and notwithstanding any other law, a covered county may borrow money by issuing revenue bonds, notes, or other evidences of obligation.
Money under subsection (a) of this section shall be made available for residential mortgage loans to families of low or moderate income, only through mortgage lending institutions by:

paragraph.text: forward commitment mortgage purchase;
existing mortgage purchase;
loans to lenders;
revolving mortgage fund; or
any other means that the legislative body of the covered county considers appropriate.

section.text: A covered county may collect from borrowers in a program the charges that the legislative body of the covered county considers proper for:

paragraph.text: loan processing;
loan administration;
mortgage insurance; and
other costs and expenses of the program.

subsection.text: The legislative body of a covered county that undertakes a program shall adopt an ordinance or resolution that specifies:

paragraph.text: the proposed program;
the amount of bonds to be issued;
the interest rate or rates that the bonds will bear or the method to determine the rate or rates; and
other provisions consistent with this subtitle that the legislative body considers appropriate to finance mortgage loans.

subsection.text: An ordinance or resolution that authorizes the issuance of bonds shall include findings about:

paragraph.text: the appropriate ranges of income of families of low or moderate income;
the need for the financing that is allowed under this subtitle;
the types of housing available and needed in the covered county; and
other factors that the legislative body of the covered county finds appropriate to establish a program.

subsection.text: A finding by the legislative body of a covered county about the qualification of an individual or family as a family of low or moderate income, or about any other matter connected with a program is conclusive in a suit, action, or proceeding that involves the validity or enforceability of a bond issued under this subtitle or the security for the bond.
The legislative body of a covered county that issues bonds under this subtitle shall determine:

paragraph.text: the time or times when interest is to be paid on the bonds;
the time or times when the bonds are to be executed, issued, and delivered;
the form, denomination, and tenor of the bonds;
the time or times when the principal of the bonds is to be paid, which may not be more than 40 years after the bonds are issued; and
the place or places where the bonds are to be paid.

subsection.text: The bonds may be secured by:

paragraph.text: a pledge of mortgages or notes secured by deeds of trust on any type of interest in real or other property, including the real property or other interests held by stock cooperatives or condominiums and their unit owners;
servicing agreements;
condemnation proceeds;
private, governmental, or other mortgage insurance proceeds;
casualty or special hazard insurance proceeds; or
any other security that the legislative body of the covered county finds appropriate.

subsection.text: The bonds may provide that, at the option of the covered county, the bonds or any one of them may be called for redemption before maturity, at a price and under the terms and conditions that the legislative body of the covered county fixed before issuing the bonds.
The following are exempt at all times from taxation of every kind and nature whatsoever by the State or a county:

paragraph.text: the principal of a bond;
the transfer of, interest payable on, or income derived from a bond; and
profit made by the sale or transfer of a bond.

subsection.text: A bond issued under this subtitle is a negotiable instrument.
A covered county may:

paragraph.text: issue its bonds in coupon form; or
provide for registration of the bonds as to principal alone or principal and interest.
The bonds shall be signed by a commissioner or other chief executive officer of the covered county.
The seal of the covered county shall be affixed to the bond and attested to by the clerk or the officer exercising the functions of a clerk.
An officer’s signature or countersignature that appears on bonds or coupons is valid even if the officer leaves office before delivery of the bonds.
The bonds shall be sold at public or private sale on the terms that the legislative body of the covered county sets.
The bonds are not subject to Article 31, §§ 9, 10, and 11 of the Code.
The bonds and the interest on them shall be limited obligations of the covered county.
The principal and interest on the bonds shall be payable only from:

subparagraph.text: the revenue derived from:

sub-subparagraph.text: interest;
mortgage insurance;
casualty or special hazard insurance or other insurance proceeds; or
condemnation proceeds;

subparagraph.text: other revenue derived from mortgage loans or property securing the loans; or
other payments or revenues derived from or relating to the making of the loans.

paragraph.text: The bonds or coupons issued under this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: are not an indebtedness or a charge against the general credit or taxing powers of the issuing county within the meaning of a constitution, county code provision, or statutory limit; and
are not and do not give rise to a monetary liability of the issuing county.

paragraph.text: On the advice of counsel, the face of each bond may plainly state that the bond was issued under this subtitle and is not an indebtedness to which the faith and credit of the county is pledged.

subsection.text: Money received from bonds issued under this subtitle shall be applied solely:

paragraph.text: to make money available through mortgage lending institutions only for residential mortgage loans to families of low or moderate income;
to establish reserves;
to pay the necessary expenses of financing; or
to advance the payment of interest on the bonds during the first 3 years after the date of the bonds.

subsection.text: A covered county may issue new bonds to pay outstanding bonds in accordance with procedures of this subtitle and Article 31, § 24 of the Code.
