New bonds shall be secured to the same extent and shall have the same source of payment as the bonds refunded.

A program may provide for loan agreements, security agreements, loan servicing agreements, forms of mortgages, notes and deeds of trust, and other security, documents, agreements, provisions, and other matters as the covered county may find appropriate to implement the financing of the program.
A transaction under this subtitle is not a capital project within the meaning of a charter or statutory provision.
A transaction under this subtitle shall be authorized by ordinance or resolution without a referendum or other procedure not applicable to all ordinances or resolutions enacted in the covered county.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Family of limited income” means a family or individual that qualifies under § 4-1706 of this subtitle.

“Owner-builder” means an individual or family that provides all, or a substantial amount, as the Department determines, of the labor to build a dwelling that will be the principal residence of the individual or family.
“Program” means the Self-Help Homeownership Technical Assistance Program.

“Project” means six or more dwellings near one another that are built or rehabilitated by owner-builders or self-help rehabilitators who use self-help methods and work as a team on each other’s dwellings.

“Self-help rehabilitator” means an individual or family that provides all, or a substantial amount, as the Department determines, of the labor to rehabilitate, renovate, or improve the principal residence of the individual or family.
“Technical assistance grant” means a grant under the Program.

section.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: homeownership is a stabilizing factor for communities and families and is the best way for families of limited income to build equity and move out of poverty;
homeownership has become less affordable over time because incomes have not kept pace with the rising costs of homeownership;
self-help housing helps families of limited income to become homeowners, increasing their financial stability;
families working together in groups to build their homes help to create stronger communities; and

there have been three successful federally financed self-help programs in the State, and modeling a State self-help ownership program on a well-tested federal program will increase homeownership opportunities for families of limited income across the State.

section.text: There is a Self-Help Homeownership Technical Assistance Program.
The purpose of the Program is to make technical assistance grants to expand:

paragraph.text: the production of decent and affordable housing for families of limited income through self-help in rehabilitation and construction;
homeownership opportunities for those who would not have these opportunities without the cost savings achieved by self-help; and
self-reliance, pride of ownership, and sense of community for participants.

section.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Program;
establish guidelines to determine eligibility of applicants for technical assistance grants; and
adopt regulations to carry out the Program.

subsection.text: A family or individual qualifies as a family of limited income if the income of the family or individual does not exceed the upper income limit that the Secretary establishes.
Factors that the Secretary shall consider in setting the upper income limit under subsection (a) of this section include:

paragraph.text: the total amount of family or individual income deemed available for housing;
the size of the family;
the ability of the family or individual to compete successfully in the private housing market;
the cost and condition of available housing; and
standards and definitions under related federal and State housing programs.

section.text: The Department may establish standards to determine eligibility for a technical assistance grant, which may include:

paragraph.text: the number of families of limited income that the requested grant will serve;
the extent to which the applicant will use federal, State, and local programs and resources in the project;
the organizational ability of the applicant to carry out the project;
the feasibility of the project;
the cost in self-help housing fund money per unit of the project; and
the extent to which project participants will use self-help labor.

subsection.text: The Department may award a technical assistance grant to a political subdivision or nonprofit organization to help families of limited income that are owner-builders or self-help rehabilitators.
A technical assistance grant under this section shall be used to:

paragraph.text: help, train, and supervise owner-builders and self-help rehabilitators in self-help construction activities and techniques;
help in project development, including:

subparagraph.text: preparing plans for self-help housing;
preparing contracts for professional services;
applying for financing;
packaging applications for assistance;
preparing subdivision maps;
reviewing engineering plans and specifications for construction and rehabilitation projects; and
complying with the requirements of political subdivisions and funding entities; and

paragraph.text: pay the administrative costs of providing technical assistance for the activity that the Department finances.

subsection.text: A technical assistance grant may not be:

paragraph.text: used to purchase land, materials, tools, or construction equipment or to pay for construction costs; or
awarded for a project of fewer than six dwellings.

section.text: The Department may award a technical assistance grant to a political subdivision, public entity, or nonprofit organization to provide owner-builders and self-help rehabilitators with information and technical assistance about any topic that the Department finds will further the purpose of the Program, including:

paragraph.text: cost savings by owner-builders in constructing a principal residence and by self-help rehabilitators in rehabilitating, renovating, or improving a principal residence;
construction materials and methods;
local material sources;
local technical resources;
financing requirements and opportunities;
site acquisition;
insurance and legal requirements;
building and housing codes and standards; and
other available housing alternatives.

subsection.text: The Department may award a technical assistance grant only if the applicant agrees to:

paragraph.text: a budget that states the types and amounts of expenditures that may be made with the grant;
the manner, timing, and conditions for disbursement of money to the grantee;
a timetable to complete each stage of the project and for final project completion; and
terms to ensure compliance with regulations, special conditions imposed by grant approval, and any other terms or conditions that the Department specifies.

subsection.text: The amount of a technical assistance grant may not exceed 20% of the average purchase price, over the last 3 fiscal years for which data are available, of a home:

paragraph.text: financed by a mortgage loan that the Administration purchased under § 4-239 of this title; and
located in the region where the technical assistance grant is to be awarded.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a technical assistance grant recipient shall complete the project within 2 years after the effective date of the grant.
The Department may extend the term of a technical assistance grant because of delays beyond the reasonable control of the recipient.

subsection.text: The Department may require that all or part of a technical assistance grant be repaid when conditions that the Department specifies occur.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Affordable” means that housing costs do not exceed 30% of a household’s income.
“Area median income” means the median household income for the area adjusted for household size as published and annually updated by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.
“Development costs” means costs related to acquisition, site clearance and preparation, relocation, construction, renovation, financing, refinancing, engineering, or architectural plans.
“Fund” means the Workforce Housing Fund.

“Household of low or moderate income” means a household that a qualifying local government determines cannot afford a sales price or rent sufficient to induce private enterprise in the area of the qualifying local government to develop enough adequate and safe housing without the assistance of a program.
“Housing costs” means:

paragraph.text: rent for a rental housing unit; or
mortgage principal and interest, real property taxes, and insurance for a housing unit that is for sale.

subsection.text: “Net proceeds of transfer” means all amounts paid to the original buyer or obligations of the original buyer assumed by a purchaser of a workforce housing unit minus:

paragraph.text: reasonable costs paid by the original buyer;
the combined amount of Program funds and qualifying local government matching funds used to develop the workforce housing unit; and
other liens as permitted by regulation by the Department.

subsection.text: “Priority funding area” has the meaning stated in § 5–7B–02 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
“Program” means the Workforce Housing Grant Program.
“Qualifying local government” means a county or municipal corporation that qualifies for participation in the Program under § 4–1803 of this subtitle.
“Workforce housing” means:

paragraph.text: rental housing that is affordable for a household with an aggregate annual income between 50% and 100% of the area median income; or
homeownership housing that:

subparagraph.text: except as provided in item (ii) of this item, is affordable to a household with an aggregate annual income between 60% and 120% of the area median income; or

in target areas that are recognized by the Secretary for purposes of administering the Maryland Mortgage Program, is affordable to a household with an aggregate annual income between 60% and 150% of the area median income.

subsection.text: There is a Workforce Housing Grant Program.
The Program provides flexible funds to qualifying local governments for workforce housing programs, including programs that finance development costs.
The Program shall be operated with money in the Fund.
A local government qualifies for participation in the Program if:

paragraph.text: the local government has:

subparagraph.text: a 5-year consolidated plan approved by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development; or
a comprehensive plan;

paragraph.text: the plans listed in item (1) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: have a workforce housing element;
assess workforce housing needs; and
contain goals, objectives, and policies to preserve or develop workforce housing; and

paragraph.text: the local government provides a statement to the Department indicating:

subparagraph.text: a desire to participate in the Program; and
a reasonable expectation of the local government’s ability to provide the matching funds required under § 4-1804 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The workforce housing element in the 5-year consolidated plan or the comprehensive plan of a qualifying local government may include:

paragraph.text: preservation and renovation of existing housing stock;
redevelopment of existing residential areas;
streamlined regulatory processes and reduced regulatory fees for construction or renovation;
financial incentives for construction and renovation including local property tax credits;
special zoning regulations for construction and renovation including inclusionary zoning;
efforts to preserve workforce housing stock for subsequent first-time homebuyers and renters;
coordination with neighboring jurisdictions;
coordination with private sector employers; and
leveraging of federal financial assistance.

subsection.text: A qualifying local government shall provide a dollar–for–dollar match for Program funds used to develop workforce housing units under this subtitle.
In determining whether a local government has met the match requirement under subsection (a) of this section, the Department may consider the local government’s:

paragraph.text: costs to administer a program under this subtitle; and
financial commitments to other affordable or workforce housing initiatives.

section.text: The Department shall proportionately distribute the annual appropriation of Program funds as follows:

paragraph.text: if a county is a qualifying local government, and no municipal corporation in the county is a qualifying local government, the Department shall distribute Program funds to the county based on the county’s share of the State population;
if a county is a qualifying local government, and a municipal corporation in the county is also a qualifying local government, the Department shall:

subparagraph.text: determine the county’s proportionate share of Program funds based on the county’s share of the State population; and
from the amount of Program funds determined under item (i) of this item, distribute:

sub-subparagraph.text: to each qualifying local government in the county that is a municipal corporation, an amount of Program funds based on the municipal corporation’s share of the county population; and
to the county, the balance of the county’s share of Program funds; or

paragraph.text: if a county is not a qualifying local government, but a municipal corporation in the county is a qualifying local government, the Department shall:

subparagraph.text: determine the county’s proportionate share of Program funds based on the county’s share of the State population; and

distribute to each qualifying local government in the county that is a municipal corporation, a proportionate share of the amount of Program funds determined under item (i) of this item based on the municipal corporation’s share of the county’s population.

section.text: Before drawing down any Program funds, a qualifying local government shall:

paragraph.text: provide evidence satisfactory to the Department that the Program funds will be matched by the qualifying local government on a dollar-for-dollar basis; and
meet other Program criteria adopted by the Secretary.

section.text: The Department shall redistribute among qualifying local governments the Program funds that have not been drawn down by other local governments within a 2–year period.

subsection.text: A qualifying local government shall use Program funds for development costs associated with a workforce housing development located in a priority funding area in accordance with the 5–year consolidated plan or comprehensive plan of the qualifying local government.
A qualifying local government may request that its program funds or match be expended by the Department through the Department’s existing housing programs.

section.text: With the consent of the Department, in appropriate circumstances, a qualifying local government may extend the income eligibility limits for a workforce housing unit developed with Program funds to include a household of low or moderate income.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall establish annually the maximum amount of Program funds that a qualifying local government may use to develop a workforce housing unit.

The per unit maximum established by the Secretary shall take into account the regional average construction costs applicable to the qualifying local government for a comparable workforce housing unit.
Rental units developed under this subtitle shall remain affordable as workforce housing for a period of at least 25 years.

If an original buyer of a homeownership workforce housing unit developed through the Program transfers title to the unit at any time, the original buyer shall pay to the Department 100% of the combined amount of Program funds and qualifying local government matching funds used to develop the unit.
If an original buyer of a homeownership workforce housing unit developed through the Program transfers title to the unit:

paragraph.text: within 5 years of the date of purchase, the original buyer shall pay the lesser of 20% of the net proceeds of transfer to the Department or a 5% annual return on the Program funds provided for the unit;

during the period that is more than 5 years but less than 15 years from the date of purchase, the original buyer shall pay to the Department the lesser of a percentage of the net proceeds of transfer that begins at 20% and declines by 2% for each subsequent year of ownership or a 5% annual return on the Program funds provided for the unit; and
during the period that is 15 years or more from the date of purchase, the original buyer is not required to pay any portion of the net proceeds of transfer to the Department.

subsection.text: The Department shall distribute to the qualifying local government:

paragraph.text: of the funds paid by the original buyer to the Department under subsection (b) of this section, an amount equal to the matching funds provided by the qualifying local government for the homeownership workforce housing unit; and

of the funds paid by the original buyer to the Department under subsection (c) of this section, a proportionate share based on the amount of matching funds provided by the qualifying local government for the homeownership workforce housing unit.

subsection.text: The Department and the qualifying local governments shall use the funds received under this section to develop workforce housing under the Program.

The contract of sale to the original buyer shall disclose all the requirements for repayment to the Department under this section in the event of a transfer of title, including the combined amount of Program funds and qualifying local government matching funds.

paragraph.text: The amounts owed to the Department in the event of a transfer of title of a homeownership workforce housing unit under this section shall be secured by a recorded lien on the homeownership workforce housing unit.
The lien created under this subsection may be a subordinate lien.
The Department may charge a fee for servicing a lien created under this subsection.

section.text: A qualifying local government shall report annually to the Department on or before January 1 of each year on the use of Program funds.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to carry out the purposes of the Program.
There is a Disaster Relief Housing Program within the Department of Housing and Community Development.

subsection.text: The purpose of the Program is to provide financial assistance in an area covered by a state of emergency declared under § 14–107 of the Public Safety Article or in a federally declared disaster area to rehabilitate or replace a primary residence to:

paragraph.text: a family whose primary residence was damaged or destroyed by the disaster; and
a nonprofit entity that assists a family in rehabilitating and replacing a primary residence destroyed by the disaster.

subsection.text: The Department may continue to provide financial assistance under this subtitle after the expiration of a state of emergency declared under § 14–107 of the Public Safety Article.
The Department may provide financial assistance under the Program utilizing funds from:

paragraph.text: any fund or program under Division I of this article; or
any other source of funds available to the Department.

subsection.text: The Department may provide any type of financial assistance permitted by Division I of this article to recipients under the Program.

In addition to the type of financial assistance allowed under subsection (b) of this section, the Department may provide financial assistance under a buy–down program that reduces the amount a borrower pays on a loan obtained from the private market or from the Department for a defined period of time.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations, guidelines, and eligibility requirements for implementing the Program.
The guidelines and eligibility requirements may be different for each disaster.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall establish income limits for the Program in connection with each disaster.

The eligibility requirements of any State fund or program from which funds are utilized for providing financial assistance, including maximum income limits, may not apply to financial assistance provided to recipients under the Program.
Repayments of financial assistance under the Program shall be paid to the source of funds that was used to provide the financial assistance.
The Department shall issue to the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article:

paragraph.text: a preliminary report 6 months after the Program is initially activated for each disaster; and
a final report on or before 18 months after the Program is initially activated for each disaster.

subsection.text: The reports shall include:

paragraph.text: the amount and type of assistance provided;
the counties in which the assistance was provided; and
the names of any financial institutions that provided assistance under the Program.

subsection.text: There is a Division of Neighborhood Revitalization.
The Division of Neighborhood Revitalization includes the Neighborhood Business Development Program.
The Division of Neighborhood Revitalization shall administer commercial and mixed-use revitalization programs to encourage physical and organizational improvements to business areas.
To carry out commercial and mixed-use revitalization programs, the Division of Neighborhood Revitalization shall administer State and federal grants and loans and other financial assistance to:

paragraph.text: political subdivisions, local public agencies, nonprofit organizations, neighborhood or community organizations, or private parties; or
corporations or foundations whose net earnings are invested to foster, encourage, help, or carry out community assistance activities, projects, or programs.

subsection.text: A commercial or mixed-use revitalization program provides assistance for downtown or business area commercial management, promotion, and revitalization.
Assistance may be in an area such as:

paragraph.text: market surveying, grantsmanship, organization, economic development, design, or similar services; or
facilitating establishment of a commercial district management authority.
The General Assembly finds that the State must have sustainable communities in order to:

subparagraph.text: preserve and protect the State’s natural resources; and
achieve the State’s economic growth, resource protection, and planning policy in § 5–7A–01 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

paragraph.text: The General Assembly finds that sustainable communities are places where public and private investments and partnerships achieve:

subparagraph.text: development of a healthy local economy;
protection and appreciation of historic and cultural resources;
a mix of land uses;
affordable and sustainable housing and job options; and

growth and development practices that protect the environment and conserve air, water, and energy resources, encourage walkability and recreational opportunities, and, where available, create access to transit.

subsection.text: It is the intent of the General Assembly that the community legacy and neighborhood business development programs:

paragraph.text: be used to create, enhance, support, and revitalize sustainable communities across the State; and

be coordinated with other State programs, such as the Sustainable Communities Tax Credit Program established under Title 5A, Subtitle 3 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, in order to maximize the State’s investment in sustainable communities.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Application” means an application to the Secretary that includes a request to:

paragraph.text: designate an area as a sustainable community;
approve a sustainable community plan; or
approve a community legacy project.

subsection.text: “Community development financial institution” has the meaning stated in 12 U.S.C. § 4702.
“Community development organization” means an entity that meets the qualifications of § 6–203 of this subtitle.

“Community legacy agreement” means an agreement between the Department and a sponsor to develop a sustainable community plan or to implement one or more community legacy projects in a designated sustainable community.
“Community legacy project” includes projects to:

paragraph.text: create, improve, or preserve housing opportunities by acquiring, constructing, rehabilitating, or improving new or existing residential properties;
demolish buildings or improvements strategically to enhance the use of land;
create, improve, or preserve commercial or mixed–use development, including an appropriate combination of properties related to business, housing, open–space, and institutional uses;

develop public infrastructure that is incidental to the implementation of a community legacy project, such as streets, parking, public utilities, landscaping, lighting, and improvements to pedestrian and bicycle circulation;
encourage and develop cooperative ownership or control of open space;

develop or create strategies designed to increase investment in existing communities, including outreach activities to attract business, capital, residents, and visitors and the development and maintenance of resources directly related to the development of a sustainable community plan or the implementation of a community legacy project;
engage in landbanking or otherwise acquire or improve vacant buildings or unimproved land;
provide financial assistance for neighborhood intervention projects; or
develop other plans or implement other projects as the Department considers necessary to further the purposes of this subtitle.

subsection.text: “Financial assistance” includes:

paragraph.text: a grant;
a loan;
a reduction in the principal obligation of or rate of interest payable on a loan or portion of a loan;
a prepayment of interest on a subordinate or superior loan or portion of a loan;
an assurance;
a guarantee; or
any other form of credit enhancement.

subsection.text: “Landbanking” means acquiring or holding improved and unimproved property:

paragraph.text: in anticipation of future development of the property; or
to keep the future use of the property and improvements affordable.

subsection.text: “Priority funding area” means an area designated as a priority funding area under § 5–7B–02 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
“Program” means the Community Legacy Program established by this subtitle.
“Smart Growth Subcabinet” means the subcabinet established under § 9–1406 of the State Government Article.
“Sustainable community” means the part of a priority funding area that:

paragraph.text: as determined by the Smart Growth Subcabinet, satisfies the requirements of § 6–205 of this subtitle;
has been designated as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone under Title 5, Subtitle 13 of the Economic Development Article; or
has been designated a transit–oriented development under § 7–101 of the Transportation Article.

subsection.text: “Sustainable community plan” means a plan consisting of one or more community legacy projects or other revitalization projects to prevent or reverse the decline of or disinvestment in a sustainable community through improvements in residential, commercial, or other public or private properties.
There is a Community Legacy Program.
The Department shall administer the Program.
The purposes of the Program are to:

paragraph.text: preserve existing communities as desirable places to live and conduct business to reduce outward pressure for sprawl development; and
provide financial assistance to sponsors or their designees to develop sustainable community plans or community legacy projects.

subsection.text: The Program shall encourage partnerships among the federal government, the State government, political subdivisions, and community development organizations to develop and implement sustainable community plans and community legacy projects.

A sustainable community plan or a community legacy project may be sponsored by a political subdivision, a group of political subdivisions, a community development organization, or a community development financial institution.

section.text: A corporation, foundation, or other legal entity qualifies as a community development organization if:

paragraph.text: its purpose is to improve the physical, economic, or social environment of the area where it operates; and
no part of its net earnings inures to the benefit of a private shareholder or individual holding an interest in that entity.

subsection.text: A sponsor may file one or more applications in accordance with the schedules that the Department establishes.
An application shall set forth:

paragraph.text: a description of one or more sustainable communities where the sponsor proposes to develop a sustainable community plan or to carry out a community legacy project using the standards listed in § 6–205 of this subtitle;
a detailed description of the proposed sustainable community plan or proposed community legacy project;
the amount and type of financial assistance sought;
the ability of the sponsor to carry out the proposed sustainable community plan or community legacy project;

the strength and quality of partnerships created among the federal government, the State government, political subdivisions, community development organizations, and other private organizations to develop the sustainable community plan or carry out the community legacy project, including:

subparagraph.text: financial support;
dedication of staff and resources; and
commitment to and development of local smart growth policies;

paragraph.text: proposed benchmarks for evaluating whether the proposed sustainable community plan or community legacy project results in a desired outcome for a proposed sustainable community, such as:

subparagraph.text: stabilizing it;
reversing its social, economic, or physical decline; or
encouraging growth in it; and

paragraph.text: the process used to seek and receive public input on the proposed sustainable community plan or community legacy project, including the nature and extent of public support or opposition.
The Smart Growth Subcabinet, on the recommendation of the Secretary, may designate an area as a sustainable community.

If the Smart Growth Subcabinet has not acted within 90 days of a recommendation from the Secretary, the Secretary may designate an area as a sustainable community without the approval of the Smart Growth Subcabinet.

subsection.text: The Smart Growth Subcabinet, on the recommendation of the Secretary, may designate an area as a sustainable community if the sponsor demonstrates that past and current trends in homeownership, property values, commercial and residential vacancy, and business or housing investment show a need for reinvestment in the area and if:

paragraph.text: entities in the community, such as local governments, employers, educational institutions, civic organizations, community organizations, or cultural organizations, support the proposed sustainable community plan and have pledged resources to develop or implement it;

the proposed sustainable community plan addresses the need for reinvestment in the area and will enhance the area, and give individuals of different incomes a range of housing options, employment opportunities, and other amenities;
a community in the proposed area is culturally or historically significant;
the proposed area is near a town center or a transportation center;

the proposed sustainable community plan is consistent with and complements other existing or proposed projects for housing, commercial or community development, education, historic preservation, neighborhood revitalization, transportation, or other things significant to the comprehensive enhancement of the community; or
there is a demonstrated need for financing assistance for small businesses, nonprofit organizations, or microenterprises.
To maintain a sustainable community designation:

subparagraph.text: every 5 years a sponsor shall file an updated plan and application with the Department; and
the Secretary shall make designation recommendations for approval by the Smart Growth Subcabinet under § 6–204 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Department shall convene an interagency review team from the agencies of the Smart Growth Subcabinet to:

subparagraph.text: review applications and plans;
provide assistance and guidance to applicants; and
make recommendations to the Secretary.

paragraph.text: The Smart Growth Subcabinet may redesignate an area as a sustainable community taking into consideration the factors in subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: review each application and may request more information from the sponsor;
accept public input on each application;
submit each application to appropriate State units and appropriate members of the Smart Growth Subcabinet;
consider any recommendation a State unit or member of the Smart Growth Subcabinet makes;
consider geographic balance when reviewing applications; and

give priority in awarding financial assistance to applicants that are likely to repay the financial assistance to a community development financial institution or to the Community Legacy Financial Assistance Fund.
The Department may not approve an application unless the political subdivision in which the proposed project is located approves the application by resolution.
If an application affects a sustainable community entirely within a municipal corporation, the approval must come from the municipal corporation rather than the surrounding county.
If an application affects a sustainable community within more than one political subdivision, each political subdivision must approve it by resolution.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall award financial assistance to a sponsor or a sponsor’s designee:

paragraph.text: in the amount and of the type that the Secretary determines; and
under the terms of a community legacy agreement.

subsection.text: The Department and the sponsor shall execute a community legacy agreement.
The sponsor shall comply with the terms of the community legacy agreement and any regulations the Department adopts to carry out this subtitle.
Not more than 15% of the total financial assistance that the Program provides may be used for noncapital expenditures.
The Department may exercise any remedy provided under the community legacy agreement or by law if a sponsor:

paragraph.text: violates any provision of the community legacy agreement; or
ceases to meet the requirements of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Subject to this section, the Department has the powers necessary or desirable to implement the Program.

paragraph.text: The Department may determine the terms and conditions for financial assistance awarded under § 6–206(c) of this subtitle.
Financial assistance may be secured by a mortgage, lien, or security interest that is superior to or subordinate to other mortgages, liens, or security interests.
The Department may establish time limits for the use of financial assistance.
The Department may enforce the terms and conditions of the financial assistance given under this subtitle.
Notwithstanding any other law, if a loan or grant is secured by a first or subordinate mortgage or other lien, the Department may:

subparagraph.text: begin an action to protect or enforce any right given by law, a contract, or other agreement;
foreclose on property;
purchase property at any foreclosure or other sale, or acquire or take possession of the property through conveyance in lieu of foreclosure or otherwise, and convey property after acquiring it;
settle or compromise any debt or obligation owed to the Department;
pay the principal of and interest on any obligation incurred in connection with the property, and dispose of or otherwise deal with the property to protect the interests of the Program; or
release or sell any mortgage, obligation, or property that the Department holds at public or private sale, with or without public bidding.

paragraph.text: The Department may contract with any person, including a private property manager, mortgage servicer, architect, engineer, or other property consultant, or with any governmental unit, for property or services necessary to operate the Program or to implement community legacy projects.
The Department may make agreements with other governmental units to establish partnerships to carry out the Program.

The Department may contract for and accept any grant, contribution, or loan of money, property, or other aid from the federal government and may do all things consistent with this subtitle to qualify for the aid or participate in or administer a federal program.

subsection.text: In connection with loans that it makes, the Department may:

paragraph.text: require and obtain appraisals, credit information, and other pertinent information; and
charge interest.

subsection.text: When it is consistent with the best interests of the State to do so, the Department may consent to the modification of any provision of any loan or other financial assistance.
The purposes of a neighborhood intervention project are to provide financial assistance for:

paragraph.text: buying properties that need rehabilitation and redeveloping the properties through rehabilitation, demolition, reconstruction, or re–use; or
demolishing property improvements and preparing property for revitalization, redevelopment, or re–use.

subsection.text: To be eligible for financial assistance for a neighborhood intervention project, an applicant shall be:

paragraph.text: a political subdivision; or
a community development finance institution.

subsection.text: To be eligible for financial assistance, the applicant must provide evidence at the time of application that:

paragraph.text: the applicant has a legal interest in the property through:

subparagraph.text: ownership of the property;
a contract, option, or other legal right to acquire the property; or
the right to demolish the improvements on the property;

paragraph.text: the applicant intends to revitalize, redevelop, sell, or re–use the property as part of a redevelopment strategy for the property or a redevelopment plan;
the applicant has complied with the requirements of §§ 5A–325 and 5A–326 of the State Finance and Procurement Article and § 13–1112(b) of the Financial Institutions Article;
the financial assistance from the Program is the least amount necessary to complete the project; and
the project meets any other condition that the Department may require under this subtitle.

subsection.text: Unless waived by the Secretary, a neighborhood intervention project shall meet the additional following requirements:

paragraph.text: the project shall be located in a sustainable community and be a part of a sustainable community plan in accordance with §§ 6–204(b)(1) and 6–205 of this subtitle; and

for a project under subsection (a)(2) of this section, the applicant shall agree to repay the financial assistance to the Community Legacy Financial Assistance Fund, up to the amount the applicant receives from:

subparagraph.text: the net proceeds of the sale of the property on which the demolition took place; or
any payment to the applicant relating to the property, including any payment for the costs of demolishing the improvements on the property.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may not allocate annually more than 15% of the Community Legacy Financial Assistance Fund to neighborhood intervention projects.
The Secretary may not award more than $500,000 for any neighborhood intervention project.

The restrictions in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subsection do not apply to projects approved by the Secretary in the case of an emergency or when the project requires urgent approval if the project is funded from the reserve established under § 6–211(h) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The sponsor shall submit to the Department quarterly progress reports on the development of a sustainable community plan or the implementation of a community legacy project.

paragraph.text: The Department shall submit an annual report to the Governor and, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on or before each October 31.
The report shall include:

subparagraph.text: the financial status of the Program for the preceding fiscal year, including the amount and type of financial assistance encumbered and disbursed;
the number of applications received;
the number and location of sustainable communities designated; and
a summary of the quarterly reports submitted by sponsors under subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: In this section, “Fund” means the Community Legacy Financial Assistance Fund.
There is a Community Legacy Financial Assistance Fund.
The Fund shall be used to carry out this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall administer the Fund in accordance with this subtitle.
The State Treasurer shall hold and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing special fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund;
earnings from the investment of money in the Fund;
repayments and prepayments of financial assistance provided by the Program; and
any other money accepted for the benefit of the Fund from any governmental or private source.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other law, the State Treasurer may invest money in the Fund in the same way as money is invested by the State Retirement and Pension System.
In any fiscal year, the Secretary may hold up to 10% of the money in the Fund in reserve for emergency use or urgent projects in accordance with this subtitle.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Development costs” means the costs incurred to construct or rehabilitate a neighborhood business development project.
“Development costs” includes the costs of:

subparagraph.text: necessary studies, surveys, plans, and specifications;
architectural, engineering, or other special services, including flood plain studies, environmental audits, and critical area or wetland assessments;
land and improvements;
site preparation;
construction, reconstruction, and rehabilitation;
machinery, equipment, and furnishings;
essential start–up operating costs, including working capital and initial occupancy expenses;
indemnity and surety bonds and premiums on insurance;
temporary relocation expenses; and
other necessary fees.

subsection.text: “Fund” means the Neighborhood Business Development Fund.
“Microenterprise” means a business with not more than five employees that:

paragraph.text: requires not more than $35,000 in total start–up capital or financial assistance; and
does not have access to the traditional commercial banking sector.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Neighborhood Business Development Program.

paragraph.text: “Project” means a neighborhood business development project that receives financial assistance from the Fund.
“Project” includes a microenterprise project that receives financial assistance from the Fund.

subsection.text: “Small business” means a business that qualifies as a small business under § 6–302 of this subtitle.
“Sustainable community” means the part of a priority funding area that:

paragraph.text: as determined by the Smart Growth Subcabinet, satisfies the requirements of § 6–205 of this title;
has been designated as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone under Title 5, Subtitle 13 of the Economic Development Article; or
has been designated a transit–oriented development under § 7–101 of the Transportation Article.

subsection.text: A business qualifies as a small business if the number of its employees and the amount of its annual receipts do not exceed limits that the Department sets by regulation.
The limits that the Department sets may not be less restrictive than those that the federal Small Business Administration sets.
There is a Neighborhood Business Development Program.
The purposes of the Program are, in sustainable communities, to:

paragraph.text: help develop, redevelop, or expand small businesses and microenterprises;
stimulate investment by the private sector;
invest in revitalization projects for small businesses and microenterprises; and
stimulate political subdivisions to participate in developing and expanding small businesses and microenterprises.

subsection.text: The Program includes:

paragraph.text: the Business Development Program; and
the Capital Access Program.

subsection.text: There is a Business Development Program in the Neighborhood Business Development Program.
The Business Development Program shall provide financial assistance to projects in sustainable communities.

paragraph.text: A small business, nonprofit organization, or microenterprise may apply for financial assistance under the Business Development Program.
The Department shall review each application.

subsection.text: An applicant may qualify for financial assistance for a project in a sustainable community if the application demonstrates that:

paragraph.text: except for a microenterprise project, the project has significant commitments for financing from other private and nonstate public sources that are sufficient to complete the project with the money from the Fund;
the financial assistance from the Fund is the minimum amount necessary to make the project financially feasible;
the project is ready to proceed when it receives financial assistance from the Business Development Program; and
the political subdivision has adopted a resolution, or its authorized designee has delivered a letter to the Business Development Program, that expresses support for the project.

subsection.text: Financial assistance under the Business Development Program may be provided to a small business, nonprofit organization, or microenterprise as:

paragraph.text: a grant;
a loan;
a reduction in the principal obligation of or interest rate on a loan or portion of a loan;
a prepayment of interest on a subordinate or superior loan or portion of a loan;
an assurance;
a guarantee; or
any other form of credit enhancement.

subsection.text: Financial assistance under the Business Development Program shall be on the terms that the Department considers necessary to make the project financially feasible.
Financial assistance under the Business Development Program may be used for:

paragraph.text: a part of the development costs of a project; or
the development costs, working capital, or business expenses of a microenterprise project.

subsection.text: The Department may require that financial assistance under the Business Development Program be secured by a mortgage or other security instrument, which may be subordinate to other security interests.
The Department may modify the interest rate, the time or amount of payment, or any other term of a grant or loan to facilitate the successful completion or operation of a project.
The Department may contract for services related to the Business Development Program.
The Department shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Business Development Program;
adopt regulations to carry out the Business Development Program;

establish, for each category of financing described in § 6-306(c) of this subtitle, minimum percentages or amounts of private and nonstate public financing that an applicant for the Business Development Program must secure; and
make a reasonable, good faith effort to make 25% of the Business Development Program loans and grants to microenterprises.

subsection.text: The Department may:

paragraph.text: sell, assign, or otherwise dispose of a Program loan or revenue from a loan on terms and conditions acceptable to the Department, including selling loans at a discount, if the maximum sale proceeds in any fiscal year do not exceed $4,000,000; and
apply the proceeds received from a sale, assignment, or other disposition under item (1) of this subsection to the Fund.

subsection.text: If the Department determines that an entity is capable of administering a microenterprise loan program, the entity may originate and administer loans to microenterprises in accordance with standards the Department adopts by regulation.

paragraph.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to establish standards for determining the eligibility of an entity to administer a microenterprise loan program.
The standards shall include provisions on:

subparagraph.text: the size, training, and experience of the professional staff that would administer the program; and
the capability of the professional staff to:

sub-subparagraph.text: determine financial capacity of a borrower;
originate a loan; and
evaluate applications for program loans.

subsection.text: The Department may:

paragraph.text: help train employees of an approved entity to administer a microenterprise loan program in accordance with standards that the Department adopts;
charge and collect from a borrower:

subparagraph.text: reasonable origination, application, and processing fees; and
other charges, fees, or reimbursements incidental to microenterprise loans;

paragraph.text: include the fees and charges listed in item (2) of this subsection in the loan amount;
pay an approved entity a reasonable origination, application, and processing fee for each loan to a microenterprise that is originated by the approved entity;
directly fund a loan to a microenterprise that is originated by an approved entity; and
provide financial assistance to an approved entity for the purpose of the approved entity making a loan to a microenterprise in accordance with this subtitle.

subsection.text: There is a Capital Access Program in the Neighborhood Business Development Program.
The purposes of the Capital Access Program are to:

paragraph.text: stimulate private sector lending to small businesses throughout the State; and
encourage private lenders to provide for a reserve of money as additional security for private sector loans made under this section.

subsection.text: The Department may enter into a Capital Access Program participation agreement with each lender eligible to participate in the Capital Access Program.
To be eligible to participate in the Capital Access Program, a lender:

paragraph.text: shall be a federally insured financial institution, as defined in § 1-101 of the Financial Institutions Article, or another institution regulated by the Commissioner of Financial Regulation; and
shall enter into a participation agreement with the Department that:

subparagraph.text: requires the lender to agree to:

sub-subparagraph.text: enroll in the Capital Access Program loans that the lender makes to an eligible small business;
establish a loan reserve account with a federally insured financial institution as additional security to cover losses of the lender on loans that the lender enrolls; and
contribute money to the loan reserve account for each loan that the lender enrolls; and

subparagraph.text: allows the lender to commingle in the reserve account contributions made for loans that the lender enrolls.

subsection.text: To be eligible for a loan under the Capital Access Program, a borrower:

paragraph.text: shall be a small business that meets the eligibility requirements set out in the Capital Access Program participation agreement between the borrower’s lender and the Department; and
shall agree with the lender to contribute money to the loan reserve account that the lender establishes.
The Department may use the Fund to contribute up to $1,000,000 per fiscal year to loan reserve accounts established under subsection (d) of this section.
The contributions by the Department are exempt from the requirements of Title 6, Subtitle 2, and Titles 11 through 17, of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Enrolling a loan in the Capital Access Program does not pledge the faith, credit, or taxing power of the State, the Department, the Neighborhood Business Development Program, or the Fund.

The State, the Department, the Neighborhood Business Development Program, and the Fund are not liable for losses of a lender on an enrolled loan, except to the extent of the loan reserve account that the lender establishes under the Capital Access Program.

subsection.text: A project financed by a loan enrolled in the Capital Access Program shall be in a priority funding area as required by Title 5, Subtitle 7B of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
A lender shall treat a default on a loan enrolled in the Capital Access Program in the same way that the lender treats defaults on other loans.

The Department may require that, before a lender withdraws money from a reserve account to cover losses on a defaulted enrolled loan, the lender agree that, if the reserve account fully covers the losses, the lender will assign to the Department or subrogate the Department to the right, title, and interest of the lender in and to:

paragraph.text: the loan;
collateral and security for the loan; and
every other right of recovery in connection with the loan.

After a default on a loan enrolled in the Capital Access Program, the Department may acquire, hold, improve, operate pending sale or other disposition, sell, assign, exchange, transfer, convey, lease, mortgage, or otherwise dispose of or encumber property that secures or is collateral for all or part of the loan, including:

subparagraph.text: real property;
personal property; and
evidence of indebtedness.

paragraph.text: The Department may act under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: in its name or in the name of the Neighborhood Business Development Program; and
notwithstanding Titles 10 through 17 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out the Capital Access Program.
There is a Neighborhood Business Development Fund.
The Department shall use the Fund to:

paragraph.text: operate and pay expenses of the Program; and
provide financial assistance to small businesses, nonprofit organizations, and microenterprises.
The Department shall administer the Fund.
The State Treasurer shall hold and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing special fund that is not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget for the Program;
any repayment or prepayment of financial assistance under this subtitle or under the State Action Loans for Targeted Areas Program under former Article 83B, Title 4, Subtitle 6, of the Code;
money transferred to the Fund from any other fund as provided in this article;
money received from the sale, assignment, or other disposition of Program loans;
other money received by the Program under this subtitle or from the Community Development Administration under Subtitle 2 of this title; and
investment earnings of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund shall be invested in the same way as other State money.

With the approval of the Legislative Policy Committee and, subject to § 7-209 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, after the first 8 months of a fiscal year, the Department may transfer unencumbered money in the Fund to any other fund established under this title.

paragraph.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in a document required to be submitted to the Department by an agreement relating to financial assistance under the Program.

An applicant for financial assistance under the Program may not knowingly make or cause to be made any false statement or report to influence the action of the Department on an application or to influence any action of the Department affecting financial assistance already provided.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Approved project” means a project that the Department approves under § 6–405 of this subtitle.
“Business entity” means a person that conducts a trade or business in the State and is subject to:

paragraph.text: the State income tax on individuals or corporations;
the public service company franchise tax; or
the insurance premiums tax.

subsection.text: “Individual” means an individual as defined under § 10–101 of the Tax – General Article.
“Nonprofit organization” means a not for profit corporation, foundation, or other legal entity that is exempt from federal income tax under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Priority funding area” means a priority funding area under § 5–7B–02 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
“Redevelopment assistance” means the money that nonprofit organizations spend for labor and materials used directly in the physical improvement of part or all of a priority funding area.

section.text: There is a Neighborhood and Community Assistance Program.
The purposes of the Neighborhood and Community Assistance Program are to:

paragraph.text: help nonprofit organizations to carry out approved projects in priority funding areas;
encourage business entities and individuals to invest in priority funding areas; and
strengthen partnerships between public and private entities.

For a contribution worth $500 or more in goods, money, or real property to an approved project, a business entity or an individual is entitled to a tax credit in the amount determined under subsection (b) of this section.
No part of a tax credit under this section may be taken more than once.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the credit allowed to a business entity or an individual under this section equals 50% of the amount of contributions:

subparagraph.text: that the Department approves under subsection (c) of this section; and
that were made during the taxable year for which the credit is claimed.

paragraph.text: The credit allowed under this section for any taxable year may not exceed the lesser of:

subparagraph.text: the total amount of tax otherwise payable by the business entity or individual for the taxable year.

paragraph.text: Any excess credit that would be allowed but for the limits of paragraph (2) of this subsection may be carried over and applied as a credit for up to 5 taxable years after the taxable year in which the contribution was made, until the full amount of the excess is used.

To qualify for a credit for a contribution under this section, before making a contribution, a business entity or an individual shall apply for and receive approval of the contribution from the Department.
Each application for approval of a contribution shall contain:

subparagraph.text: the name of the approved project to which the contribution will be made;
the amount of the contribution; and

a certification by an independent and unrelated third party as to the value of any nonmonetary contribution included or, for new goods, an invoice or receipt certifying the contribution’s net cost to the business entity or individual.

paragraph.text: The Department may not approve an application if it determines that:

subparagraph.text: the maximum amount of contributions eligible for a tax credit for the project for the fiscal year will be exceeded by the sum of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount of the proposed contribution; and
the total amount of contributions previously approved for that project for the fiscal year; or

subparagraph.text: the applicant has overstated the value of a nonmonetary contribution.

paragraph.text: On or before January 31 of each year, the Department shall report to the Department of Assessments and Taxation, the Comptroller, and the Maryland Insurance Administration the contributions that the Department has approved under this section in the preceding calendar year.

For each fiscal year, a nonprofit organization may submit to the Department, for approval under the Neighborhood and Community Assistance Program, a proposal for a project to provide services to a priority funding area.
The project may include:

subparagraph.text: community services, including child care and recreational services;
redevelopment assistance;
job training for individuals whose incomes do not exceed the upper income limits that the Secretary sets under § 4-212 of this article;
education; and
crime prevention.

subsection.text: A proposal under this section shall include:

paragraph.text: the project to be conducted;
the priority funding area that will benefit from the project;
a description of the applicant’s experience and capabilities;
the estimated costs of the project;
a description of the plans for implementing the project; and
any other information that the Department determines is necessary.
The Department may not approve a proposal submitted under this section unless the proposal is approved by the governing body or authorized designee of:

subparagraph.text: each county that includes any of the priority funding area that benefits from the project, if the project is not in a municipal corporation;
each municipal corporation that includes any of the priority funding area that benefits from the project; or

each political subdivision that includes any of the priority funding area that benefits from the project, if the priority funding area is partly within and partly outside of any municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: An approval shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing; and
state the maximum amount of contributions to the approved project that are eligible for a tax credit under § 6-404 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The sum of contributions eligible for a tax credit under § 6-404 of this subtitle for all approved projects for a fiscal year may not exceed $2,000,000.

subsection.text: In approving or disapproving a proposal and in determining the maximum amount of contributions eligible for tax credits under § 6–404 of this subtitle, the Department:

paragraph.text: shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the need for the project in relation to the need for other proposed projects;
the anticipated benefit to the priority funding area;
the capacity of the applicant to raise money for the project;
the readiness of the applicant to proceed with the project;
the ability of the applicant to complete the project as proposed;
the geographic distribution of projects; and
any other relevant factors;

paragraph.text: may give preference to a proposal that benefits a sustainable community under § 6–305 of this title;
may request data and assistance from other units of the State; and
shall apportion among all approved projects the limit imposed by subsection (c)(3) of this section.

section.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Assisted household” means one or more individuals who occupy a rental unit in an assisted project.
“Assisted project” means a property that qualifies under § 7-105 of this subtitle.
“Assisted unit” means a dwelling unit that is in an assisted project and is subject to regulatory requirements regarding:

paragraph.text: the rent the owner may charge; or
the maximum annual income of the household occupying the unit.

subsection.text: “Designated household” means a household that qualifies under § 7-213 of this title.
“Notice of intent” means a notice of intent to take a protected action in accordance with Subtitle 2 of this title.
“Owner” means a person who holds legal title to an assisted project or any mortgagee in possession, receiver, trustee, or other person that may take a protected action.
“Owner’s offer” means the written offer made by the owner to parties having a right of first purchase under § 7-204 of this title.

paragraph.text: “Project-based § 8 rental assistance” means federal rental assistance under § 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937, 42 U.S.C. § 1437f, to the owner or lender of a housing project under a new construction program, a substantial rehabilitation program, a loan management assistance program, or a property disposition program.
“Project-based § 8 rental assistance” does not include rental assistance made directly to a tenant under existing certificate or voucher programs.

subsection.text: “Protected action” means a sale, conveyance, transfer, prepayment, termination, failure to renew, or expiration under § 7-102(a) of this title.
“Relocation expenses” means costs incurred to:

paragraph.text: hire contractors, labor, vehicles, or equipment to transport personal property;
pack and unpack personal property;
disconnect and reconnect utilities, such as water, telephone, gas, or electric, and to perform related services;
disconnect and install personal property;
insure personal property to be moved;
pay rental application fees and make security deposits; and
pay other costs that the Secretary determines are reasonable.

subsection.text: “Tenant protection assistance” means payments to, and extensions of leases for, the occupant or former occupant of an assisted unit in connection with a protected action as required under § 7-212 of this title.
Each owner of an assisted project is subject to this title if the owner takes or intends to take any of the following protected actions:

paragraph.text: the prepayment in full before the maturity date of mortgage financing that is:

subparagraph.text: insured under § 221(d)(3) of the National Housing Act, 12 U.S.C. § 1715l(d)(3), and assisted under § 101 of the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1965, 12 U.S.C. § 1701s, or under § 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937, 42 U.S.C. § 1437f;
insured under § 221(d)(3) of the National Housing Act, 12 U.S.C. § 1715l(d)(3), and bears interest at a rate determined under § 221(d)(5) of the National Housing Act;
insured or assisted under § 202 or § 236(a) or (b) of the National Housing Act, 12 U.S.C. § 1701q or 12 U.S.C. § 1715z-1(a) or (b);
insured or assisted under § 515 of the Housing Act of 1949, 42 U.S.C. § 1485; or

held by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development and insured or assisted, or formerly insured or assisted, under a program authorized by a statute referred to in item (1) of this subsection;

paragraph.text: the termination before expiration of or failure to exercise any stated renewal option under an agreement providing for project-based § 8 rental assistance for any units in an assisted project;
the expiration, including a failure to extend after the expiration, of an agreement providing for project-based § 8 rental assistance to any units in an assisted project; or
the sale or conveyance of an assisted project by the owner in conjunction with, or within 1 year after the effective date of, any of the events described in item (1), (2), or (3) of this subsection.

subsection.text: Any sale, conveyance, or other transfer of an assisted project is subject to this title, including:

paragraph.text: the sale or other transfer of any general partnership interests of the owner;
the sale or other transfer, in any 1 calendar year, of:

subparagraph.text: more than 10% of the limited partnership interests of an owner; or
more than 10% of an owner’s stock;

paragraph.text: the transfer by a beneficiary of beneficial or equitable interests under a trust in which the trustee holds title to the assisted project; and
other transfer determined by the Secretary.

subsection.text: By regulation, the Secretary shall establish standards and procedures for interested persons to be exempted from any requirement of §§ 7-203 through 7-219 of this title:

paragraph.text: if Title II of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1987, 12 U.S.C. §§ 4101 through 4124, continues, is amended, or is extended, or if a successor federal law is enacted; and
to diminish the burdens of dual regulation or to prevent inconsistent or inequitable application of federal and State law.

subsection.text: This title does not apply to an assisted project if:

paragraph.text: before any protected action, the owner or purchaser records, in a form satisfactory to the Secretary, a covenant running with the land on which the assisted project is located that preserves the existing low-income rental restrictions of the federal housing program:

subparagraph.text: for the term remaining as of the date of prepayment of any mortgage described under subsection (a)(1) of this section; and

for the term remaining as of the date of termination, including all stated and unexercised renewal terms, of any rental assistance agreement described under subsection (a)(2) of this section or, if greater, for 5 years; or

paragraph.text: the sale or conveyance of the assisted project:

subparagraph.text: is subject to continuation of the existing mortgage financing described under subsection (a)(1) of this section; and
occurs before the date of a termination, failure to renew, or expiration of project-based § 8 rental assistance described under subsection (a)(2) of this section.

section.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations to carry out this title.
A household qualifies as an assisted household if its gross annual income does not exceed:

paragraph.text: upper income limits imposed by any federal, State, or local government program providing financial assistance to the assisted project; or
upper income limits that the Secretary establishes, which may vary for a particular project or a particular area of the State to the extent necessary to achieve the purposes of this title.

section.text: A property qualifies as an assisted project if:

paragraph.text: it is a building or buildings under common ownership containing 10 or more dwelling units intended to be leased to assisted households for occupancy as their primary residences; and

subparagraph.text: a loan financing the property is insured or assisted under § 221(d)(3), § 202, or § 236(a) or (b) of the National Housing Act, 12 U.S.C. § 1701q, § 1715l(d)(3), or § 1715z-1, or § 515 of the Housing Act of 1949, 42 U.S.C. § 1485; or
the project, the owner of the project, or a lender to the project receives project-based § 8 rental assistance.

section.text: This title does not reduce any obligation or right of a tenant, political subdivision, or owner under Title 11 of the Real Property Article.

subsection.text: The owner of an assisted project shall give written notice of intent not less than 1 year and not more than 2 years before the effective date of the protected action.
The owner shall give the notice of intent to:

paragraph.text: the chief executive officer of each political subdivision in which the assisted project is located;
each public housing authority in a political subdivision in which the assisted project is located;

each tenant association that represents a rental unit in the assisted project, if the tenant association has given the owner the title and mailing address of a representative to receive the notice of intent;
each assisted household of the assisted project; and
the Secretary, who shall notify every other person who has requested the notice of intent.

subsection.text: A notice of intent, other than one sent to an assisted household, shall:

paragraph.text: state that the owner intends to begin or allow a protected action;
give enough information so that the Department can decide whether the proposed protected action will be lawful on its effective date;
state the expected impact of the protected action during the 3 years after the proposed action on:

subparagraph.text: rents in the assisted project; and
continued occupancy in the assisted project by existing assisted households;

paragraph.text: give the information about the assisted project from the most recent tenant recertification documents required by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, the United States Department of Agriculture, or the Department of Housing and Community Development on:

subparagraph.text: the number of assisted households;
the number of assisted units by number of bedrooms;
the distribution of assisted households by race, gender, income, and family size;
the number of households with elderly individuals or individuals with disabilities; and
the number of households with minors;

paragraph.text: give financial information on the assisted project for the 3 years before the notice of intent that is:

subparagraph.text: required by the Department; and
based on financial information kept by the owner; and

paragraph.text: include a list, based on information that is reasonably available, of all households in the assisted project whose leases were terminated in the 180 days before the notice of intent.

subsection.text: A notice of intent sent to an assisted household shall contain:

paragraph.text: a brief summary of the protected action;
a brief statement of the expected impact of the protected action on rents and on the existing assisted household’s continued occupancy during the 5 years after the protected action;
a brief summary statement of the assisted household’s rights and obligations under this title;

a statement that each political subdivision in which the assisted project is located, a local public housing authority, and the Department may have additional information about the protected action and sources of technical assistance and financing for the exercise of a right of first purchase under this title;
the name, address, and phone number of the owner’s agent to whom the assisted household may apply for tenant protection assistance under this title; and
any other information the Secretary considers necessary to further the purposes of this title.

subsection.text: An owner may not take a protected action unless the owner has provided all tenant protection assistance required by this title.
Before a sale or conveyance of an assisted project that is a protected action, the owner shall offer the right of first purchase in accordance with this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The owner shall offer the right of first purchase by written notice to:

subparagraph.text: each political subdivision in which the assisted project is located;
each local public housing authority;
each group that represents tenants at the assisted project and has registered with the Secretary;
each low-income housing developer that has registered with the Secretary and is exempt from taxation under § 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code; and
any other person that has experience in the ownership or operation of low-income housing projects, is unrelated to the owner, and has registered with the Secretary.

paragraph.text: The owner shall deliver the offer:

subparagraph.text: with or after the notice of intent; and
to a person registered with the Secretary within 10 days after the Secretary gives the owner the title and mailing address of the person.

paragraph.text: The owner shall deliver a copy of the offer to the Department.

subsection.text: The owner’s offer shall include:

paragraph.text: the terms of the offer, including:

subparagraph.text: the date of the offer;
the purchase price, as determined under § 7-205(b) of this subtitle;
a date for settlement, which must be 1 year or more after the later of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the date of the owner’s offer; and
the date of the notice of intent;

subparagraph.text: a provision stating that:

sub-subparagraph.text: the buyer’s obligation is contingent on the buyer’s obtaining financing; and
the contingency will not expire before the settlement;

subparagraph.text: a requirement that the first $10,000 of any deposit by the purchaser be nonrefundable, except as provided in § 7-205(c)(1)(iii) of this subtitle; and
other terms determined under § 7-205(b) of this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: a summary of the procedures and timing to exercise the right of first purchase, as specified in this subtitle and in any departmental regulations.

subsection.text: The date of the owner’s offer is the date on which it is delivered to the last political subdivision to which it must be delivered.
In this section, “fair market value” means the price that a willing buyer would pay a willing seller, neither under any compulsion to buy or to sell, for a residential rental project, assuming:

paragraph.text: the highest and best use under current zoning; and

no requirements to rent to low-income tenants other than the requirements of any federal law, § 7-214 of this subtitle, or other State law, local law, governmental program, agreement, covenant, or restriction that will continue to affect the project after sale or conveyance.

Except as required under § 7-204(b) of this subtitle, if the owner receives an offer to purchase the assisted project in the form of a binding purchase contract from an unrelated bona fide purchaser, the terms of the owner’s offer shall be substantially the same as those offered by the bona fide purchaser, including purchase price, terms of payment, financing contingencies, and assumable or purchase money financing.
If the owner has not received an offer that qualifies under paragraph (1) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: the purchase price of the owner’s offer shall be the lesser of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the purchase price of any offer that does not qualify under paragraph (1) of this subsection; and
the fair market value of the property as determined under subsection (d) of this section;

subparagraph.text: the owner’s offer shall be accompanied by a written appraisal of the fair market value of the assisted project prepared in accordance with subsection (d) of this section; and
the remaining terms of the purchase contract:

sub-subparagraph.text: shall be as required under § 7-204(b) of this subtitle;
shall otherwise conform to terms that are accepted as reasonable in that market; and
are subject to final review by the Department.

subparagraph.text: Any party identified in § 7-204(a) of this subtitle may accept the owner’s offer within 120 days after the date of the owner’s offer.

If more than one party submits a timely acceptance of the owner’s offer, the Secretary shall select as purchaser the party that, in the Secretary’s discretion, the Secretary determines will most benefit the assisted households.
The owner shall return the entire deposit made by each party whose offer was not accepted.

paragraph.text: If a party that has accepted the owner’s offer withdraws the acceptance, any remaining party identified in § 7-204(a) of this subtitle may accept the owner’s offer in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection within:

subparagraph.text: 120 days after the date of the offer; or
60 days after the acceptance is withdrawn.

paragraph.text: The acceptance shall be followed by settlement of the purchase of the assisted project by the owner’s stated closing date or any extension agreed to by the owner.

subparagraph.text: If the owner is required by subsection (b)(2) of this section to submit an appraisal, acceptance of the owner’s offer made under this subtitle may state an adjusted purchase price based on an alternate fair market value.
