The alternate fair market value shall be supported by a written appraisal prepared by an appraiser selected by the purchaser and delivered to the owner.

paragraph.text: If the owner objects to the adjusted purchase price, the owner and the purchaser may:

subparagraph.text: set the purchase price at the average of the fair market values each party has obtained by appraisal; or
have the two appraisers select a third appraiser, whose fee shall be shared equally, and whose fair market value shall be binding.

paragraph.text: Each appraiser who submits an appraisal under this subtitle must be a member in good standing of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers or the Society of Real Estate Appraisers.

subsection.text: This section applies if the owner’s offer is not accepted and the acceptance period under § 7-205(c) of this subtitle has expired.
The owner may sell or convey the assisted project to any person on terms and conditions not more favorable to the purchaser than those of the owner’s offer.

The owner may sell or convey the assisted project on terms and conditions more favorable to the purchaser than those of the original offer under this subtitle only after the owner again offers the right of first purchase as required by this subtitle based on the new terms and conditions.
This section applies if:

paragraph.text: none of the parties identified in § 7-204(a) of this subtitle exercises the right of first purchase;
the assisted project has not been conveyed in accordance with § 7-206 of this subtitle; and
the owner has not taken a protected action within 2 years after the original notice of intent.
Before taking a protected action, the owner shall serve another notice of intent on each party identified in § 7-201(b) of this subtitle.
Before taking a protected action under § 7-102(a)(4) of this title, the owner shall serve notice of a right of first purchase as required by this subtitle.

subsection.text: At the settlement for an assisted project under a right of first purchase, the purchaser shall execute and record, in a form that the Secretary approves, a covenant running with the land.
The covenant shall restrict the use of all assisted units to residential rental property for assisted households, or to some other purpose approved by the Secretary, for at least the greatest of:

paragraph.text: the remaining term of the mortgage as of the date of its prepayment;
the remaining term of the rental assistance agreement, including all stated renewal terms, as of the date of its termination; and
20 years.

section.text: A right of first purchase under this subtitle may be assigned only to another party having the right of first purchase under this subtitle.

subsection.text: A political subdivision or a housing authority may exercise a right of first purchase under this subtitle and may develop, acquire, improve, own, operate, and manage a rental housing project acquired under the right of first purchase and do all things necessary or convenient to exercise these rights.

In any rental housing project purchased under a right of first purchase under this subtitle and owned or managed by a housing authority authorized under Division II of this article, this subtitle supersedes:

paragraph.text: §§ 12-401, 12-402, and 12-405 of this article; and
all otherwise applicable restrictions on tenant income under Division II of this article.

section.text: The right of first purchase under this subtitle does not apply to the prepayment of a mortgage and sale of an assisted project if the prepayment and sale are done under a plan of action approved by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development under § 225 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1987, 12 U.S.C. § 4107.

subsection.text: An owner that gives notice of intent shall provide tenant protection assistance under subsection (b) of this section unless:

paragraph.text: the owner has offered the right of first purchase in accordance with this subtitle; and
the assisted project is purchased by a party listed in § 7-204(a) of this subtitle in conjunction with a protected action.

subsection.text: Tenant protection assistance consists of:

paragraph.text: paying each assisted household $475 on or before the day that the assisted household vacates the unit;
reimbursing each assisted household for relocation expenses exceeding $475 and up to $950, actually and reasonably incurred; and
offering each assisted household that is current in its rent and has not violated any other material term of its lease, a lease extension for at least 1 year from the giving of the notice of intent.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the periodic rent during the extended lease under subsection (b)(3) of this section may not exceed the amount that the assisted household must contribute for periodic rent under the assisted household’s current lease.
The periodic rent may be increased only on the anniversary of the assisted household’s current lease, and the increase may not exceed the lesser of:

subparagraph.text: the increase allowed by applicable federal, State, or local law; and

the product of the amount the household must contribute for periodic rent for the preceding year multiplied by the percentage increase for the U.S. Consumer Price Index that the Secretary selects for the most recent 12-month period.

paragraph.text: Except as allowed or required by the Secretary, all other terms and conditions governing the extended lease shall be the same as those of the lease in effect on the day preceding the giving of the notice of intent.

section.text: An assisted household is a designated household if it includes:

paragraph.text: an individual who has been a member of the household for at least 12 months before the notice of intent is given and who:

subparagraph.text: is at least 62 years old on the day that the notice of intent is given; or
qualifies as a person with disabilities under § 3(b)(3) of the United States Housing Act of 1937, 42 U.S.C. § 1437f; or

paragraph.text: a minor.
This subsection applies if a protected action affects a unit occupied by a designated household that:

subparagraph.text: is current in its rent and has not violated any other material term of the lease;

within 60 days after the giving of the notice of intent, provides the owner with written notice showing that the household qualifies as a designated household and stating that the household is applying for an extended lease under this section; and
executes the extended lease form delivered in accordance with § 7-216(a)(2) of this subtitle and returns it to the owner within 60 days after the giving of the notice of intent.

paragraph.text: Except for a protected action under § 7-102(a)(3) of this title, an owner may not take a protected action that affects a unit in an assisted project occupied by a designated household without offering to the designated household an extended lease for at least 3 years beginning on the day of the giving of the notice of intent.
The owner shall set aside at least 20% of the assisted units in an assisted project for designated households to receive extended leases under this subtitle.

If the number of assisted units occupied by designated households that meet the standards of subsection (a) of this section exceeds 20% of the assisted units, the owner shall allocate the available units:

subparagraph.text: first to designated households with an individual described under § 7-213(1) of this subtitle with priority based on length of continuous residence; and
then to designated households that do not contain such an individual but include a minor, based on length of continuous residence.

section.text: If an assisted project includes a unit occupied by a designated household and the assisted project is sold or conveyed after a protected action:

paragraph.text: the provisions of this subtitle concerning extended leases continue to apply despite the sale or conveyance;
the new landlord shall provide each designated household with written notice of the sale or conveyance; and

on or before the execution of a contract of sale, the seller shall provide the purchaser with written disclosure of each unit occupied by a designated household subject to the provisions concerning extended leases for designated households.

subsection.text: Along with the notice of intent, the owner shall deliver to each assisted household:

paragraph.text: an application form on which the assisted household may include the information required by § 7-214(a) of this subtitle;
an extended lease form for a designated household that contains the terms required by this subtitle and clearly indicates that the lease will be effective only if:

subparagraph.text: the assisted household executes and returns the lease form within 60 days after the giving of the notice of intent; and

the assisted household is allocated one of the units made available to designated households, based on its ranking under § 7-214(b) of this subtitle and the number of assisted households executing and returning leases; and

paragraph.text: a notice that sets forth the rights and obligations of the assisted household under the provisions of this subtitle concerning extended leases for designated households.

subsection.text: Within 75 days after the giving of the notice of intent, the owner shall notify each assisted household that submits the documentation required by § 7-214 of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: whether the household meets the standards of § 7-214 of this subtitle, or, if not, an explanation of which standards have not been met; and
whether the extended lease has become effective.

subparagraph.text: An extended lease for a designated household shall be for a term beginning on acceptance and ending at least 3 years after the giving of the notice of intent.
The initial periodic rent for the extended lease may not exceed the amount the household is required to contribute for rent under the household’s current lease.

paragraph.text: The periodic rent may be increased only on the anniversary of the assisted household’s extended lease, and the increase may not exceed the product of the amount the household must contribute for periodic rent for the preceding year multiplied by the percentage increase for the U.S. Consumer Price Index that the Secretary selects for the most recent 12-month period.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, the extended lease shall contain the same terms and conditions as the lease in effect on the day before the giving of the notice of intent.

section.text: Within 75 days after giving the notice of intent, the owner shall provide to each party required to receive the notice of intent:

paragraph.text: a notice indicating the number of units in the assisted project being made available to designated households under § 7-214(b) of this subtitle;
a list of the households meeting the standards of § 7-214(a) of this subtitle, indicating the ranking of each under § 7-214(b) of this subtitle;

a list of the households returning the documents required by § 7-214(a) of this subtitle that do not meet all of the standards of that subsection and copies of the notices sent to those households under § 7-216(b) of this subtitle; and
a list of the households with effective extended leases.
A designated household may terminate an extended lease at any time by giving written notice to the landlord:

subparagraph.text: at least 1 month in advance, if less than 12 months remain on the lease; or
at least 3 months in advance, if 12 months or more remain on the lease.

paragraph.text: An extended lease for a designated household under this subtitle shall include the termination provisions of this section.

subsection.text: The extended tenancy of a designated household ends:

paragraph.text: 90 days after the last member of the assisted household who lived in the unit on the date of the notice of intent dies or moves from the unit;
on eviction for failure to pay rent or for violation of another material term of the extended lease; or
on voluntary termination by the designated household under subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: This section applies if a protected action involves substantial rehabilitation or reconstruction that does not allow continued occupancy of a unit because of danger to the health and safety of the household.

paragraph.text: The owner shall give notice of the reconstruction or rehabilitation at least 1 year before the date when the unit must be vacated.
The notice shall explain the household’s rights under this section.
To allow work to be performed in a unit, a designated household with an extended lease under § 7-216 of this subtitle may be required to:

subparagraph.text: vacate the unit not earlier than 1 year after the giving of the notice of intent; and
relocate at the expense of the owner to a comparable unit in the assisted project.
If a comparable unit is not available, the designated household may be required to vacate the assisted project until the work is completed.
When the work is completed, the owner shall notify the designated household of the completion of the work.
The designated household has 30 days to return to the original or a comparable rental unit after the owner notifies the designated household that the work is completed.
The term of the extended lease begins when the designated household returns to the assisted project.

paragraph.text: The owner shall pay all reasonable relocation expenses of a designated household required as a result of subsection (d) of this section.
The owner shall pay relocation expenses in accordance with § 7-212(b)(2) of this subtitle on or before the date when the designated household vacates the unit.
The owner shall also reimburse a designated household that returns to its unit under subsection (c)(2) of this section for its relocation expenses in accordance with § 7-212(b) of this subtitle.

In accordance with the schedule of fair market rents of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development in effect on the moving date, within 15 days after that date, the owner shall pay compensation equivalent to 3 months’ rent for a unit of comparable size and quality to each designated household eligible under this subsection.
A designated household is eligible for compensation under this subsection if it:

subparagraph.text: is current in its rent payments and has not violated any other material term of its lease;
includes an individual described under § 7-213(1) of this subtitle and:

sub-subparagraph.text: does not have an extended lease; or
cannot have an extended lease because the number of assisted units set aside under § 7-214(b) of this subtitle is less than the number of qualified households; or

subparagraph.text: otherwise qualifies for an extended lease but is required to vacate its unit under subsection (c)(2) of this section.

paragraph.text: After notice and public hearing, a political subdivision may find that, because of a protected action, a low-income and moderate-income rental housing emergency exists in all or part of its jurisdiction.
The political subdivision shall make findings as to:

subparagraph.text: the nature and incidence of protected actions;
the resulting hardship to and displacement of tenants; and
the scarcity of low-income and moderate-income rental housing.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, on finding that there is an emergency under this section, a political subdivision may enact a law, ordinance, or regulation to:

subparagraph.text: grant to a designated household a right to an extended lease for a period in addition to that granted under § 7-214 of this subtitle; or
extend any other provision of this subtitle concerning extended leases.

paragraph.text: A political subdivision may not require that:

subparagraph.text: more than 20% of assisted units in an assisted project be set aside for extended leases for designated households; or
the term of an extended lease for any household made a designated household by the political subdivision exceed 3 years.

paragraph.text: The political subdivision may require that the notice required under § 7-216(a)(3) of this subtitle be modified to disclose the effects of any actions taken under this section.

subsection.text: Within 10 days after enacting a law, ordinance, or regulation in accordance with this section, a political subdivision shall send a copy to the Secretary of State and the Secretary of Housing and Community Development.

section.text: In connection with a protected action, each tenant shall cooperate with the owner in providing information necessary to certify eligibility for housing subsidy payments and in executing all necessary documents.

subsection.text: A tenant may not:

paragraph.text: waive or assign the tenant’s rights under this title; or
receive consideration to relinquish rights under this title.

subsection.text: A waiver or relinquishment made in violation of this section is void.

section.text: If a new tenant moves into an assisted unit after a notice of intent is given, the owner shall give the new tenant written notice that:

paragraph.text: sets forth any rent increase that the owner plans after the protected action; and
states that the new tenant will not be entitled to tenant protection assistance.

section.text: Before taking a protected action, an owner may not terminate without cause the leasehold interest of a tenant occupying an assisted unit to avoid the owner’s obligations under this title.

subsection.text: In this section, “excess rent” means rent that exceeds the rent payable by a tenant under the tenant’s lease as of the date of the notice of intent, adjusted as allowed under § 7-212(c) of this title.
Until 1 year has passed since the owner gave notice of intent, and the owner complies with the requirements of this title, nonpayment of excess rent is not grounds for an owner to:

paragraph.text: terminate a lease of an assisted unit; or
sue for possession of the leased property.

subsection.text: In connection with a protected action, an owner:

paragraph.text: may not terminate or alter the terms and conditions of a lease entered into before the effective date of the protected action;
may not interfere with the efforts of individual tenants to obtain housing subsidies or other public assistance;
may not discriminate based on source of income or receipt of a housing subsidy;
may not interfere with the rights of a tenant to occupy an assisted unit under an existing lease or applicable federal, State, or local law; and
shall cooperate with a tenant to execute all necessary documents to enable the payment of housing subsidies to or for the tenant.

subsection.text: If the owner has interfered with a tenant’s application for a housing subsidy or other public assistance, the nonpayment of any amount of rent for an assisted unit in excess of 30% of the tenant’s income is not grounds for the owner to terminate the lease or sue for possession of the leased property.

section.text: The person responsible for the closing of a real estate transaction shall file with the Department a written statement, made and signed by the owner under the penalties of perjury, that the transaction complies with this title, if the transaction includes:

paragraph.text: a sale or conveyance of an assisted project or the real property associated with it, and:

subparagraph.text: is a protected action; or
occurred within 10 years after a protected action for which the owner failed to comply with this title; or

paragraph.text: a release of:

subparagraph.text: a mortgage secured by an assisted project; or
a regulatory agreement or other document executed in connection with the mortgage that restricts the income levels of the tenants or the rental rates of the assisted project.

section.text: This title may be enforced at law or in equity by:

paragraph.text: the Department;
an assisted household in occupancy when the owner delivered or should have delivered a notice of intent;
a political subdivision where the assisted project is located; or
the public housing authority.

section.text: To enforce this title, a court may enjoin an action:

paragraph.text: prohibited by this title; or
taken before preliminary actions required by this title have been completed.

section.text: A violation of this title is within the scope of the enforcement duties and powers of the Division of Consumer Protection of the Office of the Attorney General under Title 13 of the Commercial Law Article, if the violation results in:

paragraph.text: displacement of a tenant or former tenant from an assisted unit;
increased rents for a tenant or former tenant of an assisted unit; or
another violation of the rights of a tenant or former tenant of an assisted unit.
A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in a document that is required to be submitted under this title.
A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report to influence the action of the Department in connection with this title.

subsection.text: A person who violates this title is subject to civil liability and to a civil penalty not exceeding $1,000,000.

section.text: This title is the Assisted Housing Preservation Act.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Community action agency” means:

paragraph.text: a governmental unit in a political subdivision;
a governmental unit created by a combination of political subdivisions;
an agency designated as a community action agency under the Economic Opportunity Act of 1964 as amended by the Community Services Block Grant Program, 42 U.S.C. §§ 9901 through 9926; or
a private, nonprofit organization that meets the requirements for designation as a community action agency.

subsection.text: “Designation” means the selection of a proposed community action agency by a governing body.
“Governing body” means:

paragraph.text: the county council, board of commissioners, or other legislative body of a political subdivision that collectively possesses the power to adopt and carry out local laws and ordinances; or
in Baltimore City, the Board of Estimates.

section.text: The General Assembly finds that the economic and social well-being of State residents is intrinsic to the strength and viability of the State as a whole.
The purposes of this title are to:

paragraph.text: strengthen the ability of communities to plan and coordinate available federal, State, local, and private resources by making the resources more responsive to local needs and conditions; and
strengthen, supplement, and coordinate efforts to combat the causes and problems of poverty in the State by:

subparagraph.text: mobilizing resources of private and public economic entities to increase opportunities for low-income State residents to develop skills, knowledge, and capabilities;
developing the full potential of low-income State residents so that everyone can live in decency and dignity and achieve individual and family self-sufficiency; and
promoting the development, evaluation, and use of new approaches to attack the causes and problems of poverty.

subsection.text: A political subdivision may designate a community action agency to serve a community within the political subdivision or may change or revoke a designation by:

paragraph.text: an act, ordinance, or resolution of its governing body; or
an order of its chief executive, if the chief legal officer certifies in writing that the chief executive has power to make the designation.
The governing body shall notify the public and hold a public hearing before a designation is made, changed, or revoked.
A transition or close-down plan shall accompany the notification of a proposed change or revocation of a designation.

subsection.text: A change in or revocation of a designation takes effect at the start of the State fiscal year.

paragraph.text: A community action agency shall administer its programs through a community action board.
A community action board consists of at least 15 members, of whom:

subparagraph.text: one-third are elected public officials currently holding office, or their designees;
at least one-third are chosen by a democratic selection method designed to assure that they will represent low-income persons in the community; and
the others are officials or members of business, industry, labor, religious, welfare, education, or other major groups and interests in the community.

paragraph.text: A member chosen to represent a geographic area shall reside in the area.
A person selected under paragraph (2)(ii) or (iii) of this subsection may not serve for more than 5 years consecutively or for more than a total of 10 years.

subsection.text: If a community action agency is a governmental unit:

paragraph.text: its community action board may serve as an advisory body; and
with the approval of the governing body, the governmental unit may delegate to the community action board any of its powers or responsibilities under this title.
A community action agency may accept and administer:

subparagraph.text: financial assistance received under this title;
money and contributions from private or local public sources for community action programs;

money from State or federal assistance programs under which a public or private nonprofit organization may act as a grantee, contractor, or sponsor of projects suitable for community action programs; and
federal money from federal block grants previously designated as antipoverty money, subject to applicable federal law.

paragraph.text: A community action agency may transfer money and delegate responsibility to a subsidiary board, council, or similar agency for projects designed to further community action program objectives.

subsection.text: Responsibility for making policy determinations, including the characters, funding, extent, and administration of and budgeting for programs or projects affecting a particular geographic area in a community may be delegated by a community action agency to a subsidiary board, council, or similar agency if the subsidiary body is broadly representative of the area.
A community action agency shall plan systematically for an effective community action program, and in doing so shall:

paragraph.text: evaluate information on the causes and problems of poverty in the community;
assess the use and impact of current financial assistance; and
establish priorities among projects, activities, and target areas to achieve the best and most efficient use of resources.

subsection.text: A community action agency shall:

paragraph.text: encourage subsidiary boards, councils, and agencies engaged in projects related to a community action program to plan for, secure, and administer available financial assistance on a cooperative basis; and
provide technical and organizational assistance to the subsidiary boards, councils, and agencies.

subsection.text: A community action agency shall actively supplement local efforts to combat poverty by:

paragraph.text: focusing resources on the most needy;
providing employment opportunities for low-income persons;
closing service gaps; and
enabling low-income persons to participate in community action programs and projects.

subsection.text: A community action agency shall initiate and sponsor community projects to help meet the needs of low-income persons with particular emphasis on:

paragraph.text: establishing a pool of resources to serve a variety of community action programs;
developing versatile approaches and services; and
implementing stopgap measures pending the expansion or modification of community action programs.

subsection.text: A community action agency shall:

paragraph.text: establish procedures for community residents to:

subparagraph.text: influence the character of their community action programs; and
participate regularly in implementing those programs; and

paragraph.text: provide the necessary technical and advisory support to enable low-income persons and community groups to secure public and private financial assistance for themselves.

subsection.text: A community action agency shall join with and encourage business, labor, and other private or public officials and organizations to support community action programs that:

paragraph.text: use private resources and capabilities for new employment opportunities;
stimulate investments that measurably reduce poverty in areas of concentrated poverty; and
provide residents in those areas with methods to work with private organizations, firms, and institutions to seek solutions to problems of common concern.

section.text: The Secretary may provide financial assistance to designated community action agencies in accordance with distribution standards set by regulation.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations to carry out this title.
The regulations shall include provisions that:

paragraph.text: ensure that each designated community action agency receives at least as much federal money as the community action agency received in federal fiscal year 1994, unless the federal funding is reduced; and

allocate remaining federal money to those community action agencies that received a lesser share of program federal money in federal fiscal year 1994 than they would have received based on the number of persons in the local jurisdiction with household income below the poverty line set by the federal Office of Management and Budget as a percentage of the number of persons in the State with household income below that line.
By regulation, the Secretary shall adopt standards for distributing financial assistance under § 8-108 of this subtitle.
The distribution standards shall include the percentage of persons in poverty, based on the most current census population information.

The distribution standards may address specific problems in rural communities, minimum financing necessary to maintain program operations, and the potential for additional local and private financing.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Community Reinvestment Board.

“Community reinvestment assistance” means a loan, assurance, guarantee, grant, payment, credit enhancement, or other assistance provided by the Fund as set forth in § 9-404 of this title, or a commitment to provide the assistance.
“Community reinvestment project” means a project or program eligible under § 9-402 of this title to receive community reinvestment assistance from the Fund.
“Fund” means the Community Reinvestment Fund.
“Limited income household” means a household or individual whose income does not exceed the upper income limits that the Secretary establishes.
“Member” means a member of the Board.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: some communities and neighborhoods in the State are in economic and social distress because of a shortage of significant private investment;
financial institutions in the State are recognizing a heightened responsibility to provide financial assistance to these communities and neighborhoods; and
federal and State regulators are requiring more community reinvestment by these financial institutions.

subsection.text: The General Assembly therefore finds that the public interest is served by promoting the development of a financial vehicle to be operated by private financial institutions to:

paragraph.text: increase community reinvestment to neighborhoods and communities in the State that have urgent need for reinvestment;

make community reinvestment by financial institutions easier and more desirable by spreading the financial risk and offering the experience of the State in providing community reinvestment lending; and
forge partnerships among financial institutions and the State in meeting community reinvestment goals.

section.text: There is a Community Reinvestment Board.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of at least 17 members.
The Secretary of the Department of Housing and Community Development and the Secretary of Business and Economic Development or their designees are nonvoting members.
The Governor shall appoint at least 15 voting members.
Subject to the requirements of this subsection, the voting members shall be appointed and removed in accordance with the organizational documents of the Fund.
At least two-thirds of the voting members shall represent:

subparagraph.text: the commercial banking or savings institution industry in the State or other participants that have pledged or contributed money or other substantial assistance to the Fund; or

trade organizations consisting of or otherwise representing two or more members of the commercial banking or savings institution industry in the State or other participants that have contributed money or other substantial assistance to the Fund.

paragraph.text: At least 20% of the voting members shall represent community groups or other entities that may be eligible to receive community reinvestment assistance.
The majority of voting members shall represent the groups described in paragraph (2)(i) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A member of the Board may be a director or member or may have some other legal status required by or appropriate to the type of entity constituting the Fund.

paragraph.text: The term of a voting member may not exceed 3 years.
A voting member may be reappointed.

section.text: The Board shall set the times and places of its meetings.

subsection.text: Subject to the requirements of this title, the organizational documents of the Fund shall govern the operation of the Board, including quorum and voting requirements.
The Board has all powers arising from the documents and procedures creating and organizing the Fund as an independent legal entity.
The Board shall:

paragraph.text: operate the Fund;
keep proper records of the Board’s accounts;
establish standards and guidelines for:

subparagraph.text: the terms and conditions of community reinvestment assistance and other Fund reinvestments; and
allocating community reinvestment assistance and other Fund investments;

paragraph.text: apportion among Fund transactions the operating costs of the Fund; and
within the first 90 days of each fiscal year, make an annual report of Fund activities to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly.
The Board shall appoint a loan committee to review and make determinations on specific requests or categories of requests for community reinvestment assistance to community reinvestment projects.

The loan committee may review and make recommendations to the Board on other matters as the Board determines, including eligibility guidelines and financing policies for community reinvestment projects.
The loan committee consists of:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary of Housing and Community Development and the Secretary of Business and Economic Development or their designees as nonvoting members; and
the voting members that the Board appoints or their designees.

subsection.text: There is a Community Reinvestment Fund.

The purpose of the Fund is to administer the use and reinvestment of money that may be credited, paid, or otherwise transferred to the Fund from any entity approved by the Board to participate in the Fund, including a bank, savings institution, or other financial institution.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a private, independent legal entity to be assisted by the Department under this title and is not a governmental unit of the State.

Any dividends, royalties, or other earnings received from community reinvestment assistance, or from any other investment made by the Board under this title, is money of the Fund, and is not money of the State.

subsection.text: Except as specified in this title, the organization and operation of the Board and the Fund are not subject to approval by the Board of Public Works or by any State official or unit.
A member, employee, or agent of the Board or the Fund is not a State official by virtue of any status with or action for the Fund.
The Board shall determine the form of the independent legal entity constituting the Fund in accordance with the organizational documents of the Fund.
In accordance with the organizational documents of the Fund, an entity contributing money to the Fund may be entitled to receive:

paragraph.text: interests in the Fund in proportion to the entity’s contribution, in an amount and in a form that the Board determines; and
a return on its contribution to the Fund based on:

subparagraph.text: the entity’s share; and
a fixed rate of return or the amount of any dividends, royalties, or other earnings of the Fund, or on another formula and in a form that the Board determines.

subsection.text: Titles 11 through 17 of the State Finance and Procurement Article do not apply to the operation of or any transactions made by the Fund.

Meetings of the Board or its members or of employees or agents of the Fund are not subject to State requirements for open or public meetings, including any requirements for open sessions under Title 10, Subtitle 5 of the State Government Article.

The Board shall use the money administered by the Fund to provide community reinvestment assistance in accordance with this title, any other applicable law, and the organizational documents of the Fund.
The Board may use the money that the Fund administers to:

paragraph.text: assure a reasonable return on money held by the Fund before disbursing money for community reinvestment assistance;
pay expenses incurred in its formation and operation, including expenses for administrative, legal, actuarial, and other services; and
redeem interests in the Fund.

section.text: The Department shall take any necessary action, including providing technical assistance, to encourage and facilitate the creation of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Department may provide money for administrative, legal, and other organizational expenses of the Fund.
The Department of Housing and Community Development and the Department of Business and Economic Development may:

paragraph.text: provide technical assistance for:

subparagraph.text: operating and administering the Fund; and
underwriting proposed community reinvestment projects; and

paragraph.text: charge reasonable and customary fees for the technical assistance.

section.text: The Secretary shall establish upper income limits for limited income households, taking into consideration factors that include:

paragraph.text: the total income of the household available for housing needs;
the size of the household;
the cost and condition of housing facilities;
the ability of the household to compete successfully in the conventional private housing market; and
relevant standards and definitions established for federal housing programs.

subsection.text: A project qualifies as a community reinvestment project if the Secretary determines in writing that the community reinvestment project meets:

paragraph.text: affordable housing needs of limited income households in the State;

capital, operating, and other credit needs of small businesses in the State, including farm businesses, if the assets, income, and number of employees of the business do not exceed limits that the Secretary of Business and Economic Development establishes; or

capital, operating, and other credit needs of individuals, community organizations, and businesses located in or serving communities or neighborhoods in the State that have urgent needs for reinvestment due to deteriorating social or economic conditions.

subsection.text: A community reinvestment project shall:

paragraph.text: conform to eligibility guidelines and financing policies consistent with this subtitle that the Board develops and the Secretary approves; and
be submitted to and approved by the loan committee appointed by the Board under § 9-204(d) of this title.

subsection.text: An application for community reinvestment assistance shall be made to the Department of Housing and Community Development, to the Department of Business and Economic Development, to an entity contributing to the Fund, or, if the Board allows, directly to the Fund.

The Department of Housing and Community Development and the Department of Business and Economic Development may provide technical assistance in the underwriting or review of a loan for which an application has been submitted.
The loan committee shall base its action on an application on the review of the application and recommendations made by one or more parties listed in subsection (a) of this section.

section.text: To provide community reinvestment assistance, the Board may:

paragraph.text: invest in, purchase, make commitments to purchase, or take assignments from mortgage lenders of notes and mortgages evidencing mortgage loans;
act as a guarantor or conduit for mortgage backed securities;
make loans to recipients of community reinvestment assistance or to mortgage lenders;
sell at public or private sale mortgages, loans, or other obligations held by the Fund;
purchase, make, participate in making, or enter into commitments to purchase loans;
package and sell loans; and
do anything else authorized by the organizational documents of the Fund.

section.text: This title is the Community Reinvestment Fund Act.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Award” means a grant, loan, deferred payment loan, loan guarantee, or other financial assistance.
“Board” means the Board of Trustees of the Trust.
“Fund” means the Maryland Affordable Housing Trust Fund.
“Trust” means the Maryland Affordable Housing Trust.
“Trustee” means a member of the Board.
There is a Maryland Affordable Housing Trust.

paragraph.text: The Trust is an instrumentality of the State and is a body corporate and politic.
The exercise by the Trust of its powers under this title is an essential public function.

subsection.text: The purpose of the Trust is to make affordable housing more available throughout the State.
The Department shall provide staff for the Trust.
There is a Board of Trustees of the Trust.
The Board shall control the Trust and exercise all of the corporate powers of the Trust.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 14 trustees.
The nonvoting trustees are:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary;
a member of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House; and
a member of the Senate, appointed by the President of the Senate.

paragraph.text: With the advice and consent of the Senate, the Governor shall appoint 11 voting trustees, consisting of:

subparagraph.text: four representatives of the public; and
one representative of each of the following:

sub-subparagraph.text: title companies doing business in the State;
financial institutions doing business in the State;
political subdivisions;
nonprofit housing developers;
for profit housing developers;
public housing authorities; and
social services providers.

subsection.text: In appointing trustees, the Governor shall consider geographic representation.
Service as a trustee is not a State office or State employment for purposes of any prohibition against holding two public positions.

paragraph.text: The term of a voting trustee is 4 years.
The terms of voting trustees are staggered as required by the terms provided for voting trustees on October 1, 2005.
At the end of a term, a voting trustee continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A voting trustee who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

section.text: The Governor shall appoint one of the trustees to serve as chair of the Board.

subsection.text: A quorum is a majority of the voting trustees then serving on the Board.
The Board may act with a majority vote of a quorum of the Board.
The debts, obligations, and liabilities of the Trust are those of the Trust only and are not:

paragraph.text: a pledge of the State’s credit; or
those of the State or its officers, employees, or governmental units.
The net earnings of the Trust may not inure to the benefit of a trustee, officer, or private person.
A trustee, officer, or private person is not entitled to share in the distribution of the corporate assets of the Trust.
If the Trust is dissolved or abolished, by act of the General Assembly or otherwise, its assets shall be distributed to the State or a governmental unit of the State.

section.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: receive applications for awards from the Trust;
make the final decisions about awards; and
develop a process for making awards that encourages a broad geographic distribution of money.

subsection.text: The Board shall comply with the Maryland Public Ethics Law.
The Board is exempt from:

paragraph.text: taxation by the State or its political subdivisions;
the General Procurement Law provisions of Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and
the Administrative Procedure Act, Title 10, Subtitles 1 through 4, of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: The books and records of the Trust are subject to audit:

paragraph.text: by the State, at the State’s discretion; and
annually by an independent auditor approved and paid by the Trust.
Within the first 90 days of each fiscal year, the Board shall report to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly.
The report shall include a complete operating and financial statement of the operations of the Trust and a summary of the activities of the Trust during the preceding fiscal year.

section.text: There is a Maryland Affordable Housing Trust Fund.

subsection.text: The Board shall use the Fund to make awards to:

paragraph.text: help acquire, build, rehabilitate, or preserve affordable housing;
help nonprofit organizations develop affordable housing; and
help promote affordable housing by contributing to pay the operating expenses of housing developments.

subsection.text: In any fiscal year, the Board may use up to 5% of the Fund to pay actual operating and staffing expenses directly related to the activities of the Trust.

section.text: The State Treasurer shall hold and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money that the Board receives from any public or private source, including a gift, grant, or legacy;
interest earned on Trust accounts held by title insurers and their agents under § 22-103 of the Insurance Article;
investment earnings of the Fund; and
repayments of principal or payments of interest on loans from the Fund.

section.text: The Board may solicit money for the Fund from any source.
Money in the Fund shall be invested in the same way as other State money.
This title shall be liberally construed to accomplish its purposes.
In this title, “Fund” means the Maryland State Appalachian Housing Fund.
There is a Maryland State Appalachian Housing Fund.
The Department shall use the Fund to fulfill its obligations under any contract or agreement with the Appalachian Regional Commission.
The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing special fund that is not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: receipts of the Department from the Appalachian Regional Commission;
investment earnings of the Fund; and
repayments of site development advances or loan principal or payments of loan interest made under this title.

section.text: The State Treasurer shall invest money in the Fund in the same way as other State money.

subsection.text: In this Division II the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Area of operation” means the geographical area within which an authority is empowered to act.
“Authority” means a public corporation created as a housing authority under this Division II.
“Bond” includes a note, an interim certificate, a debenture, and any other obligation issued by an authority under this Division II.
“Chief elected official” means:

paragraph.text: the individual who exercises the office of the chief publicly elected executive official of the political subdivision; or
in a political subdivision without a chief publicly elected executive official, the highest executive body.

subsection.text: “Code authority” means an authority activated on or after July 1, 1990.
“County” means a county of the State or Baltimore City.
“Custodian of records” means:

paragraph.text: the clerk of the political subdivision;
the officer charged with the duties customarily imposed on a clerk; or
the political subdivision’s designee to be the custodian of records for this Division II.

subsection.text: “Economically depressed or physically deteriorated area” means an area in which most housing is harmful to safety, health, and morals because of:

paragraph.text: dilapidation;
overcrowding;
faulty arrangement or design; or
lack of ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities.

subsection.text: “Extraordinary majority” means two-thirds or more of the authorized number of members of the legislative body or the board of commissioners of an authority, as applicable.

paragraph.text: “Housing project” means a work or undertaking to:

subparagraph.text: demolish, clear, or remove buildings from an economically depressed or physically deteriorated area; or
provide decent, safe, and sanitary housing for persons of eligible income and, to the extent authorized by § 12-503(a)(4) of this title, for other persons.

paragraph.text: “Housing project” includes:

subparagraph.text: work connected to planning, constructing, reconstructing, altering, or repairing improvements, acquiring property, or demolishing structures;
adapting an economically depressed or physically deteriorated area to public purposes, including parks and other recreational or community purposes; and
acquiring buildings, land, equipment, facilities, and other real or personal property for necessary, convenient, or desirable:

sub-subparagraph.text: appurtenances;
streets;
sewers;
water service;
parks;
site preparation;
gardening; and
administrative, community, health, recreational, educational, welfare, or other purposes.

subsection.text: “Legislative body” means the council, commissioners, or other legislative body of a political subdivision.
“Military personnel” includes all civilian and military employees of the military and naval forces of the United States and their families and other dependents who are living with them.
“Obligee” includes:

paragraph.text: a bondholder and a trustee for a bondholder;
a lessor that leases to the authority property used in connection with a housing project, and an assignee of all or part of the lessor’s interest; and
the State or federal government when it is a party to a contract with an authority.

subsection.text: “Person” means an individual, a receiver, a trustee, a guardian, a personal representative, a fiduciary, a representative of any kind, a partnership, a firm, an association, a corporation, a public corporation, or any other entity.
“Person of eligible income” means an individual or family that qualifies under § 12-106 of this subtitle.
“Political subdivision” means a county or municipal corporation of the State.
“Pre-existing authority” means an authority that was activated before July 1, 1990.
“Real property” includes:

paragraph.text: land;
improvements and fixtures on the land;
property of any nature appurtenant to or used in connection with the land; and
each legal or equitable estate, interest, and right in the land, including:

subparagraph.text: terms for years and liens by way of judgment, mortgage, or otherwise; and
the indebtedness secured by those liens.

subsection.text: “State public body” means any political subdivision, commission, district, authority, or unit of the State.

section.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: there is unsanitary or unsafe housing in which individuals of low and moderate income are forced to live;
there is a shortage of safe or sanitary housing that is available at rents that individuals of low and moderate income can afford, forcing these individuals to live in overcrowded housing;
there are many families living in housing that, while decent and safe, is inadequate for the size of the family;
the conditions:

subparagraph.text: cause disease and crime to increase and spread, threaten the public health, safety, morals, and welfare, and impair economic values; and
cause too much public money to be spent for crime prevention and punishment, public health and safety, fire and accident protection, and other public services and facilities;

paragraph.text: construction of housing projects for individuals of low and moderate income does not compete with private enterprise because:

subparagraph.text: there are economically depressed or physically deteriorated areas that cannot be assisted through the private housing market; and
the private housing market cannot relieve the shortage of safe and sanitary housing for individuals of low and moderate income;

paragraph.text: clearing, replanning, and reconstructing areas in which unsanitary or unsafe housing exists and providing safe and sanitary housing for persons of low and moderate income are public purposes and essential governmental functions for which public money may be spent and private property acquired;
it is the policy of the State to develop safe, sanitary, and decent housing for State residents;

there is a need for available mortgage credit because many purchasers and owners of housing cannot afford mortgage credit at the market interest rate or get mortgage credit because the mortgage credit market is severely restricted; and
this Division II is needed in the public interest.

section.text: The purpose of this Division II is to authorize each authority to do all that is necessary or desirable to secure the financial aid or cooperation of political subdivisions, State government, or federal government to help the authority undertake, construct, maintain, or operate a housing project.

subsection.text: In this section, “Baltimore Housing Authority entity” means an entity:

paragraph.text: that is wholly owned by the Housing Authority of Baltimore City; or
in which the Housing Authority of Baltimore City or an entity wholly owned by the Housing Authority of Baltimore City has an ownership interest.

In this subsection, “nonprofit housing corporation” means a nonprofit or charitable private corporation that provides safe and sanitary housing to persons of eligible income in such a way that the corporation works essentially like an authority under this Division II.
Property is used for essential public and governmental purposes and is exempt from all taxes and special assessments of the State or a political subdivision if the property:

subparagraph.text: belongs to an authority or a nonprofit housing corporation; or
is used as housing for persons of eligible income and belongs to a Baltimore Housing Authority entity.

paragraph.text: In lieu of those taxes and special assessments, an authority, a nonprofit housing corporation, or a Baltimore Housing Authority entity shall pay the political subdivision in which a housing project is wholly or partly located an amount, if any, that may be set by mutual agreement and that does not exceed the amount of regular taxes levied on similar property.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) or (3) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: all real property of an authority is exempt from levy and sale by virtue of an execution;
an execution or other judicial process may not issue against the real property; and
a judgment against an authority is not a charge or lien on the authority’s real property.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not limit a right to foreclose or otherwise enforce:

subparagraph.text: a mortgage or deed of trust recorded against property of an authority; or
a pledge or lien given by an authority on its rents, fees, or revenues.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not deprive a political subdivision of its right to collect money agreed to be paid in lieu of taxes in the same manner as taxes are now or may be collected under State law and the laws of the political subdivision.

subsection.text: An authority of a municipal corporation or Baltimore City may:

paragraph.text: operate within its territorial boundaries; and
without regard to location:

subparagraph.text: administer rent subsidy payments and housing assistance programs for both eligible landlords and tenants;
own or manage housing projects in operation before January 1, 1990; and
develop, own, or operate a housing project at the request of and within the territorial boundaries of another political subdivision.

paragraph.text: Anywhere in its county an authority of a county may:

subparagraph.text: administer rent subsidy payments and housing assistance programs for both eligible landlords and tenants; and
own or manage housing projects in operation before:

sub-subparagraph.text: January 1, 1990, if the authority is of Baltimore City; or
January 1, 1991, if the authority is of another county.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, an authority of a county may conduct its other operations within the county.

An authority of a county other than Baltimore City may not conduct its other operations within a municipal corporation unless the governing body of the municipal corporation consents by resolution to its inclusion in the authority’s area of operation.

subsection.text: An authority created under § 12–208 of this title may conduct its operations in the area prescribed under its articles of organization.
An individual or family qualifies as a person of eligible income:

paragraph.text: for projects that are State or federally funded, if the individual or family meets the income requirements of the State or federal program involved; or

for other projects, if the individual or family, by a determination under subsection (b) of this section, lacks sufficient income or assets without financial assistance to purchase or rent decent, safe, and sanitary housing without overcrowding.

The chief elected official or the chief elected official’s designee, who may be the executive director of an authority or the board of commissioners of the authority, shall determine whether an individual or family qualifies as a person of eligible income under subsection (a)(2) of this section.

Determination of qualifying income levels may vary for the elderly, individuals with disabilities, other persons with special needs, particular projects or programs, or particular parts of the political subdivision.

section.text: A provision applicable to a particular political subdivision or its authority in another title of this Division II:

paragraph.text: takes precedence over a conflicting provision of this title; and
may not be used to interpret how this title applies to another political subdivision or its authority.

section.text: Except as provided in § 12–208 of this subtitle, in each political subdivision, there is a public body corporate and politic known as the “housing authority” of the political subdivision or as otherwise designated in the articles of organization.
Sections 12-203 through 12-206 of this subtitle are only enabling legislation allowing a political subdivision to authorize an authority to operate in the political subdivision.
A code authority may not do business or exercise its powers unless:

paragraph.text: its articles of organization have been recommended in writing by the chief elected official, adopted by a resolution or ordinance of the legislative body, and filed with the Secretary of State; and
the Secretary of State has issued a certificate of organization to the code authority.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 12–208 of this subtitle, each pre–existing authority continues to exist.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, a pre-existing authority governed only by this title:

subparagraph.text: may exercise the powers granted by Subtitles 6 and 7 and §§ 12-501, 12-502, 12-504, and 12-506(a) of this title; and

if it adopts articles of organization, may exercise the powers listed in § 12-503 of this title that are authorized by the articles of organization in accordance with § 12-205(b)(1)(vi) of this subtitle; and
is entitled to the exemptions from State law provided in § 12-505 of this title.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, a pre-existing authority governed by this title and by a title in this Division II that is applicable in a particular political subdivision:

subparagraph.text: may exercise the powers granted under the title that applies to the particular political subdivision;
may exercise the powers granted by Subtitles 6 and 7 and §§ 12-501, 12-502, 12-504, and 12-506(a) of this title as modified by the title that applies to the particular political subdivision;

if it adopts articles of organization, may exercise the powers listed in § 12-503 of this title that are authorized by the articles of organization in accordance with § 12-205(b)(1)(vi) of this subtitle; and
is entitled to the exemptions from State law provided in § 12-505 of this title.

paragraph.text: If articles of organization are adopted, the powers set forth in §§ 12-501 through 12-506(a) of this title may be limited to the extent allowed under §§ 12-205(b)(2) and 12-207 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Articles of organization, if they are not inconsistent with this title, may be adopted for an authority governed by another title in this Division II.

paragraph.text: Articles of organization shall state:

subparagraph.text: the name of the authority, which may be “housing authority of (here insert name of political subdivision)” or some other name that includes the name of the political subdivision;
that a need exists for the authority to function in the political subdivision;
whether appointments of commissioners of the authority by the chief elected official require the prior approval of the legislative body;
whether the board of commissioners of the authority will consist of five, seven, or nine commissioners;
whether commissioners of the authority will have 3- or 5-year terms;
whether the authority may exercise any power set forth in § 12-503 of this title, and, if so, any limitations on those powers; and
any limitation on or elimination of any power granted to the authority under any title of this Division II.

paragraph.text: The powers of the authority:

subparagraph.text: shall be sufficient for it to comply with each existing agreement between it and a State or federal governmental unit and with federal law; and
may not be limited in a way that is inconsistent with such an agreement or with federal law.

paragraph.text: The articles of organization of an authority shall designate an official of the political subdivision to be the custodian of records of the political subdivision for the purposes of this Division II.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the articles of organization may contain specific terms governing the operation of the authority and its housing projects, including financial reporting, budgetary, and personnel requirements.
The specific terms may not add powers to the authority other than those allowed under subsection (b)(1)(vi) of this section and may not be inconsistent with:

subparagraph.text: any existing agreement between the authority and any State or federal governmental unit;
federal law; or
this Division II or other State law.

subsection.text: Articles of organization may not require the authority directly or indirectly to pay any of its reserves or other money to the political subdivision.

The custodian of records shall file with the Secretary of State a certified copy of the written recommendation of the chief elected official and the resolution or ordinance adopting the articles of organization.

paragraph.text: If the Secretary of State finds that the requirements of § 12-203 of this subtitle have been met, the Secretary of State shall endorse the articles of organization “approved” and issue to the authority a certificate of approval attached to them and a certificate of organization.
On issuance of the certificate of approval, the articles of organization as filed are considered to have been adopted.

subsection.text: The Secretary of State:

paragraph.text: shall record and maintain all endorsed articles of organization and amendments in records kept for that purpose; and
on request, shall issue certified copies of the endorsed articles of organization and amendments.

In a proceeding involving or relating to a contract of an authority, the authority is considered to be authorized to do business and exercise its powers if the Secretary of State has issued a certificate of organization.
A copy of the certificate of organization is admissible in evidence.
A pre-existing authority may be governed by articles of organization if:

subparagraph.text: the pre-existing authority meets the requirements of subsection (b) or (c) of this section;
the custodian of records files with the Secretary of State the documents required under subsection (d) of this section; and
the Secretary of State issues a certificate of approval in accordance with subsection (e) of this section.

paragraph.text: Articles of organization shall comply with § 12-205(b) through (d) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Before a pre-existing authority may adopt articles of organization under this subsection, the articles of organization must be:

paragraph.text: recommended in writing by the chief elected official;
approved by an extraordinary majority of the board of commissioners of the authority; and
adopted by an extraordinary majority of the legislative body.

subsection.text: Before a pre-existing authority may adopt articles of organization under this subsection:

paragraph.text: the custodian of records shall provide documentation to the Secretary of State that within 5 years before the date the documentation is submitted:

subparagraph.text: the political subdivision, within each of any 3 fiscal years within the 5-year period, has provided financial assistance to the authority from local tax revenues or bond sale proceeds in an amount equal to the greater of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the product of $1 times the number of residents of the political subdivision as published annually by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene or as otherwise available; and
the product of $100 times the total number of housing units owned or managed by the authority; and

subparagraph.text: the authority, at the request and with the financial support of the political subdivision, is operating one or more housing projects for which the federal government provided no more than half of the development and operating costs; and

paragraph.text: the articles of organization must be:

subparagraph.text: recommended in writing by the chief elected official;
approved by a resolution of the board of commissioners of the authority; and
adopted by a resolution or ordinance of the legislative body.

subsection.text: The custodian of records shall file with the Secretary of State:

paragraph.text: a copy of the documentation described in subsection (c)(1) of this section, if applicable;
the articles of organization and the applicable recommending, approving, and adopting instruments described in subsection (b) or (c)(2) of this section;

certification by the custodian of records that the articles of organization have been recommended and adopted by the political subdivision in accordance with the applicable requirements of subsection (b)(1) and (3) or subsection (c)(2)(i) and (iii) of this section; and

certification by the secretary of the pre-existing authority that the articles of organization have been approved by the board of commissioners of the authority in accordance with the applicable requirements of subsection (b)(2) or subsection (c)(2)(ii) of this section.

If the Secretary of State finds that the requirements of subsection (b) or (c) and subsection (d) of this section have been satisfied, the Secretary of State shall endorse the articles as “approved” and issue a certificate of approval attached to the endorsed articles.
When the certificate of approval is issued, the articles of organization as filed are considered to have been adopted.

subsection.text: Articles of amendment or restatement of articles of organization of an authority must be:

paragraph.text: recommended in writing by the chief elected official;
if required by subsection (d) of this section, approved by a resolution of the board of commissioners of the authority; and
adopted by a resolution or ordinance of the legislative body.

subsection.text: An amendment or restatement of articles of organization shall comply with § 12-205(b) through (d) of this subtitle.

A political subdivision may not amend the articles of organization to change the number of commissioners of an authority or the length of terms of commissioners stated in the initial articles of organization.
A political subdivision may not amend the articles of organization of a pre-existing authority without the approval of the board of commissioners of the pre-existing authority.
The custodian of records shall file with the Secretary of State:

paragraph.text: a copy of the articles of amendment or restatement, the recommending and adopting instruments required by subsection (a)(1) and (3) of this section, and any approving instrument required by subsection (a)(2) of this section;

the certification of the custodian of records that the articles of amendment or restatement have been recommended and adopted by the political subdivision in accordance with the requirements of subsection (a)(1) and (3) of this section; and

if required by subsection (a)(2) of this section, the certification of the secretary of the authority that the articles of amendment or restatement have been approved by the board of commissioners of the authority in accordance with the requirements of subsection (a)(2) of this section.

If the Secretary of State finds that the requirements of subsections (a) and (e) of this section have been met, the Secretary of State shall endorse the articles of amendment or restatement as “approved” and issue an attached certificate of approval.
On issuance of the certificate of approval, the articles of amendment or restatement as filed are considered to have been adopted.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Consolidation” means the dissolution of separate existing authorities and the simultaneous creation of a new authority.
“Merger” means the absorption of one existing authority by another existing authority in which the one authority dissolves and the other authority continues to exist.

subsection.text: The Housing Commission of Talbot County and the St. Michaels Housing Authority may unite by consolidation or merger to form one authority.

paragraph.text: The unification of the Housing Commission of Talbot County and the St. Michaels Housing Authority shall be initiated by the passage of a proposal of unification in substantially the same form by the legislative body of the Town of Easton and the legislative body of the Town of St. Michaels.
The proposal of unification shall:

subparagraph.text: include a description of the boundaries of the area of operation for the proposed authority; and

be approved by each municipal corporation in the same manner provided for the adoption of a resolution or ordinance in the charter or bylaws of the municipal corporation that is considering the proposal of unification.

paragraph.text: After both municipal corporations approve a proposal of unification, each municipal corporation shall appoint an equal number of representatives, which may not be less than three nor more than five, to a commission charged with drafting articles of organization for the proposed authority.
The members of the commission shall:

subparagraph.text: adopt rules and elect officers to govern their meetings and expedite the drafting of the articles of organization; and
complete a draft of the articles of organization no later than 6 months after the approval of the proposals of unification.

paragraph.text: In the draft articles of organization or in a separate document, the commission shall:

subparagraph.text: describe the boundaries of the area of operation for the proposed authority; and
provide for:

sub-subparagraph.text: the disposition of any debts, bonds, and other obligations of the Housing Commission of Talbot County and any debts, bonds, and other obligations of the St. Michaels Housing Authority;
the transfer to the proposed authority of any property and other assets of the Housing Commission of Talbot County and any property and other assets of the St. Michaels Housing Authority; and
the designation of the chief elected official, custodian of records, and legislative body of which municipal corporation that shall govern the operations of the proposed authority.

paragraph.text: The commission created under subsection (d) of this section shall submit the draft articles of organization to the legislative body of each municipal corporation for adoption or rejection.
The legislative body of each municipal corporation must adopt or reject the draft articles of organization as a whole.
No amendment or change may be made to the draft articles of organization unless the legislative body of each municipal corporation concurs in the amendment or change.

If the legislative body of each municipal corporation adopts the draft articles of organization, the appropriate custodian of records shall file the articles of organization with the Secretary of State.

If the Secretary of State finds that the appropriate requirements of §§ 12–205 and 12–206 of this subtitle have been satisfied, the Secretary of State shall endorse the articles as “approved” and issue a certificate of approval attached to the endorsed articles of organization.
When the certificate of approval is issued, the articles of organization as filed are considered to have been adopted.
An authority created under this section may not do business or exercise its powers unless the Secretary of State has issued a certificate of approval.

section.text: The required number of commissioners of an authority:

paragraph.text: for an authority not governed by articles of organization, is five; and
for an authority governed by articles of organization, is the number set forth in the articles of organization as required by § 12-205(b)(1)(iv) of this title.

subsection.text: The chief elected official shall appoint the required number of commissioners of the authority.

paragraph.text: A certificate of the appointment of a commissioner of an authority shall be filed with the custodian of records.
The certificate is conclusive evidence of the appointment.

subsection.text: A commissioner of an authority may not be an employee of the authority.

paragraph.text: If an authority is governed by articles of organization, only one commissioner of the authority may be an employee of the political subdivision.
Otherwise, a commissioner of an authority may not be an employee of the political subdivision.

subsection.text: A commissioner of an authority may not be an elected official of the political subdivision.
This subtitle does not bar a tenant of a housing project or of property included or planned to be included in a housing project from being a commissioner of an authority.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to authorities for which the Secretary of State approves articles of organization on or after July 1, 1990.
All initial appointments of commissioners of an authority after the Secretary of State approves the articles of organization shall have the same effective date.
The effective date shall be set forth along with the term of appointment on each initial certificate of appointment required by § 12-302(b) of this subtitle.
For authorities whose articles of organization say that commissioners of the authority have 5-year terms, those who are initially appointed shall have staggered terms of:

subparagraph.text: 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 years for five-member authorities;
1, 2, 3, 3, 4, 5, and 5 years for seven-member authorities; and
1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 4, 4, 5, and 5 years for nine-member authorities.

paragraph.text: For authorities whose articles of organization say that commissioners of the authority have 3-year terms, those who are initially appointed shall have staggered terms of:

subparagraph.text: 1, 2, 2, 3, and 3 years for five-member authorities;
1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 3, and 3 years for seven-member authorities; and
1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2, 3, 3, and 3 years for nine-member authorities.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding § 12-311 of this subtitle, a commissioner of an authority who is an employee of the political subdivision serves at the pleasure of the chief elected official.
The term of a commissioner of an authority who was in office before the adoption of articles of organization ends on the effective date of the initial appointments under the articles of organization.

Except as provided in paragraphs (3) and (4) of this subsection, before the effective date of the initial appointments under the articles of organization, the chief elected official shall appoint each commissioner of an authority who was in office before the adoption of the articles of organization to a term as a commissioner of the authority under the articles of organization.
A commissioner of an authority who has delivered to the chief elected official written notice declining appointment may not be appointed under this subsection.

If the number of commissioners of an authority is reduced by the articles of organization so that there are not enough places for all those who did not decline appointment, the chief elected official shall choose which ones to appoint, and when they are appointed and qualify they are the successors of all those who were in office before the adoption of the articles of organization.

Notwithstanding § 12-205(b)(1)(iii) of this title, any other provision of this Division II, and the articles of organization, an appointment under this subsection does not require approval of the legislative body.

subsection.text: If an authority is not governed by articles of organization:

paragraph.text: commissioners of the authority who are initially appointed shall have terms of 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 years; and
each term thereafter shall be 5 years.
At the end of a term, a commissioner of an authority serves until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A commissioner of an authority who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The chief elected official shall choose as chair a commissioner who is appointed when the authority is first activated.
When the office of the chair becomes vacant thereafter, the authority shall choose a chair from among its commissioners.

subsection.text: An authority shall choose a vice chair from among its commissioners.
The powers of each authority are vested in the commissioners.
A quorum is:

paragraph.text: three commissioners of a five-member authority;
four commissioners of a seven-member authority; or
five commissioners of a nine-member authority.
