subsection.text: An authority may take action on a vote of a majority of the commissioners present at a meeting at which there is a quorum, unless a larger number is required by law or the bylaws of the authority.

section.text: With the approval of the legislative body, a commissioner of an authority may receive reasonable compensation for the commissioner’s services and is entitled to the necessary expenses, including traveling expenses, incurred in the discharge of the commissioner’s duties.

paragraph.text: An authority may employ:

subparagraph.text: a secretary, who shall serve as executive director; and
technical experts and other officers, agents, and employees, permanent and temporary.

paragraph.text: An authority shall determine the qualifications, duties, and compensation of its employees.

subsection.text: For legal services, an authority may use the chief law officer of the political subdivision or may employ its own counsel and legal staff.
An authority may delegate to one or more of its agents or employees the powers or duties it considers proper.
Each commissioner, the executive director, and each employee of an authority is:

paragraph.text: a local official for the purposes of Title 15, Subtitle 8, Part I of the State Government Article and subject to local ethics laws; and
an employee of a local government for the purposes of Title 5, Subtitle 3 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article and entitled to the protections of the Local Government Tort Claims Act.

subsection.text: A commissioner of an authority is not liable for a statement made or action taken in good faith in the exercise or performance of a power or duty of the commissioner.

Except for bonds purchased before appointment and interests in mutual funds, a commissioner or employee of an authority may not acquire any direct or indirect interest in a housing project or in property included or planned to be included in a housing project.

A commissioner or employee of an authority may not have any direct or indirect interest in a contract or proposed contract for materials or services to be furnished or used in connection with a housing project.

paragraph.text: A commissioner or employee of an authority who owns or controls a direct or indirect interest in property included or planned to be included in a housing project shall immediately disclose the interest in writing to the authority.
The disclosure shall be entered in the minutes of the authority.
Failure to disclose the interest is misconduct in office.

subsection.text: A commissioner of an authority may be removed by the chief elected official in accordance with this section for neglect of duty or misconduct in office, including violations of local ethics laws and misconduct identified in § 12-310 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The chief elected official shall file charges with the office of the custodian of records and promptly deliver a copy of the charges to the commissioner and to the secretary of the authority.
Written notice of the date, time, and place of a hearing shall be given to the commissioner at least 14 days before the hearing.

Unless the commissioner has resigned from office, the chief elected official shall hold the hearing, at which the commissioner shall have an opportunity to be represented by counsel and to be heard in person.
On completion of the hearing, the chief elected official shall make written findings.

subsection.text: If a commissioner of an authority is removed, a record of the proceedings and the charges and findings shall be filed in the office of the custodian of records.

paragraph.text: On the filing of charges under subsection (b)(1) of this section with the office of the custodian of records, the chief elected official may temporarily suspend a commissioner of an authority.
The chief elected official shall immediately reinstate the commissioner in office if the chief elected official finds the charges have not been substantiated.
The commissioner shall be reinstated automatically, unless a hearing on removal has been held and a decision made by the chief elected official within 45 days after the filing of charges.
The chief elected official may not temporarily appoint a person to perform the duties of a suspended member.
When a code authority becomes authorized to do business and exercise its powers, the political subdivision:

subparagraph.text: immediately shall estimate the amount of money necessary for the administrative expenses and overhead of the code authority during the first year thereafter; and
shall appropriate that amount to the code authority out of money in the political subdivision’s treasury not appropriated to some other purpose.

paragraph.text: The political subdivision shall pay the money appropriated to the code authority as a donation.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the political subdivision shall appropriate to the code authority money needed to comply with any requirement imposed on it by its articles of organization, if enough money for the code authority to comply is not available from State, federal, or other sources.
A political subdivision is not required to provide any money for a code authority to satisfy a judgment, liability, debt, or other financial obligation to a third party.
A political subdivision located wholly or partly in the area of operation of a code authority may lend, donate, or agree to lend or donate money to the code authority.
The code authority, when it has the money available, shall reimburse the political subdivision for all loans made to it by the political subdivision.

subsection.text: It is State policy that an authority:

paragraph.text: shall manage and operate its housing projects efficiently to enable it to fix the rent for housing units at the lowest rates consistent with its providing decent, safe, and sanitary housing units and meeting the financial needs under subsection (b) of this section; but
may not operate for profit or as a source of revenue to the political subdivision.

subsection.text: An authority shall fix the rents for housing units in its housing projects at rates no higher than it finds necessary to produce revenues that with all other available money, revenue, income, and receipts will be sufficient to:

paragraph.text: pay the principal and interest on bonds of the authority, as they become due;
pay and provide for maintaining and operating the housing projects, including the cost of insurance and the administrative expenses of the authority;

subparagraph.text: create during a period of at least 6 years right after it issues any bonds, a reserve that can meet the largest principal and interest payments that will be due on the bonds in any year thereafter; and
maintain the reserve;

paragraph.text: create reserves for operations, emergencies, renovations, replacements, and the repayment of debt; and
create funds necessary or desirable to:

subparagraph.text: subsidize rents;
develop or operate housing projects; or
operate or provide services located in housing projects or that otherwise benefit their residents.

section.text: Except for rental units that may be occupied by others under § 12-503(a)(4) of this title, an authority:

paragraph.text: shall rent the housing units in a housing project only:

subparagraph.text: to persons of eligible income, except for a reasonable number of housing units that may be occupied by management and security personnel; and
at rentals within the financial reach of persons of eligible income;

paragraph.text: may not accept a person as a tenant in a housing project if the aggregate annual income of the person or persons who would occupy the housing unit exceeds the maximum income level established for persons of eligible income; and
shall prohibit subletting by tenants.

section.text: Except as provided in § 12-506(b)(9) of this title, all housing projects of an authority are subject to the planning, zoning, sanitary, health, fire, housing, subdivision, and building laws, ordinances, codes, rules, and regulations that apply where the housing project is located.

subsection.text: At least annually, an authority shall file with the custodian of records a financial report of its activities for the preceding year and recommend any further action by the political subdivision that it considers necessary or useful to carry out the purpose of this Division II.
The political subdivision may require an authority to provide it with an annual operating budget and program reports that the political subdivision designates.
The political subdivision or its designee may at any time:

paragraph.text: examine the books and records of the authority; or
conduct an audit of the authority.

section.text: This subtitle does not limit the power of an authority to vest in an obligee the right, if the authority defaults, to:

paragraph.text: take possession of a housing project;
have a receiver of a housing project appointed; or
acquire title to a housing project, through foreclosure or otherwise, free from all restrictions of this subtitle.

section.text: An authority is a public body corporate and politic that:

paragraph.text: exercises public and essential governmental functions; and
has all the powers necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes of this Division II.

subsection.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, an authority has the powers set forth in this section.
An authority may:

paragraph.text: sue and be sued;
have and alter a seal at pleasure;
have perpetual existence;
make contracts and other instruments necessary or convenient to the exercise of the authority’s powers;
make, amend, and repeal bylaws, rules, and regulations not inconsistent with this Division II; and
carry out the purposes of the authority.

subsection.text: An authority may also:

paragraph.text: prepare, carry out, acquire, own, lease, and operate housing projects in its area of operation;
provide for the construction, reconstruction, improvement, alteration, or repair of a housing project;

provide directly or arrange or contract for a person or governmental unit to furnish facilities or services, including drug rehabilitation, elderly or child day care, and other social services for or in connection with:

subparagraph.text: a housing project; or
the residents of a housing project; and

paragraph.text: notwithstanding any other law, require in a contract in connection with a housing project that the contractor and any subcontractors comply with:

subparagraph.text: requirements about minimum wages and maximum hours of labor; and
any conditions that the State or federal government attaches to financial aid for the housing project.

subsection.text: An authority may also:

paragraph.text: make rent subsidy payments to or on behalf of persons of eligible income;
rent out houses, accommodations, lands, buildings, structures, or facilities in a housing project;
subject to the limitations contained in this Division II, establish and revise the rents or charges;
own, hold, and improve real and personal property;
purchase, lease, obtain options on, or acquire by gift, grant, bequest, devise, or otherwise any real or personal property;
sell, lease, exchange, transfer, assign, pledge, or dispose of any real or personal property;
insure or provide for the insurance of real or personal property or operations of the authority against any risks or hazards; and

get from the State or federal government insurance or guarantees of payment of debts secured by mortgages on property in any of its housing projects, whether or not the debts are incurred by the authority.

When an authority has money that is held in a reserve or sinking fund or is not needed for immediate disbursement, the authority may invest the money in property or securities in which savings banks may invest.
An authority may purchase its bonds at not more than their principal amount and accrued interest, all bonds so purchased to be canceled.

subsection.text: An authority may also:

paragraph.text: investigate living and housing conditions in its area of operation and ways to improve those conditions;
determine where:

subparagraph.text: economically depressed or physically deteriorated areas exist; or
there is a shortage of decent, safe, and sanitary housing for persons of eligible income;

paragraph.text: make studies and recommendations on clearing, replanning, and reconstructing economically depressed or physically deteriorated areas and providing housing for persons of eligible income;
cooperate with the State or a political subdivision to solve the problems set forth in this subsection; and
conduct research, studies, and experiments on housing issues.

subsection.text: Acting through one or more of its commissioners or designees, an authority may also:

paragraph.text: examine, investigate, hear testimony, and take evidence at public or private hearings on any matter material to its duties;
make findings and recommendations about any property where conditions pose a danger to the public health, morals, safety, or welfare; and
make those findings and recommendations available to appropriate governmental units, including those that in its area of operation have the duty to:

subparagraph.text: abate or require the correction of nuisances or like conditions; or
demolish unsafe or unsanitary structures.

subsection.text: An authority may also establish and control not-for-profit entities, including corporations and limited liability companies, that may own, operate, and take steps necessary or convenient to develop or otherwise undertake housing projects in the authority’s area of operation.

paragraph.text: In the manner provided under Title 12 of the Real Property Article or any other applicable statutory law, an authority may also acquire by eminent domain real property that the authority considers necessary for its purposes under this Division II, if:

subparagraph.text: the authority adopts a resolution declaring that the acquisition of the real property is necessary for those purposes; and
the legislative body and the chief elected official approve.
Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, property devoted to a public use may similarly be acquired by eminent domain.
Real property that belongs to the State or a political subdivision may not be acquired without the consent of the State or the political subdivision.

subsection.text: An authority may also:

paragraph.text: borrow money and accept grants and other financial assistance from the political subdivision, the State, and the federal government and accept grants from nongovernmental sources for a housing project in its area of operation;
take over, lease, or manage a housing project or undertaking constructed, financed, or owned by the political subdivision, the State, or the federal government; and
comply with conditions and enter into mortgages, trust indentures, leases, and agreements as may be necessary or desirable.

subsection.text: If authorized under its articles of organization, an authority within its area of operation may:

paragraph.text: make mortgage loans and mortgage subsidy payments to or for the benefit of persons of eligible income;
make construction loans and long-term mortgage loans to any person to produce housing for persons of eligible income;
purchase mortgages secured by housing for persons of eligible income;

subject to any applicable agreement, allow a number of residents of a housing project or a part of one that the authority finances to have incomes above the levels for persons of eligible income, if the number does not exceed the percentage allowed in the articles of organization, which may not exceed 80%;

acquire, develop, construct, rehabilitate, own, operate, and lease, as lessor or lessee, commercial facilities on the site of a housing project that make an economic or social contribution to the housing project, if:

subparagraph.text: the commercial facilities are intended substantially for the use and benefit of the tenants of the housing project; and
the intended use by other persons is incidental;

paragraph.text: with the approval of the legislative body and the chief elected official, acquire, develop, construct, rehabilitate, own, operate, and lease, as lessor or lessee, commercial facilities that:

subparagraph.text: are adjacent to the site of a housing project;
are not intended substantially for the use and benefit of the tenants of the housing project; or
are intended for use more than incidentally by persons other than the tenants of the housing project; and

paragraph.text: act and invest as a general partner and as a limited partner in housing projects.

subsection.text: This section does not limit the powers granted to authorities by other titles in this Division II.
An authority may exercise the powers that are granted by this Division II, even if economic competition is displaced or limited as a result.
This section does not preempt or supersede the regulatory authority of a State unit under public general law.

section.text: Unless the General Assembly specifically states otherwise, State law on the financing, acquisition, operation, or disposition of property by other State public bodies does not apply to an authority.

subsection.text: Two or more authorities may join or cooperate with one another in the exercise of any power under this subtitle to finance, plan, undertake, construct, or operate a housing project or housing projects in the area of operation of any one or more of them.

To aid and cooperate in the planning, undertaking, construction, or operation of housing projects located wholly or partly in the area in which it may act, a State public body, with or without consideration and on terms that it determines, may:

paragraph.text: dedicate, sell, convey, or lease any of the State public body’s property to an authority or the federal government;

cause parks, playgrounds, recreational, community, water, sewer, or drainage facilities, or any other works that the State public body otherwise may undertake, to be furnished adjacent to or in connection with housing projects;
furnish, dedicate, close, pave, install, grade, regrade, plan, or replan streets, roads, roadways, alleys, sidewalks, or other places that the State public body otherwise may undertake;
make, with an authority, the State, or the federal government, agreements that:

subparagraph.text: deal with action to be taken by the State public body under a power granted by this Division II; and
may last for any length of time, notwithstanding any other law;

paragraph.text: do what is necessary or convenient to aid and cooperate in the planning, financing, undertaking, construction, or operation of the housing projects;
grant easements, licenses, or any other related rights to an authority or the federal government;
cause services to be furnished to the authority of the character that the State public body otherwise may furnish;
make agreements about the exercise by the State public body of its powers relating to repairing, closing, or demolishing unsafe, unsanitary, or unfit housing;

plan, replan, zone, or rezone any part of the State public body, make exceptions to its sanitary, building, housing, fire, health, subdivision, or other similar laws, rules, regulations, and ordinances or make any changes to its map or master plan; and
agree with an authority that the authority pay the State public body an amount, if any, in lieu of taxes for any year or period of years.

subsection.text: Powers conferred under this section on State public bodies are in addition to and do not supplant any other power conferred by law.

paragraph.text: The State public body may incur the entire expense of any public improvement that the State public body makes under this section.
Notwithstanding any other law, a State public body may make a sale, conveyance, lease, or agreement provided for in this section without appraisal, public notice, advertisement, or public bidding.

section.text: A State public body may not require changes to be made in a housing project or the manner of its construction or take any other action relating to the construction if the authority:

paragraph.text: has acquired or taken over the housing project from the federal government; and
has found and declared by resolution that the housing project was constructed in a way that will promote the public interest and afford necessary safety, sanitation, and other protection.

subsection.text: An authority may develop and administer projects to make safe and sanitary housing available for military personnel.

paragraph.text: An authority has all the rights, powers, privileges, and immunities under this subtitle that it has under any law relating to the ownership, development, or administration of housing projects for persons of eligible income.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a project is not subject to the limitations under §§ 12-401 and 12-402 of this title, or any other limitation on the amount of rentals or the eligibility of tenants, if an authority, or another authority cooperating with it, administers the project under this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: with financial aid from the federal government; or
as agent for the federal government.

paragraph.text: An authority may pay the amount that it finds necessary or desirable for any services, facilities, works, privileges, or improvements furnished for or in connection with housing for military personnel.

section.text: An authority may:

paragraph.text: exercise its powers to cooperate with, or act as agent for, the federal government in the development or administration of projects by the federal government to make safe and sanitary housing available for military personnel; and
develop or administer such a project for the federal government.

section.text: A State public body has the same rights and powers to cooperate with authorities in the development or administration of projects to make safe and sanitary housing available for military personnel that the State public body has under this Division II to assist in the development or administration of housing projects for persons of eligible income.

Bonds issued by an authority for a project developed or administered under this subtitle are legal investments to the same extent and for the same bodies and officers as bonds issued under any other section of this Division II to develop a housing project for persons of eligible income.

subsection.text: This subtitle is an independent authorization for an authority to:

paragraph.text: develop or administer projects to make safe and sanitary housing available for military personnel as provided in this Division II; and
cooperate with, or act as agent for, the federal government in the development or administration of similar projects by the federal government.

subsection.text: Except for laws relating to land acquisition, an authority acting under this subtitle is not subject to any limitation, restriction, or requirement of any other law that sets forth the procedure or action to develop or administer public works.
To develop speedily or administer projects for safe and sanitary housing for military personnel, an authority may do all that is necessary or desirable to:

paragraph.text: work with or act as agent for the federal government;
get financial aid; and
carry out the purposes of this subtitle.

section.text: An authority may exercise its powers anywhere in the State as an agent or lessee of the federal government in the development, construction, operation, or management of a project undertaken by the federal government for housing military personnel.

subsection.text: The powers conferred under this subtitle are in addition to and do not supplant any other powers conferred by law.
This subtitle does not limit any other power of an authority.
An authority may:

paragraph.text: issue bonds for any of its corporate purposes;
issue refunding bonds to pay or retire its bonds; and
issue any kinds of bonds, including bonds on which the principal and interest are payable:

subparagraph.text: only from the income and revenues of the housing project financed with the proceeds of the bonds or with these proceeds and a grant from the State or federal government in aid of the housing project;
only from the income and revenues of designated housing projects whether or not they were financed wholly or partly with the proceeds of the bonds; or
from its revenues generally.

subsection.text: To secure any of its bonds, an authority may pledge any revenue or mortgage a housing project or other property of the authority.
Bonds of an authority are issued for an essential public and governmental purpose.

paragraph.text: Neither a commissioner of an authority nor a person who executes the bond for an authority is personally liable on the bonds.
Neither the State nor a political subdivision is liable on the bonds.

subsection.text: The bonds of an authority:

paragraph.text: are not a debt of the State or a political subdivision and shall state so on their face;
are payable only out of money or property of the authority; and
are not an indebtedness for purposes of a constitutional or statutory debt limitation or restriction.

subsection.text: Bonds issued under this Division II and their transfer and the income from them, including any profit made on their sale, shall be free from taxation of every kind by the State and by all political subdivisions.
Bonds issued by an authority are negotiable for the purposes of the Maryland Uniform Commercial Code, subject to the registration provisions of the Code.

paragraph.text: Bonds issued by an authority are securities in which money may be invested by:

subparagraph.text: public officers and governmental units of the State or its political subdivisions;
banks, trust companies, savings and loan associations, investment companies, and others carrying on a banking business;
insurance companies, insurance associations, and others carrying on an insurance business;
personal representatives, guardians, trustees, and other fiduciaries; and
all other persons.

paragraph.text: Money that may be invested in the bonds includes capital that an investor owns or controls.

subsection.text: Bonds issued by an authority are securities that may be deposited with or received by any State or municipal officer, governmental unit, or political subdivision of the State for any purpose for which the deposit of bonds of the State is authorized by law.

paragraph.text: This subsection:

subparagraph.text: is intended only for any public approval requirement of the Internal Revenue Code relating to the issuance of tax-exempt obligations; and
does not determine whether an authority is a governmental unit of the State or of a political subdivision.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (1) of this subsection, an authority authorized under a resolution or ordinance of a political subdivision derives its authorization from the resolution or enactment rather than directly from State law.
Bonds of an authority shall be authorized by its resolution and may be issued in one or more series.
The resolution, the trust indenture, or the mortgage shall provide for the bonds:

subparagraph.text: a date or dates;
the time or times of maturity;
the interest rate or rates;
the denomination or denominations;
whether they will be in coupon or registered form;
the conversion or registration privileges;
their rank or priority;
the manner of execution;
the medium of payment;
the place or places of payment; and
the terms of redemption, with or without premium.

paragraph.text: Bonds may be sold at public or private sale in the manner and on the terms that a resolution of the authority authorizes.

subsection.text: If a commissioner or officer of the authority whose signature is on a bond or coupon leaves office before the bond is delivered, the signature nevertheless is valid and sufficient, the same as if the commissioner or officer had remained in office until delivery.

A bond reciting in substance that it has been issued by an authority to aid in financing a housing project to provide housing for persons of eligible income shall be considered to have been issued for that purpose in a proceeding involving the validity or enforceability of the bond or its security.
In connection with issuing bonds or incurring obligations under leases, and to secure payment of the bonds or obligations, an authority, in addition to its other powers, may:

paragraph.text: pledge any or all of the gross or net rents, fees, or revenues that are or will become due to it;
mortgage any or all of the real or personal property that it owns or will own;
covenant against:

subparagraph.text: pledging any or all of its rents, fees, or other revenue;
mortgaging any or all of the real or personal property that it owns or will own; or
suffering any lien on anything listed under item (i) or (ii) of this item;

paragraph.text: covenant about limits on its right to sell, lease, or dispose of all or part of a housing project;
covenant as to what other debts or obligations it may incur;
covenant as to:

subparagraph.text: the bonds to be issued;
their issuance, in escrow or otherwise; and
the use and disposition of their proceeds;

paragraph.text: provide for the replacement of lost, destroyed, or mutilated bonds;
covenant against extending the time for the payment of its bonds or interest on them;
redeem the bonds, covenant for their redemption, and provide the terms and conditions for their redemption;
covenant, subject to the limitations in this Division II, as to:

subparagraph.text: the rents and fees to be charged in the operation of a housing project or projects;
the amount to be raised each year or other period by rents, fees, and other revenues; and
the use and disposition of the rents, fees, and other revenues;

paragraph.text: create or authorize the creation of special funds for money held for construction or operating costs, debt service reserves, or other purposes, and covenant as to the use and disposition of the money held in those funds;

prescribe any procedure by which the terms of contracts with bondholders may be amended or abrogated, the dollar amount of bonds whose holders must consent to an amendment or abrogation, and the way in which consent may be given;

covenant as to the use of any or all of the authority’s real or personal property, the replacement of the property, the insurance to be carried on the property, and the use and disposition of insurance money;
covenant as to the rights, liabilities, powers, and duties arising on the breach by it of a covenant, condition, or obligation;

covenant and prescribe as to the events of default and terms and conditions on which any or all of its bonds become or may be declared due before maturity, and as to the terms and conditions on which a declaration and its consequences may be waived;
vest in a trustee or trustees or in the bondholders or any proportion of them the right to enforce:

subparagraph.text: payment of the bonds; or
covenants securing or relating to the bonds;

paragraph.text: vest in a trustee or trustees the right, if the authority defaults, to:

subparagraph.text: take in possession, use, operate, and manage all or part of a housing project;
collect the rents and revenues; and
dispose of the money in accordance with the agreement of the authority with the trustee or trustees;

paragraph.text: provide for the powers and duties of a trustee or trustees and limit the liabilities of the trustee or trustees;
provide the terms and conditions on which the trustee or trustees or bondholders or any proportion of them may enforce any covenant or rights securing or relating to the bonds;
make other covenants of a character like or unlike that of the covenants expressly authorized under this section; and
make covenants and do acts and things that, although not listed in this section:

subparagraph.text: are necessary, convenient, or desirable to secure the bonds of the authority; or
in the discretion of the authority, will tend to make the bonds more marketable.

paragraph.text: A pledge made by an authority is binding from the time the pledge is made.
The lien of the pledge, without any physical delivery or further act, attaches immediately to revenues or property pledged and thereafter received by an authority.
The lien is binding against all persons having claims against the authority, whether or not:

subparagraph.text: those persons have notice of the pledge; or
the determination or other instrument has been recorded or filed.

subsection.text: In addition to all other rights that a contract may confer on an obligee of an authority, subject only to binding contractual restrictions, the obligee may:

paragraph.text: by a writ of mandamus or a proceeding at law or in equity, compel the authority and the authority’s commissioners, officers, agents, or employees to perform each term, provision, and covenant contained in a contract of the authority with or for the benefit of the obligee;
require the carrying out of any covenant or agreement of the authority and the fulfillment of all duties imposed on the authority by this Division II; and
by a proceeding in equity, enjoin any unlawful act or thing or the violation of any right of the obligee.

By resolution, trust indenture, mortgage, lease, or other contract, an authority may confer the right to take action under subsection (c) of this section if a default, as defined in the resolution or instrument, occurs.
The right may be conferred on an obligee that:

subparagraph.text: holds or represents a specified amount in bonds or notes; or
holds a mortgage, deed of trust, security instrument, or lease.

paragraph.text: An obligee that has the right under subsection (b) of this section to take action under this subsection may, by a proceeding in a court of competent jurisdiction:

subparagraph.text: have possession of all or part of a housing project surrendered to any such obligee;
require the authority and its commissioners to account as if the authority and its commissioners were trustees of an express trust; and
have a receiver appointed for all or part of a housing project and its rents and profits.

paragraph.text: If a receiver is appointed, the receiver may:

subparagraph.text: enter and take possession of the housing project or any part of the housing project;
operate and maintain it; and
collect and receive all fees, rents, revenues, or other charges thereafter arising from it.

paragraph.text: The receiver shall keep the money in a separate account or accounts and apply the money in accordance with the obligations of the authority as the court directs.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Annapolis Authority” means the Housing Authority of the City of Annapolis.
“Commissioner” means a Commissioner of the Annapolis Authority.

section.text: Title 12 of this article applies to the Annapolis Authority except where it is inconsistent with this title.
The Housing Authority of the City of Annapolis is a public body corporate and politic that:

paragraph.text: exercises public and essential governmental functions; and
has all the powers necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes of this Division II.
The Annapolis Authority consists of seven Commissioners appointed by the Mayor of Annapolis and approved by the Annapolis City Council.
Of the seven Commissioners:

subparagraph.text: one shall be a tenant of an Annapolis Authority property other than an Annapolis Authority property for seniors; and
one shall be a tenant of an Annapolis Authority property for seniors.

paragraph.text: The term of a Commissioner is 5 years.
The terms of Commissioners are staggered as required by the terms provided for Commissioners on October 1, 2006.
At the end of a term, a Commissioner continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A Commissioner who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a Commissioner while in office and for 2 years after leaving office may not be employed by the Annapolis Authority for compensation on a permanent or temporary full-time, part-time, contractual, or other basis.

Subject to approval by the Mayor of Annapolis and by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, the prohibition contained in paragraph (1) of this subsection may be waived for good cause shown.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other law, the Annapolis Authority’s Commissioners, Executive Director, and deputy directors are local officials under any public ethics law of the Annapolis City Council.

paragraph.text: When first retained by the Annapolis Authority, attorneys and consultants shall disclose potential conflicts of interest relating to representation of the Annapolis Authority.
The Annapolis Authority shall adopt regulations to carry out this subsection.

section.text: The Annapolis Authority may remove the Executive Director by the affirmative vote of at least five Commissioners.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Annapolis Authority shall publish notice of each of its meetings in at least two newspapers of general circulation in the City of Annapolis at least 7 days before the meeting.
The notice shall contain:

subparagraph.text: the date, time, and place of the meeting; and
a summary of the subject matter to be considered at the meeting.

paragraph.text: The Chair of the Annapolis Authority may waive the notice required under paragraph (1) of this subsection for an emergency meeting if:

subparagraph.text: notice cannot reasonably be given; and
minutes of the emergency meeting will be included in the minutes of the next open meeting of the Annapolis Authority.

paragraph.text: The Annapolis Authority may add an item to the agenda for the meeting after publication of the notice if the item is necessary to the business of the Annapolis Authority and could not reasonably have been placed on the agenda when the notice was published.
The Annapolis Authority may meet in closed session or adjourn an open session and reconvene in a closed session only to:

subparagraph.text: discuss the appointment, employment, assignment, promotion, discipline, demotion, removal, or resignation of appointees, employees, or officials over whom the Annapolis Authority has jurisdiction;
consider the acquisition of real property for a public purpose and matters directly related to the acquisition;
consult with counsel;
consult with staff, consultants, or other individuals about pending or potential litigation;
comply with a specific constitutional, statutory, or judicially imposed requirement that prevents public disclosures about a particular proceeding or matter; or
satisfy an exceptional reason, if at least two-thirds of the Commissioners present vote to find that the reason is so compelling that it overrides the general public policy in favor of open sessions.

paragraph.text: The Annapolis Authority meeting in closed session under this section may not discuss or act on any matter not specified under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, unless the action is approved in advance by the Annapolis Authority at an open meeting, the Annapolis Authority may not:

paragraph.text: award a contract exceeding $5,000;
pay more than $350 for official travel, hotel, and meal expenses; or
pay more than $350 for items for personal use, including automobiles.

subsection.text: The Annapolis Authority may not reimburse a Commissioner or an employee for expenses incurred unless the reimbursement is approved in advance by the Annapolis Authority at an open meeting.

In an emergency, the Annapolis Authority or the Executive Director may award a contract exceeding $5,000 if the contract is brought before the Annapolis Authority for review at its next regularly scheduled meeting.

Money awarded or spent in violation of this section may be recovered by the Annapolis Authority or the City of Annapolis, as appropriate, from the person compensated, together with costs and reasonable attorney’s fees that the court determines.
The Annapolis Authority shall adopt purchasing provisions that conform to the Code of the City of Annapolis.
All purchases by the Annapolis Authority that are not specifically regulated by federal procurement requirements shall be made:

paragraph.text: as provided by the provisions adopted under this section; or
as approved by federal authorities.

subsection.text: At least 30 days before submission of the proposed annual operating budget to the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, the Annapolis Authority shall publish a brief summary of the proposed annual operating budget in at least two newspapers of general circulation in the City of Annapolis.

At least 2 weeks before the submission of a proposed annual operating budget, the Annapolis Authority shall hold an open meeting that gives the public an adequate opportunity to comment to the Executive Director of the Annapolis Authority and its Board of Commissioners.
At least 5 days before the open meeting required under subsection (b) of this section, the Annapolis Authority shall make the proposed annual operating budget available to the public.
Before March 1 of each year, the Annapolis Authority shall submit an audit of its books and records to the Mayor of Annapolis and City Council of Annapolis.
The audit shall:

paragraph.text: be performed in accordance with the federal Single Audit Act, 31 U.S.C. §§ 7501-7507;
follow generally accepted governmental auditing standards; and
be performed by an independent certified public accountant approved by the Annapolis Authority and by federal authorities.

section.text: Title 12 of this article applies to the Housing Commission of Anne Arundel County, formerly the Housing Authority of Anne Arundel County, except where it is inconsistent with this title.
The Housing Commission of Anne Arundel County is a public body corporate and politic that:

paragraph.text: exercises public and essential governmental functions; and
has all the powers necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes of this Division II.

subsection.text: The Housing Commission of Anne Arundel County consists of seven Commissioners, appointed by the County Executive.
The term of a Commissioner is 5 years.
The terms of the Commissioners are staggered as required by the terms provided for Commissioners of the Housing Commission of Anne Arundel County on October 1, 2006.
A Commissioner who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Baltimore Authority” means the Housing Authority of Baltimore City.

paragraph.text: “Housing project” means a work or undertaking that is planned, acquired, owned, used, developed, constructed, reconstructed, rehabilitated, or improved to provide:

subparagraph.text: housing, of which a substantial part shall be for persons of eligible income; and

streets, roads, sewers, water service, and other supporting public or private commercial, educational, cultural, recreational, community, or civic facilities that are needed for sound community development.

paragraph.text: “Housing project” includes lands, buildings, improvements, and other real or personal property.

subsection.text: “Person of eligible income” means an individual or a family that lacks sufficient income or assets without financial assistance to live in decent, safe, and sanitary housing without overcrowding.

section.text: Title 12 of this article applies to the Baltimore Authority except where it is inconsistent with this title.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: in Baltimore City and in the area of operation of the Baltimore Authority there is unsafe and unsanitary housing, and there is a critical shortage of decent, safe, and sanitary housing that persons of eligible income can afford to rent or buy;
as a result of this shortage, persons of eligible income must occupy overcrowded and congested housing or must pay too much of their income for shelter;
these conditions require too much public money to be spent for public health and safety, fire and accident protection, crime prevention and punishment, and other public services and facilities;

the shortage of decent, safe, and sanitary housing cannot be wholly relieved through private enterprise, and therefore building housing for persons of eligible income and spending public money to help get it built do not compete with private enterprise;

the construction and operation of housing to remedy the conditions described in this section and the implementation of this title are valid public purposes and essential government functions for which public money may be spent; and
the provisions of this title are necessary in the public interest.

section.text: The Housing Authority of Baltimore City is a public body corporate and politic that:

paragraph.text: exercises public and essential governmental functions; and
has all the powers necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes of this Division II.

subsection.text: In addition to the powers listed elsewhere in this Division II and any powers given by local law, the Baltimore Authority within its area of operation may:

paragraph.text: make mortgage loans;
make rent subsidy payments to or for persons of eligible income;
make construction loans and long-term mortgage loans to any person to produce housing for persons of eligible income; and
purchase and insure mortgages secured by housing for persons of eligible income.

subsection.text: Not more than 80% of the residents of a housing project may have incomes above the levels for persons of eligible income.
The listing of powers in this section does not imply that the exercise of those powers by the Baltimore Authority before July 1, 1990, was unauthorized.
The power of the Baltimore Authority to rent housing to persons of eligible income is not limited by § 12-402 of this article.

section.text: An employee of the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development or of any unit succeeding to its functions may be a Commissioner of the Baltimore Authority.
A housing project may not be commenced, arranged, contracted for, or carried out in the City of Baltimore unless the Board of Estimates of Baltimore City approves its location.

subsection.text: In this section, “Baltimore Authority police officer” means a member of the Housing Authority of Baltimore City Police Force who, when acting in an official capacity, may make arrests.
There is a Housing Authority of Baltimore City Police Force.
The Executive Director of the Baltimore Authority or the Director’s designee shall appoint the Baltimore Authority police officers.

paragraph.text: A Baltimore Authority police officer has all of the powers of a law enforcement officer in the State.
A Baltimore Authority police officer may exercise these powers on property that is owned, leased, operated by, or under the control of the Baltimore Authority.
A Baltimore Authority police officer may exercise these powers elsewhere only if:

subparagraph.text: doing so is necessary to facilitate the orderly flow of traffic to or from property that is owned, leased, operated by, or under the control of the Baltimore Authority; or
the officer is:

sub-subparagraph.text: ordered to do so by the Mayor of Baltimore City;
asked or authorized to do so by the Police Commissioner of Baltimore City; or
engaged in fresh pursuit of a suspected offender.

paragraph.text: The Baltimore Authority shall adopt standards, qualifications, and prerequisites of character, training, education, human and public relations, experience, and performance for Baltimore Authority police officers.
To the extent feasible, the standards shall be similar to those adopted for the Baltimore City Police Department.
This section does not:

subparagraph.text: treat a Baltimore Authority police officer as a member of the Baltimore City Police Department; or
affect the salary, benefits, or retirement program of an employee of the Baltimore Authority.

paragraph.text: The list of powers in this section does not imply that the exercise of powers by the Baltimore Authority before July 1, 1991, was unauthorized.
The Baltimore Authority may recognize and engage in collective bargaining with the exclusive bargaining representatives of all appropriate employee bargaining units, including units consisting of:

subparagraph.text: maintenance, housekeeping, and technical personnel;
administrative and clerical personnel; and
supervisory personnel.

paragraph.text: The power under paragraph (1) of this section includes the power of the Baltimore Authority to:

subparagraph.text: deal with and, through an exclusive bargaining representative, address grievances and settle disputes;
meet and bargain in good faith with an exclusive bargaining representative about wages, hours, working conditions, and other terms and conditions of employment to form a binding labor agreement; and
draft and execute labor agreements that last not more than 3 consecutive fiscal years.

paragraph.text: A bargaining unit under paragraph (1) of this subsection may not include:

subparagraph.text: confidential employees;
contractual employees employed for less than 5 consecutive years;
probationary employees;
attorneys in the general counsel’s office;
supervisors, as defined in 29 U.S.C. § 152(11); or
employees whose main responsibility is to manage or direct independently the assets and affairs of the Baltimore Authority.

subsection.text: The Baltimore Authority may engage in binding third-party arbitration of:

paragraph.text: disputes over a term or condition of employment; and
grievances that relate to the interpretation or application of a written collective bargaining agreement, employment regulation, or work rule.

subsection.text: The Baltimore Authority may exercise any power that is necessary and appropriate to establish and implement a system of collective bargaining with its employees.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commissioner” means a Commissioner of the Montgomery Commission.

“Housing project” means an undertaking or project, including lands, buildings and improvements, and real and personal property, that is planned, acquired, owned, used, developed, constructed, reconstructed, rehabilitated, or improved to provide:

paragraph.text: housing, a substantial part of which is for persons of eligible income; and
streets, roads, sewer and water service, and other supporting public or private commercial, educational, cultural, recreational, community, or civic facilities needed for sound community development.

subsection.text: “Montgomery Commission” means the Housing Opportunities Commission of Montgomery County.
“Person of eligible income” means an individual or family that qualifies under § 16-108 of this subtitle.

section.text: Title 12 of this article applies to the Montgomery Commission except where it is inconsistent with this title.
This title applies only to Montgomery County.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: there is unsafe and unsanitary housing in the county and there is a critical shortage of decent, safe, and sanitary housing that persons of eligible income can afford to rent or buy;
as a result, persons of eligible income must occupy overcrowded and congested housing or must pay too much of their income for shelter;
these conditions cause too much public money to be spent for crime prevention and punishment, public health and safety, fire and accident protection, and other public services and facilities;
there is a public emergency in the county caused in part by rapidly rising construction costs, operating and maintenance expenses, and the increase in conversions of rental housing to condominiums;
the serious problems created by these inflationary conditions and conversions include:

subparagraph.text: a major displacement of large numbers of tenants, including elderly individuals and individuals with disabilities, from their housing;
a scarcity of low and moderate income housing on the market as demand for such housing increases;
too few rental units available, planned, or under construction to replace the rental units being converted into condominiums; and
frustration of general plan concepts of balanced housing mix and adequate housing for all economic segments of the community;

paragraph.text: the shortage of decent, safe, and sanitary housing cannot be wholly relieved through private enterprise, and therefore building housing for persons of eligible income and spending public money to help get it built or ready for use do not compete with private enterprise;
to remedy these conditions, construction and operation of such housing as set forth in this title are valid public purposes and essential government functions for which public money may be spent; and
this title is necessary in the public interest.

section.text: The Housing Opportunities Commission of Montgomery County, formerly the Housing Authority of Montgomery County, is a public body corporate and politic that:

paragraph.text: exercises public and essential governmental functions; and
has all the powers necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes of this Division II.
The Montgomery Commission consists of seven Commissioners nominated by the County Executive and approved by the County Council.
The County Council shall conduct a public interview with each nominee before voting on whether to approve the nominee’s appointment.

subsection.text: The term of a Commissioner is 5 years.
Removal of a Commissioner by the County Executive requires the approval of the County Council.

Under the powers given elsewhere in this Division II, the Montgomery Commission may provide housing or housing projects for persons of eligible income, but may do so only in accordance with local law or under a contract with Montgomery County.
In accordance with subsection (a) of this section and in addition to the powers listed elsewhere in this Division II or given by local law, the Montgomery Commission may:

paragraph.text: make mortgage loans and rent subsidy payments to persons of eligible income;
make construction loans and long-term mortgage loans to any person to produce housing for persons of eligible income; and
purchase mortgages secured by housing for persons of eligible income.

subsection.text: Under the powers listed elsewhere in this Division II, the Montgomery Commission may:

paragraph.text: enter into development agreements as may be necessary or convenient in which:

subparagraph.text: at least 50% of the units are initially occupied by individuals of families whose income individually or as part of a family unit is equal to or less than:

sub-subparagraph.text: 60% of the median income for the statistical area in which the units are located as determined by the federal Office of Management and Budget; or
a lesser income that may be determined by the chief elected official or chief elected official’s designee in the jurisdiction in which the property is located; or

subparagraph.text: at least 20% of the units are initially occupied by individuals who are eligible for federal subsidies; and

paragraph.text: contract to furnish services, consultation, advice, and assistance to other housing authorities or other persons in or outside of the State to assist in developing, managing, renovating, or constructing housing described under item (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: An individual or family qualifies as a person of eligible income if the individual or family lacks enough income or assets without financial assistance to live in decent, safe, and sanitary housing without overcrowding.

paragraph.text: The County Executive, or the County Executive’s designee, shall determine whether an individual or family qualifies as a person of eligible income.

For elderly individuals, individuals with disabilities, and other individuals or families with special needs, the County Executive or the County Executive’s designee may adjust the requirements for qualifying as a person of eligible income if the County Executive or designee considers that other standards are more appropriate to achieve the public purposes stated in this subtitle.
A determination made under this subsection is conclusive of the matters determined.
The County Executive may change the definition of “person of eligible income” by issuing a proposed regulation.
The regulation shall take effect only after a public hearing held in accordance with procedures established by the County Council.

section.text: A substantial part of the housing in a housing project is deemed to be for persons of eligible income if:

paragraph.text: after financing is provided by the Montgomery Commission, 50% or more of the housing units are occupied first by persons of eligible income;
20% or more of the housing units are for low-income persons who are assisted or who are eligible to be assisted with federal subsidies; or
the owners of the housing certify to the Montgomery Commission that they will make their best efforts to meet the standard under item (1) or (2) of this section.

subsection.text: In this section, the terms “assisted family housing” and “moderate priced dwelling units” have the meanings stated in Montgomery County law.
This section does not apply to proposed scattered sites and moderate priced dwelling units:

paragraph.text: that are acquired for assisted family housing;
that are proposed by the Montgomery Commission; and
for which a public hearing is not required under Montgomery County law.
The Montgomery Commission shall hold a public hearing on any assisted family housing it proposes and report in writing the findings and conclusions from the hearing.
At least 15 days before the hearing, the Montgomery Commission shall give notice of the hearing by a display advertisement in two newspapers of general circulation in the county.

subsection.text: By May 1 of each year, the Montgomery Commission shall submit its proposed budget to the County Council.
The public shall have an appropriate opportunity to comment on the proposed budget.
On or before November 30 of each year, the Montgomery Commission shall issue a financial report for the previous fiscal year based on a certified audit.
The Montgomery Commission shall publish a summary of the financial report in at least two newspapers of general circulation in the county.
The County Executive and County Council may require an audit of the books of the Montgomery Commission.
To perform the audit, the County Executive and County Council may choose:

paragraph.text: an independent certified public accountant licensed by the State; or
a firm of certified public accountants licensed by the State.

subsection.text: The Montgomery Commission shall pay for the audit out of its operating budget.
Montgomery County may provide by local law for the county’s guarantee of the principal and interest on bonds that the Montgomery Commission issues:

paragraph.text: to finance the acquisition, provision, development, or rehabilitation of housing at rental rates and prices not being offered in adequate quantity by the private sector; or
to finance wholly or partly:

subparagraph.text: mortgage loans secured by the housing; and
fund-related reserves and costs that are approved under this subtitle.

subsection.text: When a mortgage loan is financed partly by bonds guaranteed by Montgomery County and partly by bonds not so guaranteed, the part of the mortgage loan that is financed by bonds not so guaranteed shall be insured by:

paragraph.text: the Federal Housing Administration;
the Maryland Housing Fund;
a private mortgage insurer that is:

subparagraph.text: authorized to do business in the State; and
approved by the Federal National Mortgage Association or the Federal National Mortgage Loan Corporation; or

paragraph.text: more than one of these insurers.
The Montgomery Commission shall meet the terms and conditions that the county government imposes in guaranteeing bonds issued under this subtitle and § 12-702 of this article.

If guaranteed revenue bonds are to finance the total cost of the housing, the Montgomery Commission shall meet any requirements that the county government imposes after the bonds are issued to protect the financial solvency of the housing project.

subsection.text: The total principal of the bonds guaranteed under this subtitle may not exceed $50,000,000.
Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the bonds authorized to be guaranteed under this subtitle are subject to § 312 of the County Charter.
The bonds may be structured with:

paragraph.text: substantially level debt service payments; and
interest-only payments during the projected period for construction or rehabilitation of the housing project financed with bonds issued under this subtitle and § 12-702 of this article.
The bonds shall be issued on a serial maturity plan.

Part of each issue may be sold as term bonds structured with mandatory sinking fund payments, if required for market acceptance and approved by the county government in the manner specified by the County Council resolution adopted under § 16-206 of this subtitle.
On determining to issue bonds, the Montgomery Commission shall provide to the County Executive information about the bonds and the housing projects benefitting from the bond proceeds.
The information shall include:

subparagraph.text: the terms and conditions of the bonds;
an estimate of the bond interest rate and the basis for the estimate;
the estimated timing and other provisions about the advertising and sale of the bonds;
a description of the proposed housing project, with detailed estimates of construction and related costs to make it ready to rent or sell;
detailed estimates of operating costs and debt service;
schedules of reserves for depreciation and major maintenance;
separate schedules that show how, after allowance for vacancies, revenues are expected to cover:

sub-subparagraph.text: operating costs;
debt service and capital costs; and
reserves for depreciation and major maintenance;

subparagraph.text: separate schedules that:

sub-subparagraph.text: show the cost, benefit, and effect on rent schedules of added safeguards to ensure solvency of the housing project;
address devices such as mortgage insurance and debt service reserves; and
state the recommendation of the Montgomery Commission on use of those devices;

subparagraph.text: a description of the terms and conditions for construction of the housing project, including any safeguards against construction default and the conditions under which construction financing is to be provided by the Montgomery Commission; and
a description of the accounting system for recording and controlling expenditures of bond funds, debt service, operating costs, reserves, and revenues.

subsection.text: Each housing project shall be established as an independent accounting entity for revenues, expenditures, debt service, and reserves.
The local law implementing this subtitle shall provide procedures for review and approval of the issuance of bonds guaranteed by the county government.

paragraph.text: The procedures shall include requirements for the County Executive to:

subparagraph.text: comment on the feasibility of the proposed bond guarantee and each housing project contemplated by the proposed bond guarantee; and
recommend whether the proposed bond guarantee should be approved and any terms and conditions for approval.

paragraph.text: If the County Executive recommends approval, the recommendation shall include a statement that the proposed housing project is fully self-supporting.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a recommendation by the County Executive to approve the proposed bond guarantee shall be supported by an acceptable independent feasibility study or studies that the Montgomery Commission submits.
The County Executive may waive the feasibility study requirement for a housing project financed, insured, or assisted by the State or the federal government.

subsection.text: After considering the recommendations of the County Executive and holding a public hearing, the County Council shall approve, approve with modifications, or disapprove the proposed bond guarantee.
The County Council shall state the terms and conditions of an approved bond guarantee, including:

paragraph.text: the maximum interest payable;
the terms of the bond issue;
the purposes for which the bond proceeds may be expended; and
the method of controlling the expenditures of the bond proceeds and the revenues and expenditures for housing projects financed by the bond proceeds.
An approval of a bond guarantee by the County Council shall be submitted to the County Executive within 3 days for concurrence or disapproval.

If the County Executive does not communicate disapproval and reasons for the disapproval to the County Council within 10 days after receipt of an approval of a bond guarantee from the Council, the Council’s approval shall stand.

subsection.text: The County Council may override a disapproval of a bond guarantee by a vote of at least six members.
The County Council may rescind an approval of a bond guarantee by resolution adopted:

paragraph.text: before the advertisement of the bonds; or
if the sale is to be private, before the earlier of:

subparagraph.text: the sale of the bonds; and
the distribution of a related offering circular.

subsection.text: On request of the Montgomery Commission, the county may allocate by local law a part of the total guarantee authorized by this subtitle in an amount that the local law determines.

paragraph.text: Without further approval by the County Council, the County Executive may approve by executive order the use of all or part of the allocation authorized under subsection (a) of this section as a bond guarantee.
The Montgomery Commission may then issue bonds guaranteed by as much of the allocation as the County Executive has approved as a bond guarantee, and the proceeds of the bonds shall be used to:

subparagraph.text: finance wholly or partly mortgage loans secured by housing; and
fund related reserves and costs approved under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Montgomery Commission shall provide annually to the county government an audit of each housing project financed by bonds guaranteed by the county.
The audit shall be done by:

subparagraph.text: an independent certified public accountant licensed by the State; or
a firm of independent certified public accountants licensed by the State.

paragraph.text: The accountant or firm of accountants shall provide appropriate certified financial statements and a management letter on the financial soundness of the housing project.

subsection.text: The county government may undertake financial and compliance audits on housing projects financed by bonds guaranteed under this subtitle.

section.text: A bond stating in substance that it has been issued by the Montgomery Commission to help finance a housing project for persons of eligible income shall be considered to have been issued for that purpose in a proceeding in which the validity or enforceability of the bond or the security for the bond is in question.
Montgomery Commission bonds may be sold at a public or private sale in the manner and on the terms authorized by resolution of the Montgomery Commission.
This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: an attorney in the General Counsel’s office;
an employee who assists or acts in a confidential capacity for an individual who formulates, determines, or carries out management policies in the field of labor-management relations;
a Montgomery Commission merit system employee during the employee’s initial probationary period; or
a supervisor, as defined in § 2(11) of the National Labor Relations Act, 29 U.S.C. § 152(11).

subsection.text: Montgomery Commission employees are divided into two bargaining units:

paragraph.text: the office/professional/technical unit; and
the service/labor/trade unit.

subsection.text: The office/professional/technical unit includes:

paragraph.text: office classification titles in which employees are responsible for communications, recording and retrieving information, and paperwork required in an office;

professional classification titles in which employees have special or theoretical knowledge that usually is acquired through college training, other training that provides comparable knowledge, or work experience;

paraprofessional classification titles in which employees perform, in a supportive role, some duties of a professional or technician that usually require less formal training or experience than those duties performed by those with professional or technical status; and

technical classification titles in which employees have both basic scientific or technical knowledge and manual skill that are usually acquired through specialized postsecondary school education or through equivalent on-the-job training.

subsection.text: The service/labor/trade unit includes:

paragraph.text: classification titles in which employees:

subparagraph.text: perform service and maintenance;
may operate specialized machinery or heavy equipment; and
have duties that contribute to the comfort and convenience of the public or to the upkeep and care of Montgomery Commission buildings, facilities, or grounds; and

paragraph.text: classification titles in which employees must have a special manual skill and thorough knowledge of processes that are acquired through on-the-job training, experience, apprenticeship, or formal training programs.

The Montgomery Commission shall recognize the right of an employee organization certified under this subtitle as the exclusive representative of a bargaining unit to represent the employees of the bargaining unit in collective bargaining and in the settlement of grievances.

If a single employee organization is certified to represent more than one bargaining unit, the Montgomery Commission shall negotiate a single contract with that organization covering all employees the organization represents.
An employee organization certified as the exclusive representative of a bargaining unit shall:

subparagraph.text: serve as the only bargaining agent for the unit in collective bargaining; and
represent all employees in the unit fairly, without discrimination, and without regard to whether an employee is a member of the employee organization.

paragraph.text: An employee organization meets the requirements of paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection as long as its actions are not arbitrary, discriminatory, or in bad faith toward:

subparagraph.text: employees who are members of the employee organization; or
employees who are not members of the employee organization.

subsection.text: The exclusive representative or representatives and the Montgomery Commission shall appoint a labor relations administrator from a list of five nominees on whom they have agreed.
The term of the labor relations administrator is 5 years.
A labor relations administrator is eligible for reappointment.

An employee organization that is certified or that seeks certification as an exclusive representative shall submit to the labor relations administrator a copy of the employee organization’s constitution and bylaws and any amendment to them.
The constitution or bylaws shall include:

paragraph.text: a pledge that the employee organization accepts members without regard to age, marital status, national origin, race, religion, disabilities, sexual orientation, or gender;
the right of members to participate in the affairs of the employee organization;
procedures for periodic elections of officers by secret ballot;
fair procedures governing disciplinary actions;
procedures for the accurate accounting of all income and expenditures;
a requirement that a certified annual financial report be produced; and
the right of members to inspect the employee organization’s accounts.

subsection.text: The labor relations administrator shall hold an election for an exclusive representative after:

paragraph.text: an employee organization shows by petition that at least 30% of the eligible employees in a bargaining unit support representation by an exclusive representative for collective bargaining; or
an employee or an employee organization shows by petition that at least 30% of the eligible employees in a bargaining unit no longer support the current exclusive representative.
Elections may not be held:

subparagraph.text: within 1 year after the date of an election under this subtitle; or
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, during the term of a collective bargaining agreement.

paragraph.text: During the term of a collective bargaining agreement, a petition for an election may be filed only in November of the fiscal year in which the agreement expires.

At least 30 days before an election under subsection (a) of this section, the labor relations administrator shall get from the Montgomery Commission and provide to the employee organization a list of the name, home address, and telephone number of each employee in the bargaining unit.

Providing a list under this subsection by the Montgomery Commission, the labor relations administrator, or any Montgomery Commission officials, employees, or other agents does not violate § 10-617(e) of the State Government Article or any State or local law.

subsection.text: An election shall be held by secret ballot.
The ballot shall contain:

paragraph.text: the name of each employee organization that submits a valid petition for an election;
the name of any other employee organization supported by a petition signed by at least 10% of the eligible employees in the bargaining unit; and
an option for no representation.

If a petition described in subsection (a)(1) is submitted at the same time that a petition described in subsection (a)(2) is submitted, one election shall be held to determine which employee organization, if any, shall be the exclusive representative.
The ballot shall contain:

subparagraph.text: the name of the current certified employee organization;
the name of the petitioning employee organization; and
a provision for “no representation”.

subsection.text: If none of the choices on the ballot receives a majority of the votes, the labor relations administrator shall hold a runoff election between the two choices receiving the most votes.

paragraph.text: After the election, the labor relations administrator shall certify the employee organization with the most votes as the exclusive representative.

If the petitioning employee organization is certified as a result of an election carried out under subsection (f) of this section, that employee organization shall be treated as a successor in interest and party to any collective bargaining agreement to which the previous employee organization was a party.

subsection.text: The Montgomery Commission and the employee organization shall share the costs of the election procedures equally.
An individual is eligible to vote in an election under this subtitle only if the individual is a Montgomery Commission employee to whom this subtitle applies.
If the Montgomery Commission and an employee organization dispute the eligibility of an employee in a bargaining unit, the dispute shall be submitted to the labor relations administrator.
The labor relations administrator shall hold evidentiary hearings at which the Montgomery Commission and interested employee organizations shall have the opportunity to present:

paragraph.text: testimony;
documentary and other evidence; and
arguments.

subsection.text: The decision of the labor relations administrator is final.
The Montgomery Commission and the employee organization shall share the costs of the hearings equally.
The Montgomery Commission and an employee organization certified as exclusive representative shall meet and engage in collective bargaining in good faith about:

paragraph.text: salary and wages, including the percentage of an increase in the salary and wages budget that will be devoted to merit increments and cash awards, but salaries and wages shall be the same for all employees in the same classification;
pension and other retirement benefits for active employees;
employee benefits such as insurance, leave, holidays, and vacations;
hours and working conditions;
matters affecting the health and safety of employees;
the effect of the exercise of the Montgomery Commission’s rights and responsibilities under § 16-314 of this subtitle on employees; and
provisions for orderly processing and settling grievances about the interpretation and implementation of a collective bargaining agreement that may include:

subparagraph.text: provisions for the exclusivity of forum;
binding third party arbitration, if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Montgomery Commission and the employee organization share the costs of binding arbitration equally; and
the arbitrator does not have authority to amend, add to, or subtract from the collective bargaining agreement.

subsection.text: This section does not require the Montgomery Commission or the employee organization to agree to any proposal or to make any concession.

paragraph.text: The Montgomery Commission and an employee organization certified as exclusive representative:

subparagraph.text: shall begin collective bargaining on or before September 1 in the fiscal year before the beginning of a fiscal year for which an agreement has not been reached; and
shall complete collective bargaining on or before the following February 1.

paragraph.text: During the period set forth in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the parties shall negotiate in good faith.

subsection.text: If a party considers that a bargaining proposal contravenes the rights and duties of the Montgomery Commission under § 16-314 of this subtitle or otherwise violates this subtitle, the party shall petition the labor relations administrator for a determination of whether the bargaining proposal is a negotiability dispute that contravenes this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the procedure for resolving a negotiability dispute shall follow the procedure for reviewing unfair labor practice charges.
The labor relations administrator may shorten the time periods or order any expedited procedure appropriate under the circumstances.

subsection.text: The labor relations administrator may order a party to withdraw all or part of a bargaining proposal that contravenes this subtitle.
A decision and order under this section is final unless it is appealed for being arbitrary, capricious, or exceeding the authority of a party.

paragraph.text: If the parties have not reached an agreement on or before December 1 on a collective bargaining agreement that would become effective the following July 1, the parties shall jointly appoint a mediator-arbitrator.
If the parties are unable to agree on a mediator-arbitrator, the labor relations administrator shall name the mediator-arbitrator on or before December 7.
